Title: 5 Reasons Why You Shouldn’t Bother Going To Berlin
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Whether you’re looking for ideas for a fun-packed weekend break, what to see and do in top cities around the world, or are after a backpacking experience condensed into a couple of weeks, you’ll find it here.

--
Listen
Share
Should you visit Berlin? Absolutely not, as these five points prove. Not only will you have to endure a city where everyone seems to have no responsibilities and only want to party, your trip will then ruin the rest of your life when looking back at the very few things Berlin does well. Read on for some important warnings on why you shouldn’t bother visiting Berlin…
Clubbing in Berlin is like nothing else I’ve experienced. From the ridiculous door policies and marathon opening times to the endless techno, you’ll find that the nightlife in Germany’s capital is very unusual. But after just one night of being indoctrinated into the Berlin way of doing things, you’ll realise that they just do it better.
In Berlin clubs, it’s frowned upon to take photos — in some, photography is banned. But why would you want to take photos of your mates in the club anyway? Just enjoy the moment, your life shouldn’t be about showing off to your Instagram followers. Who cares if you got into Berghain, anyway??
You also won’t find any mirrors in the club toilets, either. Or anywhere else for that matter. But if you’re actually there to have a good time, does it even matter what you look like?
Next is the music. No one loves techno quite as much as Berliners do. Last time I went to Ipse in east Berlin, the crowd cheered after each DJ finished their set. Moments later, the next DJ would come on and play what sounds like the exact same track, only with a slightly different snare drum sample.
SEE ALSO: 4 things you’ll learn about clubbing in Berlin
And if you’re not into the hypnotic, monotonous music, you’re not getting in, because the bouncers will quiz you on who’s playing.
However, after clubbing in Berlin, you’ll realise that clubs elsewhere are full of posers who are just there to be seen, pretending to have fun. Does anyone even have fun in clubs outside of Berlin? Most likely, they’re not. In Berlin, they’re actually there because they love the music.
And that’s how it should be. Why go to a club with ludicrous drinks prices to pretend you’re something you’re not and live a lifestyle you don’t lead, just to impress a load of other people who’re in exact same boat as you. You might be sitting in the VIP booth, but truth is after tonight you’ll be back on your zero hours contract job or skipping your media studies lecture.
At least in Berlin, clubbers are honest. When you get home, clubbing will be ruined for you as you’ll realise just how futile and pathetic it is anywhere else.
Berlin is probably one of the cheapest major cities in the world. Want a latte at the train station? It’s yours for the princely sum of €1. Want a kebab? That’s €3.50. In fact, the only thing that’s overpriced is entry to the TV Tower.
Trust me, in just a few days you’ll get used to the low prices (unless you head over to Poland or Hungary next!) and when you get home, if you’re from the UK, the USA, or elsewhere in western or northern Europe, things will suddenly seem so expensive.
On a night out in east Berlin, you could have a beer for under €2. That would cost you around £5 in London. We even picked up 0.5l bottles of beer at a convenience store for €0.60. Sixty cents. That’s insanely cheap!
Nothing ever happened in Berlin. It might be the capital of Germany, but Germany only became a country in 1871. Even the USA has 100 years on that, while England was unified in the 10th century and has been a country ever since.
Plus, Berlin was almost totally destroyed in 1945. And nothing really happened after that…
Of course in reality, Berlin was one of the major flash points in the Cold War. Take the Berlin Crisis in 1961, where US and Soviet tanks had a standoff for 16 hours, 50 meters apart, with live ammunition. Chilling stuff.
Or the Berlin Wall, and the numerous escape attempts that led to hundreds of East Germans tragically dying at the hands of the border guards, as well as the fascinating stories of how a handful of people got away with it through their audacious escape attempts. You can learn about these at the Berlin Wall Museum at Checkpoint Charlie.
And who can forget the former German Democratic Republic? If you’ve been watching Deutschland 83, you’ll already know about the East German Communist state. Find out what life was like behind the iron curtain in the DDR museum in Berlin Mitte. Though it was one of the more successful communist states, you’ll learn that freedom was severely restricted, and find out how the population coped by listening to communist music, watching steroid-fuelled sports, and going on nudist beach holidays (yes, really).
Berlin is known for it’s chilled freewheeling spirit, that’s much less intense than other large cities like London or Paris. You’ll find the people here are really down to earth and relaxed. In the summer months, many people sit out drinking at beach bars on the banks of the river Spree, or take a dip in the Badeschiff.
They’re not uptight about when clubs close like in other cities — parties from Friday night are known to stay open until Monday morning. No matter what time of day or day of the week, you’ll see people relaxing and having fun, partly down to the rise of flexi-time working hours in the city.
SEE ALSO: What in the world is travel hacking?
The city is also home to around 20,000 artists, drawn to the city thanks to cheap rents and tons of studio space. Similarly, Berlin is a hotspot for tech startups, meaning there’s lots of hipsters to meet in the multitude of quirky, independent bars.
After you leave, you’ll miss the constant party scene, particularly if you’re going back to the daily grind of the rat race back home.
Bologna has bolognese, Tokyo has sushi, and Berlin has… doner kebabs?
But these aren’t the standard greasy kebabs you’d pick up at 3 am after stumbling out of a grimy provincial Essex nightclub. The döner im brot is ubiquitous across Berlin, and absolutely delicious, served with salad, and both garlic and herb and hot sauce. The grilled bread that these kebabs are served in makes all the difference, rather than the dry pitta you’d get served in the UK. While you can pick up a doner anywhere, you can find the best in the city here.
Let’s also not forget the famous curry wurst, made from a steamed, then fried pork sausage, served with a ketchup based sauce topped with curry powder, and a side of fries.
The humble curry wurst owes its existence to World War Two. The dish was invented by Herta Heuwer in Charlottenburg, west Berlin, in 1949. Having acquired curry powder, ketchup and Worcestershire sauce from the occupying British troops, serving up the first curry wursts to the construction workers rebuilding the city.
Today, Berliners can’t get enough, guzzling 70 million of them each year.
So yes, food in Berlin really is the wurst (sorry)
This article first appeared at The Traveloid.

Title: A City Finding Itself: How Berlin’s Startup Ecosystem Evolved
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Included VC: the first of-its-kind fully funded global Fellowship designed to provide opportunity to underrepresented and overlooked aspiring VCs who are actively committed to breaking into, and pursuing a career in venture capital.

--
4
Listen
Share
While chatting a few years ago about Berlin with a venture capital veteran from the Silicon Valley, he mentioned that he saw Berlin as ‘a city finding itself’. As a recurrent visitor of the city since 1998, I can relate to that statement; I can happily say that by now, this city has developed a character of its own (on the startups’ side).
Berlin is the capital of Germany, and one of the most eventful cities in the world.
It is a city of contrast where history and newness encounter each other on every corner.
A good example is that the city serves as the center for all political decisions in Germany as well as the hub for startups and technology advancement. But before we look at the current state of the city, it is useful to go down memory lane and understand the following:
After World War II (1945) the city was mostly destroyed. Situated at the center of such a dark recent history, the city needed to rebuild itself and was in an awkwardly divided position: West and East Berlin. The West side was controlled by the American, British and French, while the East side was controlled by the Soviet Union. The division was so strong that there was even a physical manifestation of it, the Berlin Wall, which was built in 1961 and only fell in 1989. The city became the capital of the German nation in 1991 and then started its reconstruction process.
Two main factors determined the type of people that lived or moved to the city and would later become critical for the development of the startup ecosystem:
These factors attracted talent to Berlin, creating density over time and increasing its appeal to internationals. In the words of a friend:
“Berlin is not a city where people brag about a 6-course menu at a restaurant, but rather one where people talk about the clubs they frequent.”
That alternativeness in what it means to have “made it” in the city attracts a distinct crowd.
So let’s create a short timeline with some of the main events in this ecosystem building process:
In the early 2000s, there was arguably not much happening in the city in terms of industry. In Germany, a highly decentralized country, every region or “Bundesland” was relatively specialized in terms of a certain type of business: insurance in Munich or energy in Essen. Berlin was mostly known for being the city where the artists and the government were located, but there was no big industry, which made it a fertile ground for people to build from scratch.
The first wave of startups in Berlin dates to the interval between 2007 and 2010. Within that time the city gave birth to startups like studiVZ (social network), Immobilienscout24, Zalando, Idealo, Gate5, and Jamba. Jamba was the second exit from the Samwer brothers who later became the founders of Rocket Internet. Gate5 was sold to Nokia, and the founder, Christophe Maire, would later go on to start Atlantic Labs.
This period saw the rise of venture builders; since these types of companies are not common everywhere, I’ll explain: Venture Builders are companies that focus on launching new businesses from a core team that develops them and supports them with some central functions such as HR and Legal. In short, these are companies whose purpose is to create other “child” companies. While venture builders are now present across the world, there has been a strong concentration in Berlin.
Around 2011, there were two venture builders in the city: Team Europe and Rocket Internet. Team Europe was started by Kolja Hebenstreit, Lukasz Gadowski, and supported the early days of Delivery Hero (Lieferheld back then), Wooga, and Spreadshirt. Rocket Internet was started by the Samwer brothers who had previously founded and successfully exited companies such as Alando and Jamba. There has been plenty written about the Rocket Internet and the Samwer brothers’ story, but I personally recommend reading this version by The Generalist.
While there are mixed opinions on the company and its ethics, no one can deny that they were one of the largest catalyzers to make the Berlin startup hub “happen”. Among the companies that benefited from the Rocket Internet force, we can find some of the most iconic scale ups such as Delivery Hero, HelloFresh, Zalando, Home24, and Westwing.
As time progressed, startups originated not only from venture builders but from other founders entering the scene; some of those stories relate to SoundCloud, Wunderlist, EyeEm, SumUp and Amen. On the venture capital side of things, some VCs started to see an opportunity in Berlin and one of the first ones to establish a presence here was Earlybird, which moved from Hamburg to Berlin in 2013. Berlin started to appear in the international startup scene, so much so that even Ashton Kutcher decided to invest in the city back in 2012.
Several of the companies mentioned before were the bootcamps for much of the talent we see today, and as talent churned from the bigger companies, more ventures got built. At this point in time, most of the companies built in Berlin had a flavor of commerce, consumer and copy-cats. People associated Berlin with power of execution, but not necessarily with innovation.
By 2014, Oliver Samwer, the older brother of the trio, started to professionalize his investing and from that Global Founders Capital was born. It was right around that time that Rocket Internet was considered to have reached its peak success, where many of its ventures such as HelloFresh, GlossyBox, DeliveryHero, and Zalando were present not only in Germany but had also started international expansion.
As Berlin became more recognized as a startup hub and the venture building practices became internationally known, more venture builders started to emerge such as Hitfox (now IONIQ), which expanded into fintech with finleap and later into healthtech as Heartbeat Labs. Many of these venture builders not only built for themselves but also for corporations, and soon enough it became common for several German corporations to establish their innovation practices in Berlin. Examples include Lufthansa Innovation Hub, BCG Digital Ventures, and Körber Digital enabled by consultants such as BCG Digital Ventures.
In 2015 Wunderlist, a startup from entrepreneur Christian Reber and the Wunderkinder crew, was sold to Microsoft for $125 million. While compared to some of the valuations and exits we are seeing in the current VC climate this might seem small, at the time this was a major milestone for the Berlin ecosystem. This made it clear that it was possible to build something out of Berlin and exit to global players.
By 2016, Berlin was well recognized as the second largest startup hub in Europe, only behind London. It is around this period when Rocket Internet stopped incubating more businesses. At an ecosystem level, there were already enough small successes to have attracted more capital to Berlin and many new VCs were founded: Point9, Cherry Ventures, and LaFamiglia.
As aspirations in the city grew, it became increasingly attractive to international funds opening offices in Berlin– properly committing to the city. Some examples of international funds opening offices in Berlin include Creandum, Heartcore, and Speedinvest.
The success stories of previous years have encouraged more people to pursue entrepreneurship as a viable career path. As we look into the future of Berlin, the city has diversified the type of industries it serves into fintech, logistics, mobility, edtech, etc… Furthermore, it is expected that some of the Berlin based unicorns will IPO or be acquired in the coming years, leaving several employees with disposable income to invest or start new things on their own. At the same time, this also means more second-time founders and operators with scale-up experience that will continue the flywheel in the ecosystem.
On the VC side, the proliferance of smaller VCs led to a general sentiment that Berlin has consolidated its spot as one of the leading European hubs, taking on increasingly more ambitious challenges. Two movements that were not discussed in this narrative so far were the governmental initiatives to enhance the startup ecosystem, such as the Adlershof, and the fact that for a while Berlin was considered one of the crypto hubs of Europe.
For now, I believe it is time to bring the story to the current times and identify who the movers and shakers in the ecosystem are:
By now it is no secret that nearly every important fund in the world has at some point invested in a Berlin-based company, however I want to focus our attention on funds that are “headquartered” or “committed” in Berlin.
The first category, “headquartered”, contains funds who were founded or moved their headquarters into the city. The second category, “committed”, contains the funds that have at least one person permanently based in Berlin; hence they have formalized their commitment to the city.
While the city’s stars are and will always be the startups, it is useful to see some of the VCs as the catalysts for innovation happening in the city. Many of those VCs are operators turned investors or individuals who have boldly betted on Berlin being the next innovation center of Europe. By late August, Sifted reported that Berlin startups had already obtained €5.1bn in investment:
As we can see this means that by the time I publish this article, the city is likely to have doubled the investment from 2019, the record year until now.
On the startup side, I don’t think I’d ever finish this article if I were to list all the startups in Berlin. Nonetheless, I want to highlight some of the ones that have successfully put the city on the global map:
I want to finish this article by encouraging everyone to move to, invest in or visit Berlin. Nowadays, there are more factors that contribute to the city continuing to gain the hearts of many, so here are few selling points:
Overall, it has taken a while for Berlin to become the startup capital we know and love. I am bullish on Berlin continuing to attract highly qualified talent and increasingly incubating more European unicorns. Come visit or message me if you have extra stories on the city.

Title: Summer Set Ablaze in Climate-Conscious Berlin
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

International journalism students report from Berlin, the heart of Europe.

--
Listen
Share
KREUZBERG, Berlin — At the Berlinische Galerie on Alte Jakobstraße, I rounded the corner to an exhibition room and was taken aback by a large, ape-like creature sprawled across the concrete floor in an installation that I can only term narrative art.
The ape was coated in black, stringy fur that small worker figures were stripping from her back, leaving her torso a bloody mess. Her mouth hung wide open as wooden structures leaned up against her face with other small human figures trying to extract resources from her teeth. Some laborers had even gone to loot her private parts, loading her treasures into overflowing trucks. They were stripping her bare, capitalizing on her death, and destroying her corpse to feed their greed.
On display until Aug. 21, the art installation “The Sweet Certainty of Deliverance from the Darkness that Surrounds Us” portrays the imminent threat the planet faces, with rising temperatures and natural disasters caused by greenhouse gas emissions and unsustainable ways of life and production.
Witnessing this artistic raid on the creature’s body, a feeling of violation crept up in me, confronting me with the reality animals have faced in the race toward industrialization. My feet quickly moved to the next room.
In the middle of that hall, a flower bud-shaped paper-mâché spaceship draws the eyes, luring people to enter. Within it, the faces of animals stared back at me. Surrounding the vessel are large brown leaves, each holding a painting depicting the story of human evolution and collectivism that was set ablaze by mankind.
Apes fall from trees transforming into humans. Together, the apes burn down the forests and trees from where they came. In a last effort to preserve what remains of the land, the animals work together to build the vessel featured in the center of the room, which sends humans into space as animals watch them leave the world they have destroyed.
Leaving the exhibit, I was overcome by guilt and shame.
German and Romanian artists Matthias Boehler and Christian Orendt present their shocking view of the future of civilization, attempting to explain why humans waste resources, burn acres of forests that provide the Earth with oxygen, and produce more gas emissions than ever recorded. The two have worked together since 2008, creating art installations that provoke their viewers into questioning their responsibility and prompting them to change their ways of life by experiencing impactful and ironic mixed media exhibits.
While the storyline is a work of fiction, the work portrays a reality that is eerily familiar. Thoughts of billionaires flying into space and power plant fumes drifting up through the Earth’s atmosphere entered my mind. The exhibit conjured the smell of fires burning and ashy-covered streets in California — now also happening near my home in Queens, New York, where glass shards and Styrofoam litter concrete roads that used to host freshly cut fields of luscious poppies.
Now, walking around the streets of Berlin, I am reminded of how we globally share the challenge of survival. Advertisements for sustainable products surround me. It is easy to be a more eco-conscious guest on Earth in Berlin, where the importance of conservation is posted along the walls of train stations and covers the beams of streetlights.
This is not the case in the United States, where recycling is an afterthought and rarely enforced. It is difficult to find a can to throw out trash along the streets of Manhattan. Walking is not an option in Los Angeles, when there are no sidewalks, forcing me to get behind the wheel.
In Berlin, I am rewarded with a Euro coin every time I return a glass bottle or cup, urging me to reflect on my plastic consumption. When riding the U-Bahn, I am given four options on how to dispose of my trash, prompting me to discover what materials my waste is made of. To beat the summer heat, I can find solace on a former runway at a reimagined Tempelhof airport, surrounded by lush gardens and commuting cyclists. In this city, greenery stretches across historic streets crowded with people enjoying the sunshine, filling me with hope.
Berlin seems to understand the pleasures of living on the Earth and the need to take action now. After walking out of the Berlinische Gallery, I am beginning to as well.
Rebecca Fairweather is a political science student at UC Santa Barbara who works for UCSB TV and The Indy podcast at the Santa Barbara Independent newspaper. She is reporting from Berlin this summer as part of ieMedia’s “Berlin Beyond Borders” editorial team.

Title: Berlin Has Woken Up
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

The joy of blogging while exploring your home country. A slice of your life, Food, culture, nature and more.

Member-only story
Featured
--
10
Share
You’ve probably heard of Elon Musk. You’ve definitely heard of Berlin. What I didn’t know before moving here two years ago is that it’s not just Germany’s capital — it’s also Europe’s techno capital, home to some of the most famous clubs in the world. One of them, Berghain, is a ten-minute walk from my apartment. Yes, that Berghain — the one that supposedly denied entry to Elon Musk. Now, it all makes sense. And that also tells you everything you need to know about this place.
Berlin is a story.
Berlin is many things.
For many Europeans, Berlin is an escape — from old values, expectations, responsibilities. It’s a weekend escape, a semester-long detour, a soft rebellion. You drink, you party, you feel unglued.
Berlin is an open air museum of war, destruction; but also of freedom and choice. Berlin has transcended its strictly geographical boundaries, and has transformed into more of a lifestyle.
Clothes — black; chains, nets.
Smell — urine, tabacco, weed.
Drink — beer or weinschorle.
State of mind — sad or happy.
Free time — nature, parks, rivers, lakes, nudist beaches, biking.
Money spent — on rent; in small cafes, flee markets, secondhand shops.

Title: Berlin Opera Academy: An Honest Review
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

On the art, the joy and the struggle of being your own instrument.

--
Listen
Share
Edit: After posting this, I got a lot of responses from people who also attended the Berlin Opera Academy and had something to say. I’ve asked for their permission to share their stories. You can find them at the bottom of this article.
On the first day of BOA 2022, during the general assembly, the head of the program gave us a rousing speech. It really was very good — you could see people eyes lighting up, and I felt my own face glow with anticipation.
However, he said one thing that made me a little suspicious. ‘Be positive,’ he told us. ‘Have a positive mindset. Don’t grumble or complain. Make something out of it.’
Of course, I completely agree with the benefits of a positive mindset. There’s a lot of whining and complaining in any world, and we’d all be better off without it. But at the same time, this sounded defensive to me — as if he knew there were things that weren’t right, and hoped to not get too much pushback.
As it turned out, the BOA program, for all its merits, has a few drawbacks that I think people should be aware of before signing up.
But let’s start on that positive note.
BOA is a great initiative and Berlin is a great city. The teachers that they attract are often amazing and will give you valuable feedback. They will often give you their honest opinion, and because you’re seeing lots of different people in a short amount of time, you will start to notice which comments keep popping up. I, for example, heard that I was moving around rather aimlessly from three different teachers. That’s when you know it should be the first priority on your list of things to fix.
This is a great opportunity that might be worth paying for, especially if you’ve never done it before (I hadn’t).
You’ll get to actually do a whole opera and you will be guided by professional conductors and directors. I got extremely lucky: my opera (Suor Angelica) was directed by Susan Stone. She displayed a kind of professionalism that I really learned a lot from over the span of four weeks. She was kind and open, but not overly familiar. She was ridiculously smart, had very original ideas for the piece which the executed with meticulous precision, and held us and herself to a very high standard. It was one of the most inspiring things that month.
You might make some new friends, and you’ll be able to see how you measure up to others. This will be both encouraging and discouraging. Personally, I learned that, repertoire-wise, I was way better prepared than almost anyone else there, which was lovely. But I also learned that my interpretations suffered because I wasn’t intentional enough in my on-stage movement. This was painful to realise, but it was very important as it allowed me to work on it.
During the first two weeks, I got into exactly zero masterclasses. That’s right. The booking system where you are supposed to make your own appointments was deeply flawed. It basically meant that whoever had the fastest internet connection could get multiple masterclasses every day, while others went weeks without getting a masterclass. When the students of BOA 2022 complained, there were “warnings” issued to those who over-booked. But by then, many people had fallen behind in a way that could not be fixed. When I finally got my first masterclass in week three, I let the teacher know how happy I was to finally have snagged a spot. The teacher said: ‘Are you serious? I’m seeing some people for the fourth time today.’After that, I took it upon myself to help distribute classes fairly by snagging masterclasses I’d already been to and contact people that hadn’t worked with that teacher yet, to give them my spots. I even contacted some teachers separately and paid them for private lessons at their homes, because BOA wouldn’t have them back for more classes. The people at BOA had no solution for this problem, other that to issue warnings and block people who had had too many masterclasses — but as this only happened halfway into the program, most people were not able to make up for their lost time. This meant that some people got way more than their money’s worth from BOA, while others really did not.
This was one of the factors that resulted in the over-booked masterclasses. While I was there, they were staging three or four operas at the same time, all with three separate casts. This meant an absurd number of singers, all fighting over the same finite resources. It also means that everyone’s attention is spread very thin. The maestro has to work with two other people singing the same role as you, and they’re also working on the other productions. In my case, our director was working with four casts simultaneously — two for Suor Angelica and two for Gianni Schicchi — while the conductor was working on every production that was going on at that moment (do the math: 4 operas x 3 casts per opera). Whelp.
The Berlin Opera Academy also accepts people with little to no experience (who then eat up all the time with the conductor because they haven’t studied or cannot sing their parts). I knew all my parts by heart when I got there. My “time with the conductor” was five minutes in a huge rehearsal, after which he said ‘Great, thank you’ and moved on to the two other people singing the same part.
Let me be clear: there were people at BOA 2022 who said: ‘It wasn’t like this last time.’ I think I caught the program at an especially bad time. I came during the busiest month, and halfway into the production, the entire costume and set department quit because of unsafe working conditions and the fact that BOA had not delivered on their promises to them (which BOA admitted). They tried to salvage the situation, but in the end many productions had to scramble to get any kind of costumes together.
This is a relatively minor issue, but the venue where the operas were staged was a letdown. The ‘changing rooms’ were a gigantic, completely dark garage-like space that was open to the elements. When it rained, there was water everywhere. The hall is very oddly designed and is clearly better suited to an art exposition than music. The orchestra sat to the right of the performers, while there were a couple of chairs herded together in the far corner for a tiny audience. I felt a bit embarrassed that I had invited my family to come see the production.
If you’re looking for that glamorous opera feeling, this is not the right program. Considering sticker price is almost €5000, I would have expected more.
Well… that depends. For me, it was worth the money, but mostly because I hadn’t done anything like this before, I got a partial scholarship and because I was willing to pay teachers separately for extra classes. I learned a lot and had lots of fun experiences. But I don’t think I would ever go there again, and I would not pay the full price to go there.
After I published this article, I got lots of comments from fellow students. Some of them were generous enough to let me share their opinions here.
I’d have mentioned the amount of commuting you have to do between rehearsals and classes/coachings. But overall, I think it’s too generous to BOA, to be honest. The thing is a scam. I felt so bad for the kids who paid €5000 to be triple cast as the third genie or something. And members of staff sexually propositioned people on the course after they’d finished their final show. I’ve told so many people not to do it.- Anonymous
Honestly, I think you covered everything very well — the only thing I would maybe add was that we weren’t really in “Berlin” we were very much on the outskirts of the city and had to take public transit for like 45 mins to each location, which made it hard to be able to participate in everything, to be honest.- Charlotte Forknall
I think what we received as participants in the programme was completely unacceptable. If I hadn’t received scholarship from BOA and from another source, I would probably be fighting to get a refund. I’ve done other summer programmes before and this was easily the worst, and cannot even be compared because the standard is so low. If anyone were to ask me about BOA, I would without hesitation tell them it’s a scam. - Anonymous
1000% agree with everything you said. The only reason I do it, is it’s the cheapest conducting program that includes opera. - Anonymous
I totally agree with each and every word. We as singers are so desperate to sing and do our job, that sometimes we don’t ask ourselves questions like: ‘Did I pay too much and get too little?’ This whole industry is telling us to be happy and grateful, and not to advocate for ourselves. But I think it’s important to not only be positive. Especially if you’re a woman and you’re a bit angry, people call you a bitch. But it’s not a bitchy quality, it’s a human quality to protect yourself and stay with the truth. I think it’s really important to speak about, if we want this business work for everybody, and not just for money.- Katsia Kaya
About the authorHere so you can learn from my mistakes: a classical singer/writer/recovering dancer, bringing you heartfelt stories and uppity advice.
--
--
On the art, the joy and the struggle of being your own instrument.

Title: Running the Berlin Marathon
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Fancy taking on a fast, flat World Major Marathon where world records are made? Here’s what you can expect if you’re thinking about running the Berlin Marathon!
The Berlin Marathon is one of the six Abbott World Major Marathons and is the fastest of them all. With only 285ft (87m) of elevation gain it’s not surprising Eliud Kipchoge ran world records here in 2018 and 2021, clocking a massive 2:01:09 at the latter.
So if you’re thinking about taking on a race that’s renowned for producing PBs, here’s what you can expect from running the Berlin Marathon.
Berlin Marathon sends lots of comms, but many were only in German. Yes, yes, I know it’s a race in Germany, but I’d signed up in English, selected my communication preference as ‘English’ so I didn’t understand why I was getting emails in German.
The pre-race programme was terrible — one of those useless digital e-books that was impossible to flip through a single page when using a mobile phone. And as the first half was in German (again, no issues with that) and second half in English, it was almost impossible to easily find the details you were looking for. Even a pdf would’ve been a big improvement on this, but for anyone with digital accessibility needs it would’ve been virtually impossible to find any information.
It was disappointing.
The Berlin Marathon Expo took place at Tempelhof Airport to the south of the city, an easy ride there on the U-bahn (which was free to ride for marathon runners during the whole time the Expo was open and on race day).
I arrived about 08:00 so I could take part in the Generali Berlin Marathon Shakeout Run. It was free to enter and anyone could attend, so if you were with family or friends (and they were happy running about 6k!) everyone could run (althought from 2023, the shakeout run has moved back to its usual spot at the Olympic Stadium, starting at 09:30).
It was very relaxed, I’d highly recommend taking part.
The Expo itself was inside several old airport hangars. It had quite an old-skool, Cold War-era vibe to it, which just added to the atmosphere of running in Berlin.
To enter, I had to show my race card (I’d added mine to my iPhone so it was quick and easy) and photographic ID, then they heat-sealed a wrist band to my wrist. I was told I needed to keep this on until after the race, but very frankly after the Expo, no-one asked for it — my race bib was enough. That said, I wouldn’t tamper with it, just in case… even though I had to cut mine off as there was no way it’d come loose by itself!
Race bib pickup was at the very back of the Expo and once there was quick and easy. If you’d bought a finisher’s t-shirt, you had to pick that up at another counter, where you had to go outside, join a queue, then come back inside the hangar. It again was quick, but not very intuitive.
Adidas had loads of official gear for sale, so if you liked the Berlin Marathon merchandise you could load up before you left.
My family had come with me to Berlin so I’d signed the kids up to do the kids’ races taking place on the Saturday. The first was the Bambini Run for my 5 year-old, which also took place at Tempelhof.
It was pretty congested getting the kids to the start line and they didn’t allow parents through for our age category (parents could accompany the 0–2 year olds and 3–4 year olds, but not the 5–6 year olds onwards). I was a concerned my Little Girl would freak out being by herself — especially as most of the announcements were only in German — but she was fine, the marshals were great at herding the kids around and she finished with a beaming smile on her face!
Her run was only about 500m, but it was enough so she felt like she had taken part.
On the Saturday afternoon, there was a Mini-Marathon for older kids, starting at Potsdamer Platz. There was very little information about it online — and nothing in English — so I’d emailed the organisers and asked how I could sign up my son and they were very quick to get back to me with a link and a code.
Apparently the Mini-Marathon — which covers the last 4.195km of the main Berlin Marathon route — is a big schools event, with around 10,000 schoolchildren from all over Germany participating. We had a bit of a nightmare trying to pickup my son’s race bib as apparently pickup at the Expo had ended on the Thursday and when we got there on Saturday, no-one at SCC (the event organiser) knew what was happening. We eventually found the bib pickup area but it was closed down.
So we headed to the start line in Potsdamer Platz and asked SCC there, and got Little Man’s bib in about 60 seconds — very easy! Although by this point they only had large finisher’s t-shirts left, so he’s got a good few years to grow into it!
He absolutely loved the race, it was by far the largest he’d participated in and he even got to run through the Brandenburg Gate before I did!
Collecting him afterwards was hugely stressful, however. There was no clear signage on where to go — all the parents headed into the Berlin Marathon finisher’s area but the actual end of the Mini-Marathon was further down the road. There were also two exits, so we were freaking out a bit as we didn’t anticipate that so had no idea where Little Man would emerge. I took one exit and my wife took the other, and thankfully I found him pretty quickly.
So from his perspective, the Mini-Marathon was awesome… I’m so happy he enjoyed it but as a parent it was a massive stress from start to finish.
On Marathon Day itself, getting to the start line of the Berlin Marathon was one of the easiest experiences I’ve ever had.
No need to get up in the middle of the night to catch a ferry to Staten Island like you do when running the New York Marathon, or jumping on a bus from pretty much the finish line to the start if you run the Athens Authentic Marathon or Boston Marathon.
Berlin Marathon starts in Tiergarten near the Reichstag and travel by U-bahn and S-bahn is free, with the trains run every few minutes.
There’s not much there at the start village of the Berlin Marathon.
I only recall massive queues for toilets (until the men discovered they had outdoor urinals). There were also many bag drop areas, which you could walk up to and drop-off without queuing.
Before entering my corral, I found a small piece of ground to run some warm-up loops, then saw a team mate from my running club so we headed into the corrals together.
There are no toilets in the corrals, but there are more toilets and urinals just before you enter. And if you’re tempted to go in the bushes you’ll be out of luck — literally everywhere was fenced off, so it was either go in the toilets/ urinals or not at all.
Berlin Marathon is a loop, starting and finishing in Tiergarten in the city centre.
You start in the park just beyond the Reichstag parliament building and head west past Victory Monument before turning right and looping round Tiergarten and into Mitte.
There are a couple of small bridges over the Spree but you’ll barely feel them. The first ‘uphill’ segment is around Mile 4, with an elevation gain of +25ft (7.6m). There’s another +22ft (6.7m) segment in Mile 6, then the course is virtually flat until Mile 19 when there’s a -26ft (7.9m) segment and another downhill -24ft (7.3m) segment in Mile 21.
So bottom line is, you’re not really going to feel any of the elevation gain, but there are a couple of nice (but short!) downhill sections later in the race.
The Berlin Marathon begins to draw to a close running through Potsdamer Platz, where the crowds become thronging again. Support is great along the entire marathon course, and even though for 90% of the race it’s thin, the crowd gives off a welcoming vibe.
Lots of families were out supporting, with dozens of kids looking for high-fives, which was really motivating. Berlin Marathon also prints your name on your bib, and even though my name is difficult for non-English speakers to pronounce I had more personal shout-outs running the Berlin Marathon than any other race. You really feel a close connection with the crowd.
The final stretch of the Berlin Marathon has you running through the famous Brandenburg Gate and past the Reichstag to the finish line. But as the Brandenburg Gate is still a good 400m from the finish line, it’s prudent to hold off that sprint finish until you get a little closer!
Water and aid stations are plentiful along the course, the first set are at the 5k mark and then every 2.5k afterwards. Just watch out for the brown liquid — it’s cold, sweet tea, so not to everyone’s liking!
Eliud Kipchoge may have ran a new world record that day, but I knew I wasn’t going to PB at the Berlin Marathon.
I’d had a terrible training block over the summer with two consecutive injuries that put me out for five weeks, then two weeks before the Berlin Marathon I caught COVID-19.
I also had to think about running the Chicago Marathon two weeks later, so for me the Berlin Marathon was going to be an exercise in discipline.
I decided to try to run negative splits for the first time at this distance, running the first 20 miles between 7:20 and 7:40 min/ mile, then seeing what I could give for the last 10k.
I managed to clock my first 5 miles at an average pace of 7:35 mins/ mile, then upped it to 7:20 mins/ mile up to Mile 20. I felt surprisingly good at this point, so cracked on to average 6:50 mins/ mile for the last 10k, with a sprint finish peaking at 4:59 mins/ mile at the end.
Without any hills or other notable terrain to contend with — unlike the monster hill in the middle of the Athens Authentic Marathon or the ups and downs of the New York Marathon over the many bridges — Berlin Marathon lets you focus on what pace you’d like to run to achieve your goal.
I can see why it’s so fast!
The Chicago Marathon may be flatter, but Chicago suffers from poor GPS coverage through The Loop, which makes it hard to know exactly how fast you’re going at the start and the halfway point, plus all those 90-degree bends mean you slow down at every corner.
Berlin Marathon, on the other hand, just flows, and bar one sharp turn just before Mile 3 when the two lanes of runners merge, the rest was easy going.
Post-race was excellent!
There was a massive positive vibe as Kipchoge had just ran a new world record, then the sun started to peep out. It had been a comfortable 12C (54F) for the race, so the timing (for me at least) was perfect.
You get your medal pretty much right after you finish, then water and a few other bits and pieces. It’s about a 1km walk to the end of the finish area, where it’s extremely important NOT to miss the Erdinger tents giving out their Alkoholfrei beer!
I headed to the grassed area in front of the Reichstag and sat on my poncho, drinking in the sun and my ice cold beer. I could’ve stayed there much longer, but besides the Erdinger tents there wasn’t much else going on. So after half an hour to chill, I headed back to the U-bahn station and my hotel for a well-earned bath.
I really, really enjoyed running the Berlin Marathon.
Even though the organisation wasn’t always been plain sailing up until race day, the Berlin Marathon itself was superb.
The atmosphere was relaxed, the support had a real warmth to it and the course lets you concentrate on your race.
One thing I will say about the Berlin Marathon is that it’s hard to notice anything specific about many of the areas you run through as they all kinda blend into one. Sure, the downtown area around Potsdamer Platz had a unique vibe to it, but bar the final mile through the Brandenburg Gate I had no idea where in the city I was at any given time. For sure that’s mostly on me for not being very familiar with Berlin, but I didn’t have the same issues when running the New York Marathon or running the Chicago Marathon, where it’s very clear when you move from one borough or neighbourhood to another.
This isn’t really a criticism, just an observation, and it certainly hasn’t put me off wanting to run the Berlin Marathon again.
As one of the six Abbott World Major Marathons, Berlin Marathon always sells out every year. So if you’re thinking about entering, you’ll need to be fast!
Odds through the lottery are decent — I got in on my first attempt — and it opens right after the race finishes, so one year ahead. Time qualifiers need to meet a pretty tough standard — a sub-2:45 for men aged 44 and under and a sub-3:00 for women in the same age bracket.
But if you’re looking for a marathon PB on a fast, flat course with amazing support, give running the Berlin Marathon a go!
If you’ve liked this race report, you can check out my other reports on Running the New York Marathon, Running the Chicago Marathon and Running the Athens Authentic Marathon.
Follow me on Instagram and share your own running journey with me.
--
--
Long distance runner with an unhealthy obsession for marathons!

Title: Captivating Interwar Modernism in Berlin. Part 1
Content:

Sign up

2
Listen
Share
A hundred years ago, Berlin was among the biggest cities in the world as its population rapidly grew from 2 to 4,5 million. Just imagine the demand for new housing at that time! Eventually, the city became a testing ground for architectors’ creativity and social experiments.
Passionate about the ideas of affordable mass housing, modernists were trying to make utopia come true — create cheap, standard, and, if possible, lovely houses. Not to mention, it was also a time of the Nazi’s rise to power. Nowadays, pretty small apartments and compact blocks are concealed by colored plaster, original door patterns, and manicured lawns. I’m sure that living in these houses may feel totally different from the careless meditation of a passerby. We are privileged to observe modernist estates from a distance of decades and draw our own conclusions.
This piece should have started with a bird’s-eye view of the horseshoe-shaped building, but let’s leave it to the birds. City explorers like you and me, not aided by drones or helicopters, see this site differently. When I came, the frost was gleaming on the grass in shadows, and the sun shone gently through a gap between “horseshoe” edges.
The Horseshoe Colony is a complex of townhouses and 3-story blocks of flats, and the central one — as you might have guessed — is curved like a horseshoe. A humble memorial stone at the pond tells this estate was designed by Bruno Taut and built between 1925 and 1933.
I was lucky enough to visit the Horseshoe Colony twice, at dawn and dusk, although it took me an hour to reach Britz, a part of the Neukölln district. As I left the metro, sunlit rosy-and-tartare houses with fiery doors popped up. At first, I was walking past them pretty fast, not realizing they were also part of the architectural ensemble — not just the shaped block.
I didn’t expect such a burst of color either because the whole modernist architecture (and Bauhaus in particular) had always seemed minimalistic and monochrome to me before.
Although this estate appeared as affordable housing for rapidly growing Berlin, it was designed with privacy in mind, thus feeling neither fully urban nor entirely rural. In this densely populated area, you’ll notice a lot of hedged yards with lovely arbors, swings, braziers, beds of flowers, and other attributes of carefree leisure.
The Horseshoe Colony doesn’t look luxurious; however, it gives space for individuality and embodies a passion for detail. I spotted a dozen door variations. My favorite ones are the black-framed ones with colorful rectangles in the middle. You can hardly find the same building color and door pattern combination twice.
But let’s turn back to the horseshoe building for a while. What amazed me the most about it was the optical effect of using sky-blue paint. Loggias look like holes in the building, and you can pretend to see the sky through them. As a result, this pretty massive building doesn’t feel overwhelming.
I noticed something about color that would also be relevant to other housing estates in this article. So, color is probably, the cheapest way to convey style, whereas columns or sculptures require a lot of work and material. It’s remarkable how modernists used the power of color, creating affordable yet original housing.
And the icing on the cake — a crimson wall, which turned out to be just the opposite side of those tartare houses I mentioned at the beginning. The setting sun cast its light on the wall, and the windows and balcony frames got lilac. After all this, I did realize why this settlement gained its status as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
I left the Horseshoe Colony after sunset. Black silhouettes emerged from the gloom but didn’t obstruct the sky view. If you stand on the stairs between the horseshoe edges, you’ll see magnificent scenery — the sun sets behind the building, people switch on the lamps, and this light reflects on the surface of the inner pond.
You can easily spot the White City from afar. Its white minimalist geometry stands out among yellowish houses nearby, and the five-story corner towers, like guardians, stand on both sides of the street, Aroser Allee. This housing estate in the district of Reinickendorf was built in 1928–1931 and turned out to be the last modernist quarter of the Weimar era.
The key role in the White City design belongs to Otto Rudolf Salvisberg. The central structure of this ensemble is like a sea resort hotel hovering above the street. I hate when parked cars spoil the picture, so I squatted in the middle of the boulevard and shot through a hole in the hedge, thus “hiding” the vehicles behind the bushes.
And how can an authentic German building be without a clock on its top?
Look! Another clock on the opposite side of the same building. I adore how classical modernist architects could create a style with the simplest geometric shapes: squares, circles, and rectangles. Although all the buildings generally look uniform, they have numerous unique parts — like these clocks.
Now, the doors. Doors are where modernist architects burst into various color combinations and rectangle compositions. Bright red and blue doors look incredibly vivid on the white facades.
Not to mention gorgeous blue windows along the staircase, an eye-catching stripe of volume on a flat facade.
A couple of paragraphs above, I mentioned so-called “towers,” higher parts of the corner buildings. So, I found five of them: two large towers on both sides of Aroser Allee and three narrow ones at the corner of Emmentaler Straße and Genfer Straße. They create a distinctive border with other buildings and hold the borders of this settlement.
I had visited the White City before chestnuts and poplars started blooming and one more time after trees went green. In spring, there is a short period when the sun is bright enough to make the walls sparkle, but the trees, still leafless, don’t obstruct the view. I was happy to enjoy this contrast between glaring facades and black trunks.
My final unexpected observation was red and blue bands underneath the roofs. On the one side of the street — blue; on the other side — red. Pre-war architects used to leave numerous unobvious details, aesthetic gifts for an attentive urban wanderer. By the way, White City also is UNESCO-protected and part of the Berlin modernism heritage.
Call me old-fashioned, but the number of floors in a residential building should be a one-digit number. For example, five. It seems compact enough and doesn’t turn a house into an ugly “anthill” similar to Soviet-time quarters in East Berlin. I decided to check the Carl Legien Settlement late in the evening, just before sunset.
This housing estate is located a 5-minute walk from the station Prenzlauer Berg in a district of the same name. Like many buildings displayed in this article, it appeared between 1928 and 1930 and was designed by Bruno Taut and Franz Hillinger.
Carl Legien estate is more uniform than, for instance, Horseshoe Colony, but belongs to UNESCO World Heritage, too. Its buildings don’t have varying characteristics like doors or facade colors. What fascinated me the most was the pinkish tint of the walls and, of course, red, yellow, and blue frames. Gazing at them, I immediately recalled paintings by Piet Mondrian.
And again, we observe the same simplicity and minimal expressive means — no columns, no sculptures, no molding. Rounded balconies and loggias are all facing the inner yard, and I guess it must create a feeling of privacy and own space for the dwellers.
Not many buildings in Berlin have bare brick facades. Brick is typical for factories and warehouses, but most residential estates are plastered and painted in pastel colors. However, the UNESCO World Heritage complex at Shiller Park stands out; the exposed concrete grid of balconies and ochre walls immediately drew my attention. It was designed by our good old friend Bruno Taut and constructed in 1924–1930.
I noticed a bright green car on the street between the historic houses and decided to look closer. Like the settlement itself, the car turned out to be also vintage. Citroën 2CV was a popular economy vehicle in the 1950s, and it fitted in here so well. The phrase on the car, “I fly bleifrei,” is a pun. In German, “bleifrei” means “lead-free” or “unleaded” (without added tetraethyl lead), which is a characteristic of petrol or paint. This motto and a cute duck mascot made me smile.
I noticed the streets where this estate stood were named after English cities — Bristolstraße, Dubliner Straße, Oxforer Straße, and Windsorer Straße. Later I understood why — in Google Maps, this area was called the English Quarter. Except for the car and street names, there were some other beautiful details, like a white doily in one of the windows.
The way how I instantly spot historically significant buildings in Berlin is by well-preserved wooden doors and windows. Look at these bold red frames. If the door is original, not a later replacement, the paint must have been scratched off and carefully repainted a dozen times. Paint sagging and overshooting on the glass look so heartwarming and naive when you can visualize the story behind it.
At the end of that walk, I was thinking about the balconies, which were half-glazed and half-opened. Large windows with white “skeletons” created the impression of porches. Maybe this is why so many local dwellers have beds of flowers, sun umbrellas, and chairs on their balconies. It’s a blessing when your home has a special place to meditate, sipping coffee to the sounds of birds’ songs.
It’s getting more challenging to impress you with Berlin modernism, but I’ll try. The ace up my sleeve is this lovely settlement on the southeastern outskirts of Berlin. It was built a bit earlier than most estates introduced here, in 1913–1916, and the design belongs to — surprise! — Bruno Taut.
While walking and taking pictures, I felt uncomfortable — like an obnoxious intruder or a guy chewing popcorn and slurping beer at the museum. Fortunately, there is little chance you disturb someone at 6 a.m. on Saturday because people (except for me though) prefer to bask in bed a bit longer. But my weird pleasure is to stay one-on-one with architecture and avoid city dwellers casting suspicious glances at me.
This settlement is probably the richest in styles and colors and feels specially designed for vacationing. Not surprisingly, it’s called “Gartenstadt” (garden city) in German and belongs to UNESCO World Heritage.
All the buildings have two or three floors, bright wooden shutters, and terraces. Even though most houses are arranged in blocks, they don’t feel like dull clones.
On some doors, I saw eye-shaped stickers with a silhouette of a thief and a phrase in German, “Neighbours are watching.” I don’t know about you, folks, but to me, this is a typical village security system when people notice more than any video surveillance from highly urbanized districts.
So far, the “garden city” was primarily painted in warm colors: orange, red, and yellow; however, it has a winter-cold section, too. If I happened to choose my favorite building here, I’d choose this stunning blue villa. The tree, in the shade of which it stands, seems to be at least a century old, planted at the times of settlement construction.
Sorry, I cannot overcome a desire to show you the lovely doors of Falkenberg once again in detail. See how carefully a trellis (this white frame for supporting climbing plants) is covered with a sheet of glass. Residents’ needs might have changed over time, but they didn’t spoil the initial design with a massive overhang. And the red door below, besides being amazingly beautiful, has a sticker I’ve already told you about.
Did you think there was just one blue house in the garden city of Falkenberg? Here is another one. You can compare how differently the same tone looks in the sun and after the sunset. In the light, it is glossy, and in the gloom, it gets matte and soft like a gouache drawing.
It was pretty late when I headed back to the station, yet I couldn’t miss an opportunity to take one more picture. What a combination of a cold-blue sky and pavement and orange-warm lights and a bush.
I’m not overwhelming you with historical facts from Wikipedia, so you should have some energy left to cope with the last chapter. This so-called “Waldsiedlung” (forest settlement) is located in one of the most picturesque districts of Berlin, Zehlendorf. You cannot take a single photo here without capturing at least one pine.
All the previous modernist settlements were located 5–10 minutes from the nearest train stations, but this one surrounds the station with an unusual name, “Uncle Tom’s Hut.” These beautiful 2–3-story blocks of flats and townhouses were finished between 1926 and 1931. Could it happen without Bruno Taut? Of course, no, folks. And Taut was accompanied by fellow architects Hugo Häring and Otto Rudolf Salvisber, whom I mentioned many times in this and previous articles.
Onkel Toms Hütte, unfortunately, hasn’t been (yet?) honored with the status of UNESCO World Heritage and remains the only settlement in this article without this status. However, it doesn’t mean city authorities neglect its preservation. All the buildings look well-maintained and don’t have noticeable stains on their bright facades.
In childhood, my granny dressed me in not-so-new grey and brown stuff because she knew I’d be dirty by the end of the day. A residential building is something people “use” very often, and why the hell do you make it so bright? I admire the courage of architects who cared about the dwellers’ moods, too. It is much more pleasant to live in a place that also pleases your eyes than just a practical and robust apartment!
My poor German skills, though, were sufficient to interpret gorgeous letters on the building below. It must have been a hairdresser’s workplace, but now it looks unoccupied by any business.
The shadows were growing higher and getting longer. Time to return home and view all the photos taken that day…

This year, I was able to finally cross off a major dream of mine: visiting Europe for the first time! It was a dream come true to visit Germany and Italy, but Berlin in particular caught my attention in unexpected ways. I had the chance to stay with a close friend in Wilmersdorf, a neighborhood that offered me a fresh outlook on living in Berlin away from the tourist attractions. I spent 12 days learning about the city’s interesting history, lively markets, thriving food culture, and quirky retail spots from my travel companion and the kind Berliners I met along the way.
I was so affected by this experience that I was motivated to write this guide. In order for anyone considering a trip to Berlin to experience the history, culture, and distinct charm of this incredible city as I did.
Since the tours, I’ve realized that the reason Germans sometimes come out as aloof or uncaring might be directly related to their past. Deep wounds from World War II’s loss and the terror of Nazi Germany persist to this day. Through memorials, museums, and the Stolpersteine — brass “stumbling stones” commemorating Holocaust victims — Germany confronts its past head-on, admitting its collective guilt. It’s simple to see how this emotional burden, which hasn’t been resolved, might be inherited and cause a reserved, occasionally disconnected mannerism.
Berlin is well-known for its lively flea markets, each of which offers a distinctive blend of local culture, art, antiques, and vintage finds. These are a few of the more well-known ones:
Kreuzberg’s Markthalle Neun transforms into a street food paradise on Thursday nights that you won’t want to miss. I had the opportunity to try a variety of international cuisines while exploring the ancient hall, including fresh oysters, Venezuelan arepas, and Korean dumplings. It was more than just cuisine because of the vibrant ambiance, which was full of wonderful scents and welcoming sellers. It’s a must-see if you’re in Berlin on a Thursday!
I got the opportunity to go to Hosek Contemporary, a unique art and music venue situated on a Spree River boat. It was a bizarre experience to listen to experimental music there; the live sound, artwork, and soft boat swaying created a unique experience. This location is a must-see in Berlin’s art scene if you’re looking for something immersive and different.
For those interested in avant-garde music culture, other venues such as Sophiensaele, Quiet Cue, Radialsystem V, and Berghain are also worth seeing.
Restaurants
Coffee & Dessert
This guide to my favorite Berlin spots is my debut travel article — I hope it helps you plan an amazing trip! Follow or comment for more travel guides!

Title: Ruins and Resistance: Life Inside Berlin’s Past
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
1
Share
A city is nothing without its people. Yet a city is also a silent witness to the past. Walk any berlin street, day or night, and you feel the past. If you can see marks of the past in the cobblestones, then you can surely feel it in your bones.
I look for clues of the past in Berlin’s architecture. I’m always walking, looking upwards, often too much; Car horns warn me to watch where I walk.
Architecture shows us the present and the past. Tall columns that reach up high enough to make your neck ache. Designs that mix up a little of the Romans with the Greeks, Doric, ionic, Corinthian, Tuscan and Composite.
Northern European architecture favours smallness. Not tall columns reaching towards the heavens, but squat doorways, tiny windows that protect dwellers from winter weather. Country homes that are functional, workshops only big enough to roll a wooden cart into then load up with goods. That’s my imagination. Walking on Berlin cobblestones fires up the heart.

One day I found myself on a flight to Berlin, Germany. Berlin didn’t even rank within the top ten places to visit on my list but I had to go for work, so why not enjoy this obligatory adventure? I had heard that Berlin was moody and grungy, like the emo child of Europe except it’s not “just a phase”. I was prepared to be met with a lot of punk rock and broody, techno vibes but (as is custom when traveling) I discovered the unexpected.
I landed in the mid evening in Berlin and my colleagues and I were starving and excited to sample Berlin cuisine. Three of us were American and were humbly disappointed that many restaurants nearby were already closed — how inconvenient! It’s usually good to be humbled like this as an American abroad, it definitely enriches one’s character. We did manage to find — what else —but a McDonalds. At this moment, I was less than dazzled by Berlin’s seemingly inaccessible evening meal options but figured it could only get better from here.
In the days that followed, I found Berlin to be a fascinating albeit (at times) icy, bustling city of natives, expats and tourists with cool modern buildings and large boulevards. While the overtone of German austerity, order and efficiency was undeniable, there were surprising pockets of whimsy mixed in here and there.
My personal favorite site was the Brandenburg Gate. A stunning piece of architecture with a lot of history and easily one of the most recognizable landmarks of Berlin.
I also visited Checkpoint Charlie, which was historically the Berlin Wall crossing point. This was a quirky museum overflowing with objects large and small, significant to a major turning point in German history. Not too far from the Brandenburg Gate was the beautiful, lush state park called the Tiergarten. Dense with trees, I would describe the Tiergarten as “Central Park with European elegance” — definitely another favorite location.
While Berlin certainly had highlights of grunge, some parts were charming and even rather quirky with fun thrift stores, local farmer’s markets and the unexpected hipster-style cafe.
Before traveling to Berlin, I was looking forward to sampling famous local fare (currywurst and sauerkraut of course) but Berlin also had much to offer in terms of international cuisine, with a lot of Turkish influences. I made it a priority to sample at least one döner kebab (something I would describe as a cross between shawarma and a sub sandwich) and it did not disappoint. To date, one of the best breakfasts of my life (avocado toast, covered in sautéed mushrooms over thick, fresh bread) was at a highly aesthetic cafe called Kaffee Karamell Berlin. And when I finally got my fork into some local sauerkraut, I knew that I was ruined for any canned, store-bought variety…forever. At the end of my trip I discovered that Berlin was certainly more complex than I had originally imagined. Quirky, grungy, cool, refined, steeped in history yet unapologetically modern, a bit edgy with it’s soft sides as well. Snag your ticket to Berlin and see for yourself!

It’s been 5 months since we moved to Berlin; I’m still astonished we pulled it off as a family. Here are some things we did and learned along the way:
That’s it. I don’t mean to sound cheeky but it’s actually completely doable and only seems daunting in principle. Once you’re executing, you’re operating a checklist, it becomes all about unwavering project management. The biggest deal breaker for us was the school and it worked out rather well.

Title: Berlin — one of Europe’s most vibrant urban centres
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Looking to visit somewhere new on your next trip to Germany? Check out our city and regional profiles. Whether you prefer tucking into Currywurst in Berlin, or dancing in a carnival parade in Düsseldorf, you’re bound to find something for you.

--
Listen
Share
Steeped in history, Berlin has been the capital city of the united Federal Republic of Germany since 1990. In that time, it has become one of the hippest and most vibrant urban centres in Europe — with a flourishing cultural scene, brilliant nightlife, and a plethora of bars, restaurants, shops and cafés, as well as green open spaces. Read on for a few insider tips on what to explore off the beaten track.
The loop route along the boundaries of former West-Berlin is also known as the Berlin Wall Trail (Mauerweg). The approximately 160 km (100 miles) loop road is accessible by bike, skates or on foot. The trail follows the former border that ran through and around West Berlin. It turned those parts of the city into an island surrounded by the former East Germany from 1961 until 1989.
Everyone is invited to enjoy all the sights along the road from forests, rivers and parks at the “outer parts” of the trail, as well as architecture and lively city atmosphere at the inner parts of the loop. Along the route there are information stands about historic events in the time of the Cold War and successful escapes. Fears as well as hopes of those fleeing former East Germany are described. But it also depicts personal stories and notes about the dead of the wall (known as Mauertote).
The Berlin Wall Trail combines history and being active in a very distinctive way. At the same time you can see how nature took back areas which used to be known as “death strips”, where people in East Berlin were prohibited to go.
Click here for more information on the Berlin Wall Trail
Berlin’s Wall Park (Mauerpark) that used to be a border strip, is the perfect place to go on a sunny Sunday afternoon. Check out the huge weekly flea market, which sells almost anything you can imagine, from vintage handbags to Soviet helmets. If you’re feeling particularly brave, you can also try out a Berlin tradition — outdoor karaoke! Organised by locals, Bear Pit Karaoke lets anyone turn up and have a go at serenading those relaxing in the park with their favourite song. Don’t be put off by the intimidating name, however — almost every singer, no matter how horrendous, is guaranteed a round of applause.
Click here for more information on the Wall Park
Formed of sections from the former Berlin Wall, the East Side Gallery is a permanent installation showcasing some spectacular examples of street art.
Click here for more information on East Side Gallery
Tiergarten is the second biggest public park in Berlin and is located right in the city centre. Within walking distance to other famous Berlin sights like the Brandenburg Gate, the Victory Column or the Reichstag, home of the German Bundestag, the park is a refuge from the loud and busy city life. Tiergarten used to be the royal hunting ground in the 16th century. Nowadays you can walk among mature trees, classic sculptures, ponds and breathe fresh air in an area much more similar to a forest due to its massive size and bunch of trees.
Click here for more information on Tiergarten
Only a few years ago Tempelhofer Feld was an airfield. Used by the American Allies as an airport and army base until the 1990’s, Tempelhofer Feld is today the biggest park of the German capital. Since 2008 it has been used as a public park, where everyone is invited to spend their free time. Whether it is by bike, on roller skates or even flex-wing, you can get active in the designated areas. But you can also take your barbecue and have a nice BBQ with your loved ones around or meet people from all over the world. Note: there are almost no trees, because the aim to preserve the impression of an airfield does not allow the plantation of trees.
Click here for more information on Tempelhofer Feld
A former Cold War listening post, the spectacular Teufelsberg complex looks like something out of a science fiction movie, perched on an artificial mountain to the west of the city. Abandoned for almost twenty years, the site has since been reinvented as a creative space by Berlin artists and musicians. Whilst off-limits to the public due to the somewhat dilapidated state of some of its buildings, the Teufelsberg is open for official tours.
Click here for more information on Teufelsberg
A striking courtyard complex made up of restaurants, shops, bars, cinemas, theatres and galleries, Hackesche Höfe is one of Berlin’s hidden gems. The striking Jugendstil (Art Nouveau) architecture makes for a gorgeous backdrop for a cocktail outside on a balmy evening. If the weather’s a little inclement, take in a film or a cabaret show.
Click here for more information
Berlin’s Kreuzberg district is home to many people of Turkish heritage, so it’s no surprise that the riverside Turkish Market, which runs twice a week all year round, has so much on offer. Here you can find a wide range of delicious Turkish food and drink. It’s a particularly good place for fresh fruit and vegetables — go along to the very end to get the best deals.
Click here for more information
Town twinnings between British and German cities play an important role in promoting cultural exchange. Berlin has been twinned with London since 2000.

Title: Week 1: Berlin
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Traveling from Europe to Asia. Will he make it? Find out next week.

--
2
Listen
Share
Everyone I know who visited Berlin came back saying the same thing:
“Berlin is a magical city.”
They weren’t lying. It’s hard to capture the essence of this place with just a few words, but there’s something really special happening here. Every block is teeming with energy and creativity. Walls are plastered with interesting graffiti and residential balconies are bursting with floral arrangements. Sidewalks are wide enough to accommodate outdoor seating for cafes and restaurants, pedestrians, and bikes all at once, and the streets are bustling with people at all hours.
The cultural atmosphere feels leisurely and less profit-driven, and people seem to be actively enjoying living and working in their city. There’s a sense of civic harmony here I haven’t experienced anywhere else. Most importantly, beer is suuuper cheap, sometimes cheaper than bottled water. It’s also legal to drink in public which makes it tempting to buy a drink for the road (any road). I was afraid I’d bankrupt myself on booze if I stayed any longer.
My German experience began before my plane touched down. The stewardesses on my flight were dressed like beer maidens and handing out free schnitzel and brews for Oktoberfest. A yodeling contest was held at the front of the plane moments later. I arrived in Berlin around 10pm and took a train to my hostel.
I spent the first half of the week touring the city together with some floor-mates from the U.K. We wandered Berlin’s deceptively large streets and hopping on and off public transportation (which had a pretty high learning curve) to visit public squares, churches, and landmarks. Luckily for me, my hostel-mates had a local friend who showed us some fantastic spots, like a rooftop bar called the Klunker Kranich that sat atop a seven-story parking structure and overlooked the city. The most memorable was a mind-blowing place night club called Sisyphos. Here’s my journal entry if you’ve got some time to kill.
On the days I wandered by myself, I joined random walking tours, ate at an African food collective that helped re-integrate refugees into Germany, and went to a bar where all the furniture was upside-down and attached to the ceiling. I visited the Holocaust Memorial at sundown and walked in silence between the large concrete blocks, thinking about the United States and the path we’re headed towards if we don’t remain proactive and vigilant of our bubbling fascism.
I walked around Templehoff Regional Park, an abandoned airfield with old hangars and dilapidated planes. It was a bit surreal seeing kids riding bikes and flying kites on airstrips where bombers used to take off. I strolled through Tiergarten, Berlin’s central park, on my last day. It was raining on and off, but when the sun finally came through, the trees shimmered like verdant jewels.
On my last night, I met up with five other travelers through the Couchsurfing app and we drank late into the morning, (which made for a very rough trek to the bus station a few hours later).
One week doesn’t feel like enough time to do Berlin justice, but I guess that gives me a reason to come back. I’ve got the rest of the world ahead of me and it felt like the right time to get going. I still feel a bit timid whenever I enter a new hostel or restaurant, especially when I can’t speak the language, but I’m slowing getting more comfortable with the discomfort. Getting by in a multi-cultural city like Berlin wasn’t too difficult, but I know the language barrier will only become more challenging as I travel east. At least I’ve got time to ease myself into it. My phone has been an invaluable companion, allowing me to book tickets and hostels in the same sitting and save maps for offline use. I purchased my first international SIM card today, but all of the instructions are in German. So I’ll have to figure that out at some point.
I’m writing you from a hostel in Dresden now, where I’ll be staying for at least the next few days. I’m waking up early tomorrow to visit one of Germany’s national parks. I’ve been craving some nature after being immersed in such rich urban environments for the past few days.
Thanks for taking the time to read this. I’ll be trying to post weekly, so shoot me a message if there’s something in these you’d like to hear/see more or less of in the future. Any feedback is deeply appreciated.
Until next time!
