Title: Welcome to Cyber Berlin
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

The future is already here — it’s just not very evenly distributed. Stories about cyberpunk becoming our modern reality.

--
Listen
Share
I travel the world exploring high tech low life places. Most of these places are in Asia, but what about Europe? Wikipedia Cyberpunk page mentioned Sony Center in Berlin as an example of cyberpunk-influenced cityscape. Modern incarnations of cyberpunk are exact focus of this blog, so we’re going to Germany!
First place we’ll visit is Potsdamer Platz in Berlin’s central borough called Mitte.
This place is awesome and looks more like Manhattan than a German city.
Being a kid in late 90s I loved a TV show called “Total Recall 2070”. It was loosely based on Philip K. Dick works. Plots of most episodes are quite cheesy, but its futuristic atmosphere was so damn dark and sinister! And you know what? Potsdamer Platz looks and feels exactly like Total Recall 2070.
As I know, no cyberpunk books or movies are based in Berlin, but they definitely should!
Berlin is worth visiting just for Potsdamer Platz, but let’s proceed to the Sony Center, which is nearby.
It is easy to approach Sony Center from Potsdamer Platz, just go where all the neon lights are.
This area consists mostly of shopping malls, offices, restaurants. But who cares? For me it looks exactly like William Gibson’s 80s vision of the future.
Large shining dome reminds me of Highlander 2 movie. By the way, the movie was very much high tech and low life.
Offices on the sides of Sony Center looks super futuristic even without glowing neon lights.
The area of Sony Center and nearby office buildings is quite crowded and noisy. Walk couple of minutes westward and suddenly the streets become empty.
Approaching Tiergarten, Berlin’s central park. It is completely empty at 8pm.
Going to Unter den Linden street, which passes Mitte horizontally. Westernmost part of the street is a place of famous Brandenburg Gate and different government building.
But let’s go east, where Berlin looks more hi tech and noire.
Probably low life is not what you’ll find here, but central Berlin still has its dark vibe at night with techno clubs and dark cold streets.
Mitte reminds me both Manhattan and Moscow, but feels darker than each of them.
Speaking of Moscow, we’re approaching Alexanderplatz which looks a lot like large soviet city, rather than Western Europe.
Which is quite obvious, since this district was a part of Eastern Germany.
When it is foggy, Alexanderplatz feels like a vampire movie.
Visiting Berlin is definitely a good idea for dark future fans. Other districts look less dark, but still interesting to explore. Berlin is easy to reach via major airlines (sometimes with connection in Frankfurt or Munich) and its relatively cheap, comparing to other Western Europe capital cities.

--
The future is already here — it’s just not very evenly distributed. Stories about cyberpunk becoming our modern reality.

Title: Saved by the Book: How I Warmed up to Berlin (Part One)
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Features Supplement to the Online Journal of Literature and Art

--
Listen
Share
My first days in Berlin were terrible. The apartment I agreed to rent based only on photographs was too cold: Spartan in its hyper-masculine functionality. It would not warm up. It also became clear that I could not get by on English alone despite Berlin’s reputation as a cosmopolitan hub. I bought cream cheese when I wanted yoghurt, and had to use sign language in the grocery store, bakery, and flower shop. Buying tickets for the subway was not easy either. I walked around in an alienating landscape in which most of the signage was incomprehensible, newspapers made no sense, and I required GoogleTranslate to use the washing machine. It was unsettling to be able to discern the letters, but not the words. I realized that German acquisition, even basic German, was necessary if I wanted to interact with people outside the Anglophone expat cocoon, and if I wanted a more meaningful connection to my new home.
Fortunately, I am good with languages. That talent paired with a six-week language course and being unabashed about speaking terrible German has made a difference. Now I can talk to the butcher, the baker, and the Siemens washer. The other thing that has made a difference is my decision to get to know this city through its bookstores. I resolved to visit a different bookstore each weekend, and from there to launch my explorations of the neighborhood in which the store stood. This would get me out of my (cold) apartment, and into Germany’s capital, get me walking, looking at buildings, and discovering food, shops, and public spaces.
How happy I am with my choice, because Berlin is thick with bookstores. I won’t bore you with statistics, just my anecdotal experience coming from New York via Los Angeles. Brentwood, my old neighborhood in La-La Land, is thick with movie stars, and nail salons. There’s no lack of storefronts offering manicures and pedicures and juice cleanses, but there was not a single bookstore within walking distance (or even easy driving distance) of my apartment on Sunset Boulevard. Contrast that with at least ten bookstores within a ten minute walk of my current apartment in Berlin’s Prenzlauer Berg, and several just steps away. Even Morningside Heights, my Manhattan neighborhood, can boast of only Book Culture (formerly Labyrinth Books), the wonderful, intellectual heavyweight on 113th Street, and its sister store on Broadway and 116th Street, across from Columbia University’s gates.
But it’s not only Berlin’s high per capita of bookshops that I wish to extol, it is also their variety, specificity, and idiosyncrasy. You find the usual suspects of course, like bookshops devoted to children’s books or used books or art books, but I have also found bookshops aimed at naturalists; crime fiction aficionados; cookbook enthusiasts; travel nuts; theater buffs; sci-fi fiends; visual design freaks; and expat Anglos. There are so many others still waiting to be discovered. Let’s take a short walk from the Wasserturm,
the 19th century brick water tower that anchors my part of Prenzlauer Berg, to see what I mean.
Walking north on pretty, cobblestoned Ryke Straße, past the synagogue and its security detail, will take us to the intersection with Wörther Straße. A right on Wörther leads to St. George’s Bookshop, a purveyor of second-hand English books since 2003, and a left finds us in front of Georg Büchner Buchladen and its enticing window display. From Wörther Straße, walk north on Kollwitz Straße and its popular cafes and restaurants and cross Danziger to Senefelder; continue north until you get to the intersection of Senefelder and Raumer Straße and Buch Reigen. Their beautiful children’s books (yes, in German) have been tempting me since I moved into the quarter. Then walk west on Raumer to Helmholtzplatz, a lovely square where, on Sundays, neighborhood folks sell clothes, books, and toys. Then a quick right on Duncker Straße and a left on Letter Straße, following the tree-lined square, until you reach Buchbox! and its outdoor racks with postcards and wooden toys. From there, take Lychener Straße north and turn left on Stargarder Straße to find the Buchhandlung Moby Dick. If instead we had walked east and south from the Wasserturm we would encounter about one block east at the corner of Knaack Straße and Prenzlauer Allee the Mowgwa Antiquariat, a used bookstore with a small English section. Continuing south on Prenzlauer Allee and then going east on Heinrich Roller Straße takes us to the Einar and Bert Theaterbuchhandlung, a sweet corner where, on the right day, you can enjoy your tea and book in a sunny spot overlooking Leise Park.
Admittedly, Prenzlauer Berg, which was formerly in East Berlin, has changed dramatically since the fall of the Berlin wall in 1989: the once dilapidated apartment buildings are festooned with refurbished balconies and terracotta ornamentation, and their marble floors, tile work, and stained glass windows gleam. Coffee shops, yoga studios, organic food joints, and chic boutiques welcome both the local gentry and tourists.
Yet the bookstore is flourishing, when it has all but disappeared in comparable neighborhoods in American cities. In Berlin, the bookstore thrives even in less affluent and more demographically diverse neighborhoods. Two such are Kreuzberg and Neukölln, where a range of booksellers coexist with mosques, döner kebab shops, and Middle Eastern food marts.
What is it about this city? How do the book and the spaces in which it can be held, beheld, smelled, heard and, dare I say it, tasted, continue? Is it rent control? Is it state support? Is it Berlin’s vaunted independent artistic sensibility, emblematized by repeated references to body art and body piercings? Is it Berlin’s exceptional character, its special air, and its sexiness, as in Berlin ist arm, aber sexy? Translation: Berlin is poor but sexy.
Whatever it is, I have been seduced. I have fallen for this city’s intellect, its understated style — or is it studied shabbiness? — and the opportunities it presents to engage with the physicality of the book in a variety of spaces — sleekly modernist, cheerfully colorful, musty and cavelike, or hiply furnished in typical Berlin style with wooden pallets and mid-century modern. The sheer somatic pleasure of letting the eye wander, having it alight on a book, picking it up, feeling its heft, the pliability or resistance of its binding, turning its pages, noticing their typecasting, the sprawl of lines or their compact containment in stanzas, getting a waft of age or crisp newness, finding an inscription, a coffee smear, a tear, underlined text, or marginalia in a brisk hand.
I think it’s telling that the German word for bookstore is Buchhandlung, a compound of the words buch and handlung, the word retaining, unlike the English, the tactility of the operation, and the implication and involvement of the hand, and of the entire body in the act of engaging the book.
Editor’s Note: Tomorrow, we feature Subhashini Kaligotla’s interview with St George’s Bookshop bookstore owner Paul Gurner.
--
--
Features Supplement to the Online Journal of Literature and Art
A poet and architectural historian of medieval India, Subhashini lives and writes in Berlin. Her first book of poems is forthcoming in Fall 2017.

Share
But what exactly is Pictoplasma? Similar to the question posed in “The Matrix,” I found myself needing to discover the answer for myself. Let me explain: In 2004, I bought the first Pictoplasma character book in a bookstore in Switzerland and was completely captivated. I also visited their very informative website at the time and gathered that it was a meeting for character designers. Since that day, I wanted to attend Pictoplasma myself. However, it took me 20 years to finally make it. So in May 2024, I attended the conference in Berlin. On the first day, I felt a bit overwhelmed, not because of what was offered, but due to the organization. Everyone had to wait patiently until they could register. I felt a bit lost, but around 3:30 PM, things finally got started. I went to the registration and then directly to the first exhibitions by the artists who would be giving talks in the coming days. I saw some of the works and took them in. Then I wandered around the venue for a while.
The next day, the conference truly kicked off. According to the program, some highly renowned artists from the scene had gathered in Berlin. I attended talks by Joe Bennett, a young designer and animator from the USA. He recently made waves with his series “Scavenger Reign” on HBOMax, a sci-fi series that looks like it could have come from the mind of the artist Moebius. He has been working on this series for over seven years, and it will be available on Netflix in the coming months. His other works for Adult Swim and Fox also stand out, characterized by a quirky but endearing sense of humor.
Additionally, the artist duo “Los Calladitos” really impressed me. Their stunning murals depicting a fantastical world centered around the preservation of light captivated me. They work on their pieces with incredible care and creativity. They also showed some animations from their own film, which brought even more life to their characters and world. Unfortunately, I missed a talk by Peter The Roman, an artist known for experimenting with AI in his 3D worlds. However, I saw some of his works in the exhibitions spread across various locations in Berlin. Overall, 20 artists participated, giving talks and workshops.
But what sets Pictoplasma apart? It’s not merely a stage for artists; it’s also one of the largest communities in the realm of character art and animation. The “Artist Talks” provided profound insights into the world of artists: their methodologies, how they develop ideas and strategies, and how they publish, sell, and make a living from their art. It’s a platform for exchange and collaboration, bringing creatives from diverse backgrounds together. Moreover, the conference reflects the zeitgeist of 2024. In a world dominated by AI, Pictoplasma artists emphasize the importance of emotion and craftsmanship. It became evident that while AI is a valuable tool for ideation, the execution of most artists’ works remains in human hands. This realization, which I suspected before Pictoplasma, was confirmed and reinforced during the event. Indeed, the use of AI elevates the significance of handmade art. Consider, for instance, the wooden figures crafted by artist Parn “Ani” Aniwat, who carves more than 30 charming characters each month. Or reflect on Los Calladitos, who seamlessly transfer their unique style from the vast walls of their murals to their animated films. Even the ceramic lamps crafted by Portuguese artist and entrepreneur Ana Seixas demonstrate how handmade artworks garner special relevance and appreciation. Ultimately, one desires to touch the art that inundates our digital world.
All the days at Pictoplasma were incredibly lively and full of inspiration. One of the most interesting talks was by Philip Hunt, a creative director at AKA Studios from the UK. He shared his experiences and insights about design and art, particularly regarding the film industry and the challenges of adapting a children’s book like “Here We Are” by Oliver Jeffers into a film. He discussed the extensive thought and effort required to translate beautifully drawn 2D characters into a 3D medium. After many ideas and experiments, he and his team successfully turned the book into a beautiful film, which can be admired on Apple TV. By chance, I met Philip on Sunday, the last day of Pictoplasma, at a small flea market in Berlin. I approached him because I didn’t get the chance to talk to him at the event. We had a pleasant conversation about the industry, covering topics like advertising, films, and other media. He asked me how I found Pictoplasma, and I told him that initially, I didn’t know what to expect or what I would take away from it. He responded that each year, he takes away inspiration and a reminder of why he continues his work. He loves attending Pictoplasma, getting inspired by other artists, and gaining a perspective beyond commercial work. He also shared that he attended the first Pictoplasma 20 years ago and didn’t know what it was about back then either. Now, he teaches workshops and helps lead the Pictoplasma Academy. It was a very enjoyable conversation. So, what makes Pictoplasma so special? It’s the chance to see designers and artists doing something different from just working on commercial projects. This is something I can definitely take away from it. I was deeply moved by the following artist talks. One of them was by the artist Parn “Ani” Aniwat. Out of necessity, he began carving small figures out of wood. Now, he makes 30 pieces a month — small, cute characters that he sells to collectors and exhibitors. It has become his business. He gave us a glimpse into his workday, which runs from 9 to 5, after which he spends time with his family, sketches ideas, and watches Netflix. The same goes for the Portuguese artist and entrepreneur Ana Seixas. During the pandemic, she started working with pottery and created clay lamp characters that sold faster in her shop than she could make them.
Of course, even at a conference focused on hand-drawn, painted, or crafted characters, the topic of artificial intelligence can’t be avoided. Some artists use AI as a tool to support their ideas. However, despite the technology and digital capabilities that AI offers, traditional craftsmanship remains one of the most important aspects. While no one insists that art must be created by hand, most artists still find themselves holding a pencil or an Apple Pencil. One of the most memorable statements about AI came from Philip Hunt. A young designer from the audience asked him whether she should focus more on AI. He responded that she should focus on drawing, as AI will inevitably come. But drawing with a pencil would always convey ideas better (or something along those lines; I’m not certain of the exact wording). Another artist, possibly Christopher Rutledge, mentioned that AI is a useful tool but compared it to mastering image databases or programs like Photoshop or After Effects. Artists have shown that they engage with AI, but in the end, it’s their ideas and visions that they bring to life. For the past few months, I’ve felt that we are returning to an era of “handmade” artistry, especially in art, film, and design. With the overproduction of AI-generated images and texts, which now look and read quite well, the personal touch is often missing. A good example is animator Joe Taylor, who makes his style unmistakable with hand-drawn loops that resemble flat designs from claymation. He showcased a commercial clip for the ProCreate app, which he both drew and animated using their software.
Aside from the talks, there were workshops, exhibitions, and parties. Unfortunately, I couldn’t attend all the talks or everything that was offered. Given that Berlin is a very large city and the event organizers thought it would be a good idea to use various locations across the city, it wasn’t easy to be everywhere. There was also an AR scavenger hunt called Character Hunt, where participants had to travel around Berlin using the Adobe Aero app to view the characters. Great ideas, but too little time to experience everything. Attending Pictoplasma was a fascinating journey into the realm of art, characters, and animation. It was far more than I could have ever imagined back then. For me, it was a significant source of inspiration for my work as a designer. Here, I could discover new perspectives and gain a wealth of inspiration.
The most captivating talk was also the last one of Pictoplasma. It was by Mila Useche from Colombia. She is an artist and filmmaker who had a tough journey. She had to fight hard in the working world, including working for a game company where she worked up to 15 hours a day. She then became a freelancer, working for studios like Disney, Warner Brothers, Nickelodeon, and Netflix. She also worked on her own concepts and film ideas. One of these is currently being realized in a German-Colombian co-production.
Recently, there has been a crisis in many animation studios in the USA, with widespread layoffs and job cuts. Adding to this were the aftermath of the pandemic and the surge of companies eager to use AI. Mila needed to find a way out, so she began sharing her hand-drawn images on Instagram, reaching many people who celebrated her art. She now lives in Japan, where she produces her art and characters. That was Pictoplasma 2024. A few days in another world, a world full of inspiration, art, characters, and animated films. Just a different kind of matrix.
--

Title: 10 Challenges Americans Face Moving to Berlin
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
While moving to Berlin was a dream come true and I could go on about all of the things I love about this hedonistic city, it came with its share of adjustments.
Some were easier to acclimate to as I quickly picked up a new way of doing things. Other things I still struggle with, even after a year of living here.
But at the end of the day, it’s all a part of the adventure. Anyone who picks up their life and moves abroad naturally craves change, newness, and a lifestyle shift. However, despite all of the best intentions and a can-do attitude, some things take longer than others to get used to.
— Want to know the flip side? Check out 20 Things I Love About Living in Berlin — From an American Expat for all the magical and exciting things I love about life in Berlin. —
Over the past year, I’ve noted what I’ve found to be frustrating, confusing, or a royal pain in the ass. Keep reading to learn about the harder, more challenging things for Americans moving to Berlin.
Finding a place to live where you can register your address (or Anmeldung in German) is by far the most challenging experience internationals face early on when moving to Berlin. As one of the most populous cities in Europe with the best nightlife in the world, not to mention the culture, history, and booming startup scene, it’s no wonder people from all over the world flock to Berlin’s gates.
Rent prices have skyrocketed in cities across the world, and it’s no different in Berlin. While it’s more affordable than Paris, London, or Amsterdam, it’s not as cheap as it once was either.
For example, I live in Neukölln where rent used to be extremely low since it was once a risky neighborhood to live in. That is no longer the case. Today, Neukölln’s known for eclectic bars, hipster cafes, music venues, green spaces, and some of the best street food Berlin has to offer. No matter what district you wind up in, finding a suitable place to live can be tricky.
Here are some tips that may help your search:
Just remember, when it comes to finding a flat, it becomes a lot easier once you’ve arrived and have feet on the ground. So, if you’re dealing with the madness of finding a place, getting rejected, and losing sleep over securing a spot before you arrive — take a breath and know it will work out once you get here.
2. Germany’s Cash Culture
The phrase “cash is king” takes on a whole different meaning in Germany. Paying with cash is mandatory at many bars, restaurants, shops, and even doctor’s offices in Berlin. If your purchase is a small one, you almost always have to pay with cash. I once got yelled at by a bartender in Friedrichshain when I didn’t have the cash to pay my tab, muttering “In Germany, we use cash.”
This is not the case in the U.S. or any other country I’ve visited in Europe. As one of the most prosperous and wealthy countries in the E.U., it’s surprising that card payments are frequently not accepted. I’m used to it now and always have some amount of cash on me, but it took time before this felt normal.
3. The Bureaucracy
Similar to my previous point, Germany is still lagging in the digitalization department. All important documents are sent by post. Video calls and emails to get legitimate documents are nonexistent. You have to physically visit the administrative and governmental buildings for anything official.
As a result, the system is backed up and it often takes months before you can schedule an appointment with any official administration. While the system is slowly becoming digitalized, it’s a slow process that was exacerbated at the height of the pandemic.
For example, when you’re registering your address or interviewing for a resident permit, it may take months before you can schedule your appointment. The slots fill up so fast, and you have to wait patiently on your computer, hitting the refresh button repeatedly every morning to see if anything opens up. It’s a major headache, but eventually, you begrudgingly accept that that’s just the way it is. You have to play the game.
4. Everyday Items That Are Only Available at the Pharmacy
Buying rubbing alcohol, skin care, flu medicine, or melatonin can all be bought at any drug store in the States. In Berlin, you have to go to the pharmacy (or Apotheke) for all of these things. This can be frustrating when working around limited hours of operation and dealing with the anxiety about speaking German, or trying to, before asking if the pharmacist speaks English.
Luckily, there are apps, like MAYD, that you can use to order from the pharmacy online and avoid this process altogether if you plan ahead.
5. Hours of Operation Aren’t Always Reliable
You know when you need to visit a store after work so you look up the opening hours on Google beforehand to plan your day? You expect it to be open when you get there before closing time, right? Well, depending on the shop, that doesn’t always go as planned in Berlin.
If the shop is slow and nobody’s walked through the door for a while as the end of the day approaches, shops won’t hesitate to close earlier. This has happened to me on multiple occasions when visiting a copy shop, photo studio, butcher, or bakery. Similar to my point about the lag in digitalization, online hours of operation are more of a suggestion than a rule for many small businesses across Berlin.
6. Learning German is Challenging When Everyone Speaks English
Perhaps a blessing and a curse, most people speak English in Berlin. You can actually get away with never learning German and only speaking English if you really want to. Sure, this helps during the initial transition moving from the U.S. to Berlin. But now, after living here for over a year, the improvement in my German language skills hasn’t grown much.
Whenever I try to practice and communicate in German, most people usually recognize that it’s not my native tongue and switch to English. Yes, this is helpful at times, but all in all, you have to work harder to learn the language than you would have to in a smaller city in Germany.
7. Winter Nights Begin at 3:00 PM
Coming from Florida, a state known for its sunshine and tropical climate, getting used to the winter season was a major adjustment — especially during my first winter. After Daylight Saving Time, it gets dark by 4:30 PM and gradually increases to 3:00 by mid-December. The winters are long, cold, windy, and grey. As a result, seasonal depression affects many people and vitamin D deficiency can easily become a problem.
To combat the dreary winter season, consider investing in a sunlight lamp that emits artificial sunshine. I just got one and it’s already making a huge difference. Now that it’s my second winter here, I’m much more mentally prepared. I already know I’m going to be inside more often, and I try to use this time for working on my goals and projects — like practicing my German.
Thankfully, summers in Berlin are incredible and make the winter season worth waiting out. Just hang on until then and you’ll understand why people rough it through the winter.
8. Understanding the Metric System
If you grow up in the U.S., you use the Imperial System for measurements and the Fahrenheit scale for temperature. Except for a handful of other countries, that’s not the case for the rest of the world where the Metric Scale and Celsius degrees are standard.
I remember the first time I tried to bake a pumpkin pie around Thanksgiving because I was feeling homesick. It took forever as I converted quantities for every ingredient from my mom’s recipe while using a measuring cup with few details. Needless to say, my pie didn’t come out splendidly. It didn’t take long before I got proper measuring utensils that converted cups, ounces, and teaspoons to grams, liters, and milliliters.
It helped to change my phone settings to Celsius degrees early on. While I had to look up the Fahrenheit conversions for a long time, it started making sense after a couple of months. Figuring out the differences becomes second nature with time.
9. Grocery Shopping
Shopping at the grocery store can be a bit intimidating the first time in Germany for several reasons, particularly the lighting speed that cashiers scan your items at the check-out line.
The hardest thing for me was grocery shopping in general translating all the ingredients from German to English. I’d often wander around my local Rewe, Aldi, or Nahkauf for hours before finding everything I needed. In retrospect, it’s probably easier to shop online in the beginning.
On the bright side, it’s good practice to familiarize yourself with the German terms for garlic, cinnamon, vegetables, potatoes, and more early on if you plan on making this country home for a time.
10. Doing Laundry Using a Drying Rack
Flats in Berlin don’t come with dryer machines. Instead, you dry your laundry using a drying rack. I made a mess of things my first time or two hanging my clothes that left noticeable indents and wrinkles. Thankfully, my flatmate was able to correct my technique to avoid this problem in the future. It’s simple once you figure it out. That first time or two, though, was something new.
The other aspect is understanding the German settings on the washer machine. I used the scan image feature on my Google Translate app in the beginning. After that, I could figure out the setting by just going off the time limit, temperature, and spin speed.
Even typing this makes me feel extremely privileged to have always had a dryer. Nonetheless, nobody wants to ruin their clothes doing laundry, and this was still something I had to get used to during the first few weeks of life in another country.
I hope this provides some perspective for anyone searching for a realistic view of some difficulties you may encounter when moving to Berlin or another European country from the U.S.
In comparison, my list of “challenges” is much shorter than the list of things that I love about Berlin. Some of the adjustments, like not having air conditioning or learning your shoe size in European measurements, are so trivial in contrast to all of the experiences and growth I’ve enjoyed since moving abroad. If given the opportunity, I’d make the same decision to move abroad a hundred times over — no questions asked.

Title: Berlin Wall and Beyond: Discovering the Charm of Germany Over 120 Miles of Steps!
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
A couple of decades ago, what began as casual weekend hikes with friends — just a few hours in the mountains — slowly evolved into a deeper exploration of local and state parks. A curiosity for new adventures soon led to the discovery of National Parks across the country, and that passion expanded into international travels, exploring nature’s preserved wonders in parks around the world.
Along the way, it became clear that some of the most breathtaking and inaccessible parts of nature could only be reached through multi-day hiking and backpacking trips. These journeys, typically lasting 7 to 10 days, became a regular part of travel, often solo. Trips around the world were undertaken, each offering a unique experience and challenge. Over time, 20+ hikes were completed, each with its own set of lessons and rewards.
This growing love for exploration led to a shift in how trips were planned. Hiking and biking along coastlines, following rivers, and exploring port cities offered new perspectives. Night walks through urban landscapes provided a chance to see cities in a whole new light, often traversing them in unusual shapes like O, S, W, M, and X.
Last year, the focus turned to recent history, with travels through the Balkan countries. A deeper interest in historical trails soon emerged, culminating in the discovery of the Berlin Wall Trail — a 99-mile loop around Berlin. Fascinated by the trail’s historical significance and the surrounding landscapes, this became the perfect opportunity to explore the city and its neighboring regions in a way that blended history, culture, and nature.
During the visit, the energy in Berlin was undeniable, with a culture that’s constantly evolving yet still deeply rooted in its vibrant past. It’s a city that attracts tourists, but somehow still manages to feel like a place where locals truly live. Over the years, it’s become safer and more accessible, but what really stood out was how seamlessly everything is connected. The public transportation system made getting around a breeze, which only added to what made the experience so memorable. With the river winding through Berlin, it’s impossible not to feel the weight of over 30 years of division between East and West. That history is still very much present, and its echoes can be seen in so many corners of the city today. Walking along the carefully crafted Berlin Wall Trail gave me a deep sense of how far Berlin has come since reunification. The city feels like it’s truly found its stride — growing, changing, but always preserving the memories of its divided past.
Though initially set to walk the entire loop of the trail, after 4 days exploring its most iconic portions, it became clear the industrial sections could easily be skipped. This saved time was then reinvested in visiting nearby cities — Hamburg, Hannover, Bremen, and Celle — spending another 4 days soaking in Germany’s unique charm.
In this trip of 8 full days, an amazing 120 miles (190 kilometers) were walked, with hardly 10% of the routes repeated. Staying in city centers made it easy to take public transportation, using time effectively. The convenience of downtown hotels also made nighttime exploration effortless.
Hamburg stood out as a major port city, with its significant role in global trade. The city’s impressive post-WWII rebuilding efforts were evident, and the mix of modern, sleek architecture alongside remnants of historic buildings created a unique atmosphere, highlighting Hamburg’s resilience. A tour of the Airbus plant offered a fascinating behind-the-scenes look at aircraft production.
Hannover, though less touristy, had a quieter, almost deserted feel, which allowed for relaxed exploration and the opportunity to take day trips to nearby Bremen and Celle.
Bremen charmed with its well-preserved UNESCO sites, like the Town Hall and Roland Statue. The medieval architecture and cobblestone streets exuded timeless old-world charm.
Lastly, Celle felt like stepping into a fairytale, with its picturesque half-timbered houses. The historical center offered a perfect blend of history, culture, and cozy cafés, making it a delightful place to explore.
Overall, this format of exploring cities with rich history by foot was incredibly rewarding. It keeps the mind curious, constantly discovering new details, and made this trip unforgettable.
Closing Thought — Berlin Wall and Beyond
This journey through Germany, spanning over 120 miles of history-rich exploration, reaffirmed the joy of traveling on foot. From the Berlin Wall Trail to the charming streets of Hamburg, Hannover, Bremen, and Celle, this trip was an immersive blend of history, culture, and nature. Each city added its own flavor — Hamburg’s resilient port spirit, Bremen’s medieval UNESCO treasures, Hannover’s quiet allure, and Celle’s fairytale-like charm — together painting a vivid picture of Germany’s past and present.
The decision to walk through these cities wasn’t just about covering miles; it was about connecting with the soul of each place. The Berlin Wall Trail, with its emotional weight, felt like a journey through time. I could almost feel the ghosts of the Cold War as I walked along its path. Even in cities with less obvious history, like Hannover, the quiet streets told their own story.
Walking gave me the freedom to truly absorb the atmosphere — no rush, no rigid plans, just a deep dive into local life. The convenience of public transport in Germany allowed me to move seamlessly between iconic landmarks, neighborhoods, and hidden gems, maximizing every moment of daylight.
Ultimately, this trip reaffirmed that history is best experienced on foot. Each step taken brought a new perspective, whether it was a look at post-WWII reconstruction in Hamburg or a quiet afternoon in Celle’s picturesque town center. There’s something powerful about walking through a place, experiencing its rhythms, and understanding its past.
After 8 days and 120 miles, it’s clear that this way of exploring — slow, deliberate, and connected to the land — offers the richest insights. Germany’s history, from the Berlin Wall to its modern-day cities, is an open book, one that’s best read one step at a time.

Title: Berlin’s Best Workout Classes- The Lazy Girl Guide
Content:
Sign up

Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Note: Most of these are around Prenzlauer Berg/Mitte because I would be the last person to travel across the city for a workout.
I was born without a single athletic bone in my body, and I was okay with it until I moved to Germany. Why do Germans love Sport machen so much?! I began to feel the FOMO shortly after moving here. I tried going to the gym and also doing YouTube workouts- but turns out I am bad at consistency unless there is a later cancellation fee on the horizon. Luckily, the company I work at presented me with a discounted Urban Sports Club membership and so I was able to also mache Sport and discover my favourite studios/workout classes.
If you are a party person (I am not), you’ve definitely heard of Club Athleten’s CLUB BOXING classes. These are a mix of boxing and HIIT workouts, paired with a techno soundtrack and super groovy studios. But if you’re looking to build your booty, ASS ASS ASS is my favourite class at Club Athleten. They’ve got a bunch of workouts to choose from, and regardless of which on you choose, it’ll feel like a party!
If you’re on that clean girl or pilates girlie vibe, then a barre class is exactly what you need. Barre is mixture of pilates, yoga, ballet and strength training and will definitely leave the studio feeling the burn. Feel the Barre has some of the most attentive instructors who will make sure you’ve got the correct form. My favourite class is the BarreSIGNATURE- this gives you a taster of all of the classes they offer, that focus on different areas (core, strength, cardio, etc).
BEAT81 is another Berlin classic and I think it’s for the people that love an extreme workout (or maybe I am just that unfit). BEAT81 will push you to new lengths when it comes to cardio and strength training, as well as indoor cycling. What makes it more fun is the heartrate trackers you wear during the workouts, and you can track your progress on a screen. My favourite class at BEAT81 was the Strength class- which they describe as low on cardio but it still killed me (in the best way).
Despite having grown up in India, I was never someone who did yoga, except when I was forced to at school. However, because I grew up in India and have experienced real yoga, I am a snob when it comes to yoga instructors. To my delight, Yogic Escape offers that exact authentic Yoga experience. It is Indian owned, and all the instructors I’ve had so far have been great. I cannot recommend the Yoga for Beginners class enough. The class size is quite small so your form will be corrected and you will be pushed, but you will leave feeling lighter and stronger.
Yeah Studio offers a range of Pilates, Barre and Yoga classes, as well as teacher trainings. I love the Barre45 class by Tanja, and the Yobarre class too. Both classes use various props to elevate your workout and all the instructors are super motivating. There’s always a friendly community feeling as well.
Every week when I walk into Rocycle, I feel boujee and part of something exclusive- so you best believe I never skip a Rocycle class. Rocycle, on paper is a spin class but in reality is so much more. Not only does it incorporate some ab exercises and weights (all while on the bike), it is a great way to put away all your screens and forget about everything on the outside for 45 mins. A dark room, loud music, choreohraphy and a motivating instructor is really a great combination for a fun and effective workout.
Ride and Rocycle have the same concept and I would say they are equally good. The bonus with Ride is that you can book a class based on the type of music you like working out to. The closest studio to me is also smaller than the Rocycle one and it feels like the employees and regulars know each other well which is super cute.
Boaré is another one of my local studios that offers a variety of Pilates, Yoga, and Meditation classes. I enjoy their Pilates selection, as everyone class I have taken has left my legs SHAKING. I also tried a Sound Healing here and it left feeling ever so relaxed.
If the clean girl aesthetic was a studio, then this would be it. I have only taken classes at the Prenzlauer Berg studio, but all of their studios look equally beautiful. Hale.Now offers a range of Yoga, Pilates, Barre, Meditation and Sound Healing classes. I live for their Pilates Sculpt class (which literally books out instantly on Urban Sports). Their signature class is called Female Strength and it’s next on my list to try out.

Title: The Berlin Philharmonic Logo Is an Example of Design Excellence
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

A publication by and for marketers. We publish marketing inspiration, case studies, career advice, tutorials, industry news, and more.

--
3
Listen
Share
One of my favorite hobbies is collecting inspirations of art and design I come across while browsing the internet. Thanks to those new “save” features in apps like Pinterest or Instagram, I’m able to build little digital art museums for myself. I have thousands of “saved” pictures, from vintage photography to exotic art collage. One day I caught myself amused by the simple, elegant, extremely creative logo of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra.
Whatever your career is, imagine yourself designing an orchestra logotype. First, you’d take a look at previous creations: mostly elegant curve-shaped designs with ornamental details or typographies. In color patterns, you’d see a majority of red, black and white, sometimes blue or green.
Second, you’d might brainstorm general aspects of orchestras. I’ll help: Tradition. Old Style. Chic. Elegant. Perfection. Beauty. Cult. Deep emotions. Beethoven. The frequency of sound wave. Instruments. Symphonies. The treble clef. The air-drawn lines of a baton.
The ordinary “elegant curve-shaped designs” illustrates these round elements of an orchestra. Music is not “straight”. Emotions are not “straight”. What about the color pattern? They are clearly trying to call attention, communicate passion (red tones) in a classic and elegant way (black, white tones) with notes of respectfulness or loyalty (blue, green tones).
The access to a huge source of inspiration enables the creation of my little digital museums, but it also harms uniqueness. You can create something beautiful and well constructed, but it’s easy to fall into ordinary. You can find many “how-to-do-a-beautiful-orchestra-logo-in-10-steps”, but the real challenge is to be creative and unique and still carry the message you are trying to transmit.
Well, here is why the Berlin Philharmonic logotype owned it:
This overlapped series of pentagon forms (straight lines), instead of illustrating common aspects of an orchestra, communicates the masterful architectural work of Hans Scharoun (1832–1972) for the orchestra’s concert hall, previously all fan or shoebox shaped.
The chosen yellow, a color that’s uncommon for this market, grabs attention, transmits creativity, motivation, optimism, and warmth. That conveys the Berlin Philharmonic is a modern, vivid, joyful orchestra but also warm — musically and emotionally deep.
There is also an easter egg: The overlapped pentagons clearly but not perfectly represent the floor plan of the concert hall. These overlapped pentagons suggest, besides all, a circular movement:
Yes. Circular. Do I have to say more? The logotype merges, in an exquisite way, an architectural uniqueness that characterizes the Berlin Philharmonic, without forgetting the musicality, elegancy, and round elements that surrounds an orchestra. All of those represented, with not a single curve.
“Good design is obvious. Great design is transparent.”
— Joe Sparano

Title: proudA Conversation with deerBLN: Inking Love onto the Streets of Berlin
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
He’s a trained cabinet maker, a qualified social pedagogue, and a professional graphic designer and illustrator. Christian Rothenhagen, also known as deerBLN, is a Berlin patriot with a conceptual flair. proud magazine sits down with the artist to discuss his love for the city, his creative ambitions, and what it means to be a true Berliner.
proud: What is your ambition behind putting tiles on the city’s streets?
deerBLN: My ambition is clearly to beautify my city and to express myself: in drawings, on t-shirts, on skateboards, in installations, wherever. I am happy to live in the most beautiful city in the world. I see myself as a modern local historian. I document the city through my drawings and give something back to it through my work in public spaces. My “street art” is, for the most part, not illegal, but rather tolerated interventions in the urban landscape. It’s an expression of my love for this city.
proud: You are a true Berliner. Do you even like the city anymore these days?
deerBLN: I have lived here since 1976. For me, the city is still the most beautiful, the roughest, the most diverse, the most interesting, the most incorruptible, the most broken — and the most honest. It’s the city that doesn’t lie to you. It wears its scars openly, shows its wounds, and is as direct as a punch in the gut. But it’s also the city that will always catch you. I love Berlin — now more than ever!
proud: You just designed a skateboard series for Artsprojekt. Are you a skater?
deerBLN: I used to skate a lot, but I wasn’t particularly good. I started in the mid-80s on one of those plastic boards from the department store. When I was 15, I bought my first real board, a Santa Cruz with Independent trucks and OJ II wheels — a classic! That board was my pride and joy and my ticket to a world that has shaped me to this day: skateboarding, punk rock, and hardcore. The DIY ethic of that scene has influenced my work from the beginning. So, to design a board series now is a huge honor for me. It’s a childhood dream come true.
proud: What are you currently working on?
deerBLN: Right now, I’m developing a T-shirt series for a Berlin-based streetwear label and working on a few poster designs. I’m also preparing my next solo exhibition, which will take place in the spring of 2009 in Friedrichshain. Besides that, I’m always drawing… my city… Berlin!

Title: Walk around Berlin through the Big Screen
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
There are thousands of films shot in Berlin (click for city map). Opposite to many other shooting locations, Berlin surpasses the mere location tag. Instead, the city is a breathing creature, making it a character on its own.
It holds true not only in movies, though. When visiting Berlin, I felt like walking through Berlin is to walk through human memory, through disaster and overcoming. It was a walk through the urban movements seemingly never stopping to run its streets, breathe from its walls and remind us about the history and human condition.
Here are 4movies (to be frank, I only watched 3 of them, and adored 2.5) that are must-sees before visiting berlin. Or, you may just follow my path and watch the first three.
The movie takes a look into East Berlin life of intellectuals in 1984.
The scenes of the prison of the lives of others were filmed in the Royal Prison, the former Central Prison of State Security (Stasi) of the German Democratic Republic, today converted into the memorial site of Berlin-Hohenschönhausen. If you wish to book a visit, you must first register here. What’s more, former prisoners often offer guided tours where they narrate their personal experience.
Run Lola Run is a movie that literally takes you through Berlin in the turn of century. From now oh-so-hip Friedrichstraße to Charlottenburg near the National Opera, with stops on the Museum Island, Lola is on the mission to save her boyfriend’s life (literally). The other storyline of the movie conveys the saving of herself. Visiting her father, and running through the whole Berlin, she finds herself once again.
She also passes through Schlesischer Tor, Oberbaumbrücke in Kreuzberg or the beautiful square of Gendarmenmarkt in Mitte among many other streets.
In short, its route does not make any geographical sense, but how good and beautiful is Berlin from beginning to end from home and in less than an hour and a half?
Berlin, Symphony of a Great City has an incalculable historical value: this silent film immerses us in day-to-day life in the centre of Berlin in 1927, a Berlin that we neither knew nor will know as it would be reduced to rubble a few more years late.
Probably only the river Spree has remained immutable since then. The Berlin Cathedral, like so many other buildings and monuments portrayed by Walter Ruttmann’s camera, we only know of its recent reconstruction. And others, like the Royal Palace in Berlin, cannot be visited again until 2019 (next year).
Roberto Rossellini stood in what was left of Berlin in 1947, made a casting between non-professional actors and filmed the third chapter of the quintessence of the Italian neorealist: the trilogy of Rome, Appointment aperta, Paisà and this Germania, Anno Zero.
The result is devastating. Edmund Kohler is thirteen years old and wanders through the centre of Berlin with the sole purpose of surviving and helping his family survive. The backdrop is a Reichstag that is already only rubble and the barren esplanade of the Tiergarten, whose wood served to warm German homes during World War II.
The penury was such on and off the screen that many actors escaped when it came time for repatriation after recording the interiors of the film in Rome.

Title: From West Berlin to Washington, DC — A Bridge Between Cultures
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
(Author’s note: A German version of this article was published in Berlin’s “Der Tagesspiegel” newspaper on March 15, 2025)
It didn’t matter if the neighbors looked on disapprovingly. The New Year had arrived, and spring began with a large fire that we, as children, would jump over for what felt like hours to leave behind the evil spirits of the past year. The scent of saffron rice and grilled fish. The loud music surrounded us and the families of my father’s Persian friends who visited each other, greeting with kisses and embraces. Whenever I remember the Persian New Year celebrations I experienced in West Berlin during the 1980s, I’m filled with a warm, hopeful feeling. Back then, I didn’t understand how much more this festival must have meant during that time, amid a terrible war between Iraq and Iran that lasted nearly a decade and resulted in half a million casualties. A celebration amid a German society that was still firmly convinced it was not yet open to immigrants and what they could contribute. For my dad and his friends, the celebration was a piece of home helping them feel more at home in a foreign land.
Only years later did I learn how widespread the tradition of this New Year’s festival is. According to UNESCO, “It has been celebrated by more than 300 million people for over 3,000 years in the Balkan Peninsula, the Black Sea region, the Caucasus, Central Asia, and the Middle East.” The festival’s observance traces back to the Zoroastrian ancestors of today’s Iranian people. Since 2009, the UN has even included Nouruz in the Representative List of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity.
When I would return to my Berlin school on Mondays after the festival, there was no mention of the Persian New Year. Only Christmas, Easter, and New Year’s Eve existed. Once, in 12th grade, our English teacher asked about our backgrounds and our parents. I remember it clearly because it was such an unusual experience. She wanted to know if we, as children of immigrants, felt any particular conflict. The only thing I felt were the glances of my classmates, which led me to give an evasive answer. The meaning and power of the New Year’s festival thus remained hidden from her and the rest of the teachers and students.
For example, the story of Kaveh the Blacksmith, who plays an important role in Ferdowsi’s famous Book of Kings. According to legend, Kaveh led an Iranian uprising against a cruel, child-devouring dragon king. This symbolism of resistance against oppression has led authoritarian governments to attempt to ban the festival over the years repeatedly. However, the most important meaning of the festival is the awakening of nature to new life in spring, the victory of light over darkness, and of knowledge over ignorance.
When I speak with my friends in Berlin every weekend, it becomes increasingly clear to me how important it is to celebrate the Persian New Year and remember its message, especially this year. For weeks, I’ve been hearing much about the challenges originating in Moscow and here in Washington, D.C., and the increasingly difficult political and economic situation for Germany and Europe. Even during the pandemic, I didn’t perceive this much fear and uncertainty about the situation.
Next week, I will tell the children at my daughter’s elementary school in Washington, D.C. about the Persian New Year. There are some children there who are directly affected by their parents’ dismissals by the Trump administration. There are flyers preparing for the possible removal of children of illegal immigrants at the school. The teacher invited me at my daughter’s request, who had so enjoyed the presentation of the Indian Festival of Lights, Diwali, in the fall by a mother of Indian descent. I will tell them about the great New Year’s festival and its message that we will celebrate with friends and neighbors. With a fire that many in the city will jump over to rid themselves of the evil spirits of the past year. And about how for me, the festival is also a piece of memory of Berlin and a home that I gladly share with all who currently need more confidence and community.
--

Title: What Is Berlin Famous For? Why Bother Visiting Berlin? | easyGuide
Content:
Sign up

Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
What is Berlin famous for and why do travellers everywhere recommend and rave about the German capital so often?
Berlin is an eccentric city with an eclectic culture and is one of the most ‘happening’ places in Europe. The city attracts over 14 million visitors every year and tops many tourist’s bucket lists who all want to experience its vibrancy and aesthetic. However, you probably want to know exactly why the city is so highly regarded before booking your next trip.
Let’s find out what is Berlin famous for? And why is it so different to any other capital city?
The city is home to many iconic, quirky buildings and monuments. From the Gothic design of Berlin cathedral, to the Rococo-inspired Charlottenburg Palace, and post-war Brutalist architecture, like the harrowing concrete landscape of the Holocaust Memorial. The city is full of diverse architectural styles.
The Berlin art scene is modern, vibrant and alternative. Whilst the city has many galleries dedicated to classic art, Berlin is probably most famous for its brilliant and bizarre street art, which coats buildings and the remains of the Berlin wall. The creativity of Berlin artists is unparalleled — no concrete surface is safe!
Berlin’s music scene is well known and respected across many genres. The city has three operatic houses — perfect locations to perform the works of German composers like Beethoven, Brahms and Bach, to name a few. Disco, electronic and synthpop are also very popular in the city and many club-goers enjoying dancing till dawn to this modern music in trendy venues.
Speaking of dancing in trendy venues, Berlin’s nightlife is widely considered one of the best in the world. The capital’s most exclusive club and notoriously difficult to enter is Berghain, but there are many other exciting and elusive venues to party in, dotted about the streets.
Berlin is renowned for its charming markets. Some weekly events include a traditional farmer’s market selling German craft food and drink, to hipster flea markets full of handmade treasures. Germany is also famous for hosting magical Christmas markets too, and Berlin is no exception!
Berliners are serious about their sausages! And the currywurst is the most popular item, available on almost every street corner of the capital. Quick n’ easy, yet filling and tasty, the sausage dish is a world-famous German delicacy.
Berlin famously contains many beautiful gardens and clean parks which contrast, yet compliment the built-up, concrete landscape. Tiergarten is perhaps the most famous central garden and is located next to popular attractions the Reichstag and Victory Column.
Berlin’s fascinating, dark past has left behind many abandoned and derelict buildings, some of which are open to exploration, such as an American spy station and an abandoned theme park. The sites are often covered in incredible street art and are a must-see amongst adventurous travellers who enjoy going off the typical tourist paths.
The bear is the mascot of Berlin. It proudly stands on the city’s coat of arms and the Berlin Buddy Bear is a fun interpretation of the animal. Berlin has 140 painted Buddy sculptures scattered around the centre. They have become an integral part of the streets of Berlin, not to mention inspiring many souvenir gifts. Many tourists enjoy counting how many they find on their travels through the city.
This is just a short list about what Berlin is famous for. The city is treasured and respected by so many for an abundance of personal reasons, but anyone lucky enough to have seen the capital can agree it is a unique and visit-worthy city.
Will you add Berlin to your bucket list?

“The strength of career success lies in the power of networking.” - Omotola E.O.
I shared in my previous post about my speaking engagement in Berlin at FOSS Backstage, where I spoke on Contributors’ Engagement and Monetization Opportunities.
In this series, I’ll share some of the new connections I made on this trip, particularly at the FOSS Backstage event.
This is my first international trip outside of Africa. I got the feeling you get when you go to a different country and meet people from different cultures. The good thing is I was already looking forward to connecting, learning new cultures, and having a good time.
I did! I met some cool folks from different organizations and career paths. One thing that brought us together is our love for open source.
Among many other connections I made at this conference, meeting with Outreachy mentors was one of my highlights.
I met with Antonin Delpeuch, an Open Refine community mentor, and Jarek Potiuk, an OpenStack community mentor.
We discussed their experience as an Outreachy mentor, how the program has benefited their projects, and them as a mentor. It’s good to hear them talk about what excites them about Outreachy applicants and interns and how the program has enhanced their projects.
After the conference, I had a good dinner with Antonin Delpeuch, and we talked more about the future of open source and outreach programs. We also shared individual goals, our steps, and what we see in open source.
It was such a great privilege to not only meet with other open source advocates who are interested in what the Outreachy program does but to learn more about how open source experts and the community can get involved, the benefit of the program to mentors, and the steps and requirements to participate in the program.
I was able to preach the gospel of Outreachy to these fantastic folks and build and strengthen their knowledge about the program and relationship. Looking forward to further connecting with them and having them support diversity in tech through the Outreachy program.
Until the next and final series, I will share my experience exploring the great Berlin. Mach’s gut (Welle)!

Title: Why Berlin Might Become Europe’s Greatest City

Germany is Europe’s most important country. It is the most economically powerful country on the continent, a heavyweight in political and humanitarian affairs, and the EU’s most populous country.
Yet its capital city, Berlin, is a bit of a disappointment. Despite its urban sprawl, it boasts quite a small population for the capital of such a big country — significantly lower than Istanbul, Paris or London.
It’s also quite poor for the capital of such a rich country — until 2018, Berliners were actually poorer than the national average. That means that Berlin was in the extraordinary position of being a capital city that dragged down the rest of the national economy. Even now, many big cities in Germany (Munich, Hamburg, Frankfurt, Stuttgart etc) are richer than Berlin.
Nevertheless, like virtually all capital cities, Berlin has a dream to sell. London and New York brand themselves as the financial rulers of the world; Paris sees itself…

Title: “God Bless America”: Celebrating Irving Berlin and Military Veterans
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Follow publication
A not-for-profit organization dedicated to enriching the cultural life of Los Angeles through plays and educational programs that inform, entertain and inspire. www.geffenplayhouse.org
Follow publication
--
Listen
Share
You might expect a 91-year-old to have plenty of leisure hours. Not Francis Kilduff. The WWII veteran is so busy putting the final touches on his latest docudrama and hobnobbing at the USO headquarters, he barely made it to the theater. Though he managed to carve some time out of his weekend to enjoy a pre-performance meal at the Geffen Playhouse, he’s hurriedly slicing into his beef and hoping he doesn’t miss curtain.
It’s the Sunday night before Veteran’s Day, and Geffen has invited military vets not only to take in the final dress rehearsal of Hershey Felder as Irving Berlin, but also to enjoy a catered dinner buffet. Partnering with the Gary Sinise Foundation (Sinise and Randall Arney, Geffen’s Artistic Director, are pals from their days working together at Chicago’s Steppenwolf Theatre), the Geffen celebrates veterans by hosting these special veterans nights for every Gil Cates Theater subscription production. As a proud partner of Blue Star Theatres, the Geffen Playhouse also offers veterans free tickets to season productions year-round.
But tonight is extra special. For most of these vets, Irving Berlin composed the soundtracks to their lives.
Seated at the table with Kilduff is Alan Bertik, an affable vet who was on a Navy destroyer in the Korean War (“It was 30 below,” he says, chuckling). He and his wife used to usher at the Geffen. They saw Felder perform one New Year’s Eve, but he’s especially excited about this show for the simple reason that he knows most of the music. Of course, everyone knows the biggies: “White Christmas,” “There’s No Business Like Show Business,” “Oh! How I Hate to Get Up in the Morning.” Still, Berlin’s catalog is so expansive — he wrote at least 1,500 songs — there are many that history has forgotten. Yet the men and women who fell in love, broke up and fell in love again remember them fondly.
“Of course I’m excited!” Kilduff chimes in. “That’s my era.”
Hershey Felder has crafted one-man shows based on Gershwin, Chopin, Beethoven and Bernstein, creating experiences that are half concerto, half stage play. In fact, they’re so unique he’s become quite famous not only in Southern California, with many premieres at the Geffen, plus performances at Pasadena Playhouse, Laguna Playhouse, San Diego Rep and the Old Globe, but also across the nation and world. (You can read more about his work in a recent American Theatre magazine article that is also re-published as the program note for the show.)
For Hershey Felder as Irving Berlin, Felder recounts Berlin’s life story by weaving memories into songs. During the peformance, Felder plays one of Berlin’s most famous songs, “God Bless America,” and invites the audience to sing along. As voices surged with pride during the dress rehearsal, there were more than a few eyes filled with tears. The one constant in Berlin’s life — from being an immigrant baby to a “singing waiter” to Fred Astaire’s best bud to a lonely recluse — was that he found comfort in music. Berlin may be America’s most famous composer, but to that end, he’s not so different than the rest of us.
Join the Geffen Playhouse in celebrating veterans like Francis Kilduff and Alan Bertik. Click here to donate now or call Regina Miller at 310.208.6500 ext. 112.
Click here for tickets and more information on Hershey Felder as Irving Berlin.
Haithcoat is the Geffen Playhouse’s Communications Editor. Her writing on music, theater and even weddings has been published in LA Weekly, The New York Times, Noisey and Billboard, among others.

I visited many galleries and art exhibitions in Berlin and here’s my reviews.
It is not as difficult to purchase tickets as it is in Barcelona, but it is critical to double-check the opening days and hours.
I visited "the soul station" : the LAS Foundation in Halle am Berghain. An extensive interactive metaverse ethical gaming installation.Brathwaite-Shirley investigates marginalized histories, particularly those of the Black and Queer communities. When prospects go into Berlin’s renowned space, they are greeted by a dark, foggy environment filled with an array of varying screen displays flickering with artificial light, waiting us to tap in.
I spent a lot of time there trying to understand everything, but there still remain some parts of the journey that are perplexing. The storyline offers the sense of limitless possibilities. As my friend grace said , it kind of reminds me of Love + Death robots vibe too.
By the time I visited it was only 8 euro and it was episode 1 of the game.
Episode 2: ARE YOU SOULLESS, TOO?Will start from September to October.
Really really worth it.
Really famous on social media. An immersive museum exploring the concept of dark matter. It was really far away , and maybe I expected too much after the halle- exhibition visit. There are several rooms to explore and you can probably finish it all in 1 and a half hours. Or even faster without the drink/snack breaks in between. However, this place made for a really good video/ photos. The tickets are quite expensive for what it offer though…
I truly had fun that visit! Film buffs will thoroughly like this. There are free smartphone applications for audio guides, and it was simultaneously interesting and enlightening. Day tickets cost 9 euros and close at 6 p.m. After experiencing the museum, visitors can also visit the Library of Film Archives. Aside from that, it’s clear that the Deutsch kinemathek hosts a variety of exhibitions. On top of that, the permanent display will close in October. I had an absolute blast there.
Honestly ， I encountered a lot of fashionable people here. And I think they’re here for the IG post. It certainly is a cool place to take photos.
I saved a lot more museum visit as well but I just couldn’t make it because of prior plans. Next time , Berlin!

Title: Off The Rails: A Run-In With German Bureaucracy
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

International journalism students report from Berlin, the heart of Europe.

--
4
Listen
Share
The Berliner Verkehrsbetriebe (BVG) — Berlin’s citywide public transportation system — boasts an sprawling web of trains running with cold, calculated efficiency. A moment’s tardiness leaves your arms struggling to stretch the closing doors. A Google search reveals a link to its website, which bears the slogan: “Because we love you.”
Evidently, this love only applies to the native and the lucky. As with any bureaucratic bunch, alas, the company’s true love remains the almighty Rulebook. German culture in general reveres tradition, so the guidelines of their businesses prove tighter to squeeze through than their departing train doors.
When I arrived in Berlin after 16 restless hours of international travel, I scoured the BVG ticket dispenser for the student option. I was desperate to end the day, but both I and my travel organizers had done our research. The website listed the 61 Euro “Ausbildung” (“education”) ticket as the one for students and nowhere did it state any specification beyond possessing a student card, so I bought the ticket and left.
A week passed. I grew infatuated with Berlin, its cosmopolitanism broadening my perspective on what a big city could be. Worried that if I didn’t lower my gaze from the high rises to my laptop I might miss my deadlines, I ventured off to the nearest U-Bahn station, aiming to write at a local café.
I boarded a U-Bahn remarkably devoid of people. Over that last week alone, I’d shared more physical intimacy with fellow train-riders than in many long-term friendships, so any room to breathe was precious.
The second a BVG officer boarded, however, all air left the train car. A heavyset, bald man, clearly born for this role, he bore a black vest thicker than any soldier’s. Beneath this riot gear he wore a black T-shirt, with the skull logo of Marvel Comics character The Punisher imprinted on its sleeve.
I was sure that I had no reason for concern. As the train left the station, he whipped out his scanner, demanding that all passengers present their tickets. A few good citizens later, he reached me, scanned my ticket, and stared me down.
“Let me see your student ID,” he said. I obliged. Staring at the UC Santa Barbara logo, he remarked: “This is not the ticket.” Confused, I emphasized that I was indeed a student studying here. Shaking his head, he replied: “You will get off with me.” As he turned to continue scanning, I made nervous eye contact with The Punisher’s skull.
Stepping off, I found my pitiful German akin to a fist in a gunfight. He claimed my ticket was solely “for job education” and set me an appointment to pay it the next day. Having conveniently reached my stop, I hobbled off, defeated, to the coffee shop.
The next day, I trekked over to the BVG headquarters for my appointment, with Vanessa — my trip-appointed German translator and true hero — by my side. The front of the building, complete with LGBTQ+ rainbow colors displayed, seemed inviting enough. Quickly, however, we were directed to a crude little crevice in the building’s back corner.
A bouncer-type at the BVG customer office bellowed orders from the front door. We sat together, awaiting our turn. I expressed confidence in our success.
Okay, you absolutely shouldn’t judge a book by its cover. But when I tell you my confidence melted the second I saw the man behind the counter, please let me off this one time. His eyes teemed with dissatisfaction. Mercy was not in this man’s vocabulary — nor was any English. Funny how this was the only place in Berlin I’ve been where no one has spoken English.
Vanessa fought valiantly, but it was a losing battle. The facts of the story — I am a student studying in Berlin and I had bought a ticket at the student ticket price — meant nothing to this man. “You wouldn’t go to Thailand and use your student ID to buy a ticket there,” he repeated. I am neither sure why that’s something I wouldn’t do, nor what his focus on Thailand was about. But we were chipping away at stone.
“You cannot buy this ticket as a foreigner,” he said. We emphasized that nowhere did the website specify this. “Go online and write a complaint,” he responded.
Vanessa looked at me sympathetically. I sighed, knowing the war was lost, and paid the fine. The 60 Euros aside, I felt robbed of the wide-eyed earnestness I’d brought in my suitcase. There was something potent in that initial Berlin buzz, the excitement of believing this new place might be better than back home. But now I felt disillusioned.
Make no mistake, I’m still loving my time in Berlin. You could spend weeks peeling back this city’s layers — the boundless events and different cultures it hosts — and still never find the end. Any place this large and bustling needs a public transit system, so one must deal with the BVG. Still, I wanted to issue this warning, just in case The Punisher tries to track you down.
Go online and write a complaint, huh?
Fine, man. Here it is, for the entire world to read.
Nick Blair is a California college student majoring in Film and Media Studies. He is in Berlin this summer reporting as part of ieiMedia’s “Berlin Beyond Borders” journalism team.

Title: 16 Things I Wish I’d Known Before Moving to Berlin, Germany
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

A publication for expats, former expats, and soon to be expats and their adventures around the world.

Member-only story
--
6
Share
Thinking of making Berlin your new home?
Take these things into account for a smoother move.
A “Wahlberlinerin” (Berlin citizen by choice) explains.
Visiting my hometown in Groningen, the Netherlands feels like a breath of fresh air, as if I’m walking through a village. Most pedestrians on the street greet me with a smile and a nod.
It doesn’t work like that in Berlin.
You ignore one another. Some neighbors who accepted my packages in the past and certainly know who I am ignore me in any other setting.
It’s no different when walking on the street. No one greets you, you greet no one. If you do, expect frowns, very confused, or even scared looks.
The temperatures drop to or below zero during the winter months. People get moody, sulky, and the city turns bleak.
The only good thing about Berlin winters from the perspective of a Dutch person: it doesn’t rain…

Title: Berlin Diary Part I
Content:

Sign up

Follow publication
