Title: Believing the Unbelievable: Berlin at 80
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I was in Berlin, Germany, on May 8th; the 80th anniversary of the day that German forces surrendered unconditionally to the Allies, marking the end of WW2 in Europe. This day is sometimes referred to as “VE Day” (Victory in Europe Day). What a fitting place to be for this momentous occasion.
I have been in Berlin twice before. My first visit, in the summer of 1963 when I was 15 years old, was as part of a “teen tour” of Europe. Asleep in a Berlin hotel, I was awakened by gunfire. The construction of the Berlin Wall (at first, a barbed wire fence) began in August 1961 and in the years following, many people were shot as they tried to escape from East into West Berlin.
My second visit was 24 years ago, as part of a small group from the US Holocaust Memorial Museum, visiting historic sites in Eastern Europe that included memorials, museums, and several concentration camps. Sachsenhausen, one such camp near Berlin, is in the village of Oranienburg. It began as a slave labor camp for “political prisoners” with many subcamps. Still visible are barracks and the ruins of buildings in which remain the remnants of a gas chamber, medical experimentation areas, torture and killing areas, and several crematoria. Prisoners were treated inhumanely, inadequately fed, and openly killed. If you are reading this article, you probably know the list of who would be considered enemies of the state. A partial list includes those against the Reich whether they were Christian, Protestant, Jewish, Coptic, Roma, Communists, Gays, and anyone who was perceived to be mentally or physically disabled. This camp, not unlike others, was not on the outskirts of town. It was in the town. An alleyway separates the town from the gates to the camp with the words “Arbeit Macht Frei” (Works Sets You Free) welded into the gate. This place was not hidden. Quite the contrary, it was wide open to view and more importantly to odor. With several crematoria where bodies were burned, the smell and the ash wafted over the town, falling onto people’s rose gardens as well as onto the town residents themselves.
But I digress. Twenty four years ago, when I visited this camp, there was a person with us who, as a young man, had been a prisoner in Sachsenhausen. Somehow, miraculously, he survived. A Christian man, he had been a journalist, soon to be married, but that did not happen. It was a privilege to see the camp through his eyes, and listen as he recounted his experiences, some of which he had thought he buried along with his fellow inmates.
This was a sacred place whose stories were told to keep alive the memory of those who perished and those who survived. For decades after the war ended, “Never Again” was repeated to ensure that this kind of unleashed hatred and vitriol, resulting in these sorts of inhuman actions, would never happen again. And most of us in the world were confident that nothing like this could ever happen again!
This visit was different.
First, I am different. I am 24 years older. What I try to convince myself of is “unbelievable.” I need to believe.
Second, the world is different. Hatred, vitriol, and cruelty have become normalized. The vile antisemitic tropes that were used to degrade and denigrate people are not only ripe, but they are blossoming. Regrettably, in many places, they are in full bloom. This kind of hate flourishes on the dark web, and in the full light of day. Repulsive speech and actions have become acceptable. Throughout the world we see the rise of political parties with slogans reminiscent of a world which we thought could never be resurrected. And not only is it resurrected, but these parties have also gained representation in congresses and parliaments in the same countries where brave citizens sacrificed and fought against this to make the world safe for all.
Third, the camp is not the same. Shockingly, there are some people who visit the camp, stand next to the crematory ruins, on the rim of the entrance of the first experiment for a gas chamber, beside the remains of a barracks, who say: “this did not happen.” When you tell a lie often enough, people tend to believe it. That’s what happened prior to and during World War II. And in many parts of our world, it is happening now.
I am at a time in my life when more people than not ask me “When are you going to retire?” Here’s my response. Not only am I not going to retire, I am also committing to rededicate myself to engaging in education programs and social justice issues concerning basic human rights related to antisemitism and anti-LGBTQ hatred. All in, in my “golden years” I will not stand by and silently witness the normalization of hatred.
I write this article with both a heavy and a hopeful heart. When I say things are unbelievable, I reinforce in my own mind that I shouldn’t believe them. I am awake to the reality and the knowledge that I must believe what I see, hear, and witness. When I believe it, I will be able to address it in ways that, hopefully, will change where we are, and where we can go as a civil society.
We can choose hate, or we can choose to stand up to hate. We can be silent, or we can call people out when they say or do things that are rooted in prejudice and hate. Each of us can use our voice and our platform for good. We can choose to make excuses for bad behavior, or we can call it out. We can acquaint ourselves with history. We can familiarize ourselves with the consequences when hate is permitted to run amok. We can call out when we see lies presented as truth. And we can challenge people who are fearful or intimidated into saying and behaving in ways that are unacceptable.
When we sit by as people are being dehumanized, referred to as the “other,” we are at the entrance to the gates of Hell. I went through those gates as a tourist. I’ve listened to and read testimonies, seen films and photographs of what Hell looks like. If we consider ourselves members of the human race, we need to take that membership seriously and be aware of what it means to be human. To have hope in the future we need to discover compassion within and speak out against antisemitism and all forms of hate. We cannot excuse the inexcusable and we must believe the unbelievable.
In life’s most challenging moments, how we respond influences both our immediate wellbeing and long-term recovery. Crises arrive uninvited, testing our resilience when we feel most vulnerable. The following tips offer guidance through the turbulence, toward steadier ground.
Remain Calm: When crisis emerges, take a gentle body scan — notice your breathing, pulse, and physical sensations. Do not judge, just observe. Then begin to breathe and focus on your breath. The key is to avoid panic. When we panic, we cannot solve problems effectively. The goal is to think clearly while being aware of what is happening in your body. During this process, pause, take more slow, deep breaths. For some people, repeating prayers that offer solace, doing mindful practice, mindfulness, or engaging playfully with a pet can help.
Assess The Situation: From this centered state notice where you are physically, mentally, and emotionally. Then, identify the elements defining the crisis. What risks exist? What consequences might follow different actions? This assessment doesn’t require perfect information — only honest recognition of what is known and unknown in this moment.
Create Safety: Do what you need to get out of harm’s way. Look around, listen attentively, and notice your surroundings with fresh eyes. Take actions that move you toward greater security, extending this same protective attention to others if they’re with you.
Gather Your Support Circle: Reach out to those whose compassion brings calm — trusted friends, family members, professionals, or others who have walked similar paths. Seek those who offer the support you need rather than imposing what they believe you should want. Throughout the situation, maintain connection with beloved others. Consider engaging in creative activities that redirect mental energy — photography, gardening, music, reading, or writing — offering your mind the opportunity to “reset.”
Communicate with Transparency: Share information others need to hear to assist you, especially during medical emergencies when providers need accurate knowledge of your condition to offer effective care with minimal risk. Honest communication about symptoms, relevant medical history, concerns, and needs, creates the foundation for receiving proper assistance.
Create a Crisis Plan: Consider creating a simple emergency kit kept in your vehicle or near an exit. Maintain accessible records of essential medications, identification, and emergency contacts — both digitally and physically. Identify people who might assist with temporary housing, caregiving, pet-care, or other practical needs that could arise.
Honor Your Fundamental Needs: In crisis, the basics become precious: adequate rest, nourishment, hydration, and moments of quiet. Reflect on what essentials you require and consider how to ensure access to these necessities even during disruption. Tending to these fundamental needs becomes an act of self-compassion during challenging times.
Remember that getting through times of crisis times isn’t about handling everything perfectly. It’s about showing up as best we can, being kind to ourselves, and figuring things out as we go. Sometimes the hardest moments teach us what we’re made of and connect us more deeply to what matters. We might surprise ourselves with what we can handle, even when it feels impossible at first.
I’ve co-authored a book about kindness. I believe deeply in the lasting effects of love. It is in that context that I share my own daily habit. Each morning, I say thank you for another day and ask for an opportunity to make a difference in this world.
To that end, I look for signs of connection to those who came before me — a robin reminds me that my father is near, a butterfly reminds me of my mother. I feel their presence and listen for their guidance. Certain songs transport me to moments in my past, conjuring places, people, and, sometimes, lessons learned.
This daily habit provides continuity to my life. I’m grateful that my journey has been a healthy one so far. Though everything is unpredictable, I express gratitude however I can and move through the world appreciating all the companions I’ve known along the way.
Dr. Dale Atkinsdale@drdaleatkins.comwww.drdaleatkins.com

Title: The Ultimate Guide for the Blue Card in Berlin
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
A step-by-step guide through the recently released online Blue Card application
The fact that Berlin’s Immigration Office, a.k.a Ausländerbehörde, is currently totally collapsed is widely known. As time passes by, more and more people apply for a residence permit, blue card, or any other immigration matter, and they have almost Zero digitalized processes, which makes the workload humanly impossible to handle by the workers there. The current backlog was estimated to be processed within the whole year of 2024. And the forecast doesn’t bring any good news about digitalizing the entire immigration process. (What would be the most reasonable thing to be done).That said, when you try to make an appointment to do whatever you need to do there, the system proves to be failed once more, and it’s not operational at all. A piece of brick to be written on would do a better job.
As surprising and ghastly as it can sound to the average German citizen, Berlin LEA has recently released an ONLINE application for Blue Card purposes, that includes IT Specialists as well. (You didn’t read it wrong. Yeah, it’s online, and it’s in Germany).
Before diving into the guide, I just want to highlight my situation with this bureaucracy.
On September/23 I was a victim of a mass lay-off from a company in Berlin, the good old story of the awful Upper Management that brings dozens of immigrants to work at their startup with nothing but a bet on getting money out of it in the future, and when things goes wrong the immigrants pay the price (Less than 5% of the laid-off were Germans or had lived in german for more than 5 years).
For my luck, I got a new Job on October/23 and things were quite good at this point. I didn’t know what was expecting me tho…
I got the information that since I’ve been in Germany for less than 2 years (I arrived on October/22), I needed another approval from the Central Foreigners and Specialist Placement office a.k.a ZAV. This consists of a bureaucratic step where a person with ZERO knowledge of your area of expertise will evaluate if you have or not the qualifications to engage in the new Job that you already have. So, no matter if you pass through a selection process of the company and they evaluate your skills, this government organ must approve it as well. It’s the government shooting its own feet and creating the problems on its own.
That said I got an appointment at the Immigration Office (Every Wednesday between 11 am and 1 pm pretend that you have no other thing to do in your life and just refresh the appointment page every 1 second and you may be lucky to get an appointment). When I went there I was told they needed to send my application to ZAV to get the new approval and only then I could start working.
2 Months have passed, and nothing happened.
At the beginning of December, almost sure that I would need to ask for money on the streets, while I was exploring all possible options on the immigration office website, I found this online tool to apply for a Blue Card.
And they won’t let it easy to be found, on purpose, I believe.
After the last step you pay the 100 Euro fee, and it’s done. After 1 week I got the info that ZAV approved my new Job and I could finally start working.
TLDR: here’s the link: https://service.berlin.de/dienstleistung/324659/
Just translate the page and click on “Do it online now”
Two things are important to highlight:
1 — Your company must provide you with a letter (PDF) saying that your English level is good enough and that they only speak English at your company. Additionally, they can amend it by saying that you’re qualified enough for the role and have passed through a selection process.
2 — After applying you must call ZAV every day on +49 228 713 131 and make sure that your company can reach out to LEA as well.
When calling ZAV you shall go for option 2 (speak in English) and 1 (ask about work permit). Most of the time a robot speaking in German will just drop your call, so try at 9 am and 12 pm, 1 pm and 2 pm. These are the best times to call.
When speaking with the agent you shall ask about the status of your blue card application informing your last name and birthdate. Once they say it’s approved, you can ask your company to reach out to LEA so they can get a confirmation document saying that you’re allowed to work.
Your blue card in fact will only arrive after several months, but at least you’ll be able to work till then.
I hope that this guide can be useful for other people struggling with Berlin’s Immigration Office and for those who are in a situation similar to the one I was in.

Title: The Rave Guide—Berlin Club Etiquette
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
This guide contains a collection of dos and don’ts to make sure you and everyone you’re raving with has a great time while clubbing. Although it’s based on the Berlin club culture, I’d be happy to see this applied everywhere where people are enjoying music together — be it at a club, festival or concert anywhere in the world.
I’ve spent a significant amount of my lifetime on the dance floor, because that’s simply one of the things in life that gives me the most joy. I was lucky enough to get introduced to the Berlin nightlife, festivals and Burns by great friends and experienced ravers, but often enough I meet people who didn’t get a chance for such an introduction. And although I don’t think that too much of advice is needed for yourself to have fun while clubbing in Berlin, I feel like there certainly are some things to keep in mind in order to make sure your fellow ravers are also having a great time.
So basically this is me wanting others to behave the way I consider appropriate, just so that I can keep on enjoying my time raving as much as possible. But that sounds terribly egocentric, so let’s not put it that way…
Figuring out where to go and how to dress can be challenging. There are quite a few guides available for selecting the right club or what to wear to blend in, but let me quickly add some points: The vibe you’ll experience will greatly vary between different clubs — and even between different events at the same club — so try out as much as you can. You’ll eventually find the scene you’ll enjoy the most. And while you generally should adhere to dress codes (e.g. no streetwear), don’t overthink it. The most important thing is that you’re being comfortable. Feel free to express yourself, your fellow ravers won’t judge. The people that do are not the people whose opinion you should care about. Avoid dressing a certain way just because others are doing it, go with your own style.
Although you should pack as light as possible, make sure to bring essentials that you or others may need. You’ll need cash in most clubs unfortunately, and ATMs in or at clubs often come with deposit fees. Don’t underestimate the importance of ear plugs, preventing hearing damage is reasonable in general and in some locations the sound can be unpleasantly loud. Bringing chewing gum, a lighter (even if you don’t smoke) or tampon and pain killer (even if you’re not going to need it) are easy ways to earn some karma points.
If you’re planning to do drugs: Do proper research about the substances that you consider consuming and also check how they interact with each other. The TripSit wiki is a great resource for that. Don’t try out stuff for the first time in a club you’ve never been to before or without people you trust and don’t push your limits. Remember that set and setting are key for psychedelic experiences. If possible, purchase what you need outside of the club, prepare it for consumption and label it properly. Club toilets are not a great place for doing that! Read about safer use guidelines.
If you’re not planning to do drugs: Awesome, chances are you’ll get into ecstasy just by focusing on the music and visual effects anyway! However, I would still recommend reading up on the effects of common party drugs, since quite a few people around you will be high. It will help you understand why people are behaving in certain ways, and empathy is key for having a great time together.
Most people will be joining the queue between 12 am and 3 am and it can stay crowded until the early morning. I personally never understood that and feel it’s much more comfortable to avoid arriving at the prime time.
Perks of arriving early: You get to skip the super long queues and are less likely to be rejected. I get that, for many people, queueing is part of the experience and I’ve met a fair share of my friends randomly while waiting in line. However, I’d rather spend that time chatting in a chill-out area inside, or dancing on the not yet crowded dance floor. Some clubs also have a reduced entry fee or cheaper drinks before midnight.
Alternatively, arriving in the morning can also be great (given you selected a club that isn’t closing): You’ll also avoid the entry queue, and the people that are still there or arriving with you are the really motivated ones. If you got some sleep during the night before, this will also be easier on your sleep schedule for the next day. Unfortunate timing can have you queuing for the coat check together with people that want to leave though.
Whenever you arrive, please don’t skip the queue unless you know someone who’s already in line. Some people make a sport out of it, but it’s simply annoying for everyone else.
Just like at the entry queue, please don’t push to the front. Know what you want to order before being asked. Have money prepared and don’t start looking for cash after your drinks are ready. Give a tip if everything was alright. Leave the bar counter after you paid. Same applies to the coat check.
Chances are that you’ll spend more time queuing for a bathroom stall than for drinks at the bar. And that’s mainly because they’re being used for taking drugs without needing to worry about the security.
If you’re in need for a place to consume stuff, first check if there are other options. Many clubs provide some conveniently separated small areas, these are there for this exact purpose (not to be confused with dark rooms meant for sexual encounters). The club staff won’t disrupt you there. If only bathrooms are available, make sure to minimise the time you spend in the stall and share it with other people that just need it for the same reason.
If you’re actually in need to relieve yourself with some urgency, it’s not unlikely that people will let you take their place in line if you ask nicely. Look out for groups of people that seam like they’ll not use the toilet for its intended purpose. Remember to check if there’s toilet paper in your stall before you need it, since there often is none.
Let loose and dance like no-one is watching. And smile while you’re at it. Having fun is contagious, your motivation will lift the mood of everyone around you. Similarly, if you’re not currently feeling it, don’t stand still right in front of the DJ looking like you’re forced to be there. Maybe go explore the other areas or grab a drink instead.
Dancing is so much more fun if you’re seeing how others are enjoying the music too. The dance floor is not the place to have smalltalk at, or to call the friend you’re supposed to be with, or to check your connection for the way home. Focus on the music and allow others to do the same.
The single most annoying thing for many ravers are other people using their phones (occasionally challenged by rude wasted people). A few clubs will require you to leave your phone at the coat check, most will cover your cameras. And that’s for a reason. Capturing the experience you’re having using a phone camera will likely be underwhelming and it’s degrading the experience that others are having. If you need to message someone, don’t do so in the middle of the dance floor. Your screen will be blinding and distracting for people around you. You and others will have the best time if you manage to not use your phone at all.
This should go without saying, but just be nice. Respect the personal space of others. If you bump into someone, say sorry. If you spill someones drink, go get a new one. If you find something that someone else lost, return it at the bar or coat check. If you see someone that could use help, offer some or go get the awareness team. Treat others the way you would like to be treated. Try finding joy in others having a great time with you, e.g. by doing a random act of kindness to a stranger. Offering water to someone who looks like they might be dehydrated is an always appreciated gesture. Imagine strangers just being friends of friends that you didn’t get introduced to yet. They might actually are!
For some more general guidelines that are worth being aware of, I’d recommend checking out:
If you’ve made it this far, I’m certain you’ll be a great rave companion.See you on the dance floor!

Title: I’m leaving Berlin?! Why?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
I’ve come to realize just how much our surroundings can immediately influence the way we feel and live. Even with the best intentions, if our environment doesn’t align with the life we’re trying to build, it can slowly drag us in a different direction.
As someone who genuinely values wellness — not just fitness, but a balanced lifestyle — I started feeling really out of place in Berlin, where the culture often revolves around techno, party scenes, kink, smoking, drinking, drug use, and getting by on gig work and state support.
Yes, I said it.
So yeah… I’m counting down the days until I leave Berlin.
I’ve been feeling exhausted — not just physically, but mentally and spiritually too. Lately, my coping mechanism has been traveling, trying to shake off the energy around me. If I can afford the trip, I go.
But then I have to come back, right? And as soon as I do, it all hits me again.
So, I’ve started seriously thinking about ditching Berlin for good. Wild, I know. But, as I’m not exactly rolling in money, and as dreamy as it sounds to just chase sunsets and sip cocktails by the beach, reality’s got other plans. Like, you know… needing an actual job. Minor detail.
But you’re talking to Miss “I Got a Plan” over here. Structured as heck, checklist in hand.
First, things first, I will finish my short-term work contract in Berlin, then find a proper job — ideally one that doesn’t evaporate in six months. Radical idea, I know. And, move! Somewhere. Anywhere. Preferably with fewer existential crises per square meter.
Surprise, surprise — after a six-month-long panic search, most job leads pointed right back to… you guessed it: Berlin (shockingly original) or in that other glittering gem of excitement: Frankfurt am Main. Honestly, I don’t even know what’s worse — Berlin’s militant wokeness or Frankfurt’s charming little drug haven, the Bahnhofsviertel.
Oh, the irony… Am I giving off too much of “Alan is Morissette ’95” vibes if I start singing, “Isn’t it ironic?” Because that feels like the perfect soundtrack.
If you’ve ever felt like you love a place but it just doesn’t love your lifestyle back — trust that feeling. You don’t have to shrink your values to fit.
Seven months of job hunting across Germany’s “livable” expat-friendly medium-sized cities, and the only way out is out of the country. The economy’s going straight down the drain, so jobs are disappearing faster than my patience. Oh, and to add some extra spice, every single role now expects you to be a SQL, Python, and AI specialist.
I asked around with some colleagues and friends who are job hunting too, thinking maybe I’m just unlucky. Turns out, nope, the same story for them. Everyone’s just hanging on to whatever they can, and the ones who actually can do something are waving goodbye and not in a “see you later” way.
So yeah, the options right now? Not great. In Berlin, most jobs are short-term contracts, with only a handful leading to permanent roles. On top of that, tons of German and international companies based in Germany are outsourcing operations to cheaper countries or relocating staff abroad. So basically, if you’re not planning to survive on social welfare, you either have to accept lower pay and live paycheck to paycheck in constant instability or… well, there’s not really a “or” at this point.
I always wanted this blog to be as honest as possible, because life as an immigrant is way more about adapting to constantly changing circumstances. I chose this path, and I’m fully aware of what it means. But… deep down, I still wish I could make it all work without so much stress.
Against The Odds
--

Fluent in sarcasm, not in German. Came for the vibes, stayed for the existential paperwork. Life as an immigrant in Germany.

Title: On A Sunday in Berlin
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
After living in Berlin for almost six months, it’s time to remedy my failure in writing about its multitude of offerings.
That’s the thing with cities like this, ones spread out over land and history and culture; the sites of early palaces and modern immigration centers. The latest example of gentrification and one of the most well known sites of counterculture movements. A club scene for the leather-clad, but also a site for the wannabe artist and yoga practitioner. It’s just got too much!
Not even a year here will give me a chance to truly sense the song sung by the pulse of this city’s enduring arrhythmia. Instead, I’ll share a few of the spaces that have brought me joy while fall turned to winter and Berlin became the place I call home.
No list of recommendations by a Feldman exists without copious consideration for the locale’s foods. Without an aside on food’s integral place in cultural definition and experience, I’ll recommend a small slice of Berlin’s best culinary experiences.
From April to October, Thai Park street-food market swarms the green space of Preußenpark with delectable, colorful, lustrous-smelling Thai goodies. A cultural event as much as an opportunity for food, grabbing a steaming hot bun and a boba tea, a plate of rolls and a small fruit cake, sitting on the grass to enjoy your scores, Thai Park brings a joyous mix of culture to every demographic in Berlin.
Transported by the sound of Thai spoken at every stall, I used German to order my friends and I steaming vegetable buns, mini pumpkin cake, traditional tea, and noodle dishes. The food was good, the experience was better. Counting down the days until April.
The United State’s lacks a lot of Europe’s most redeeming qualities. And no, not the welfare state or the responsible gun laws, I’m talking about proper Western-Chinese cuisine. I love Chinese food as much as the next coastal Jew, but nothing could prepare me for finding out I’ve been lacking Sichuan noodles my entire life.
In comes Wen Cheng’s, the noodle house of my dreams. Hand-pulled, Sichuan noodles and a low-intensity atmosphere. Just the people of Berlin, and their f*cking delicious noodles.
Split — or don’t — a Gua Bao (Bao Bun) and a classic noodle dish on the sidewalk of Prenzlauer Berg (you can expect a decent line). You won’t think of much else for a while.
Another food I’ll truly never find an equal of elsewhere is, you guessed it, Döner. I like to joke that Döner is one of Germany’s most vital infrastructures, and I have yet to be proven wrong. There’s no one that doesn’t love it. A gift of the Turkish population in Berlin since the 70’s, Döner really is special to the mix of cultures in German cities, and more rural areas alike.
Don’t be mistaken and compare your local Kebab house for the satisfying flavors of Döner sauces, the endless carts of breads that steam as they’re split for filling, or the unmistakable script of most Döner location menus.
My local spot, the roadside Crispy Döner in Charlottenburg, has never done me wrong. Consistently the best 5 Euros one can spend on a given night. I don’t believe the cultural significance and deep satisfaction of a Döner is easily explained. I wish you the best Döner experience when that day comes.
Nestled in a bustling section of Neukölln, neighbored by rows of Middle Eastern sweets shops and Spätis, is Azzam Restaurant; my favorite Middle Eastern restaurant in Berlin.
As low maintenance as it gets, but the staff’s kindness and the sense of community overpowers any “finer” dining experience I’ve had. Azzam, like many businesses that cater to Berlin’s many culturally specific Kiez (neighborhoods), is the embodiment of community and the transportable abilities of food.
Order one or two dishes and you’ll have enough to split between two to three people. If you’re lucky, like my friend and I were, commenting on how good a dish looks will have you walking back to your table with said dish in hand, “a gift for you” from the kind men behind the counter.
Richly flavorful, wonderfully comforting, spiced in a way that makes you forget you’re in Germany — and my favorite — made with an authentic love of a culture I’m newly acquainted with.
Across the street, Azzam Market is a world of its own and while not a restaurant, deserves a visit. A portal to some far away country, or maybe to one that doesn’t exist — a perfectly balanced mixture of Arabic life and culture in Berlin. Grab spices by the kilo from enormous mounds, fresh spreads and Halal meats, local produce, imported specialities, and the most beautifully crafted sweet treats I’ve ever laid eyes on.
YamYam’s Mitte location is packed on an average evening. Rightfully so, as its adorable low tables (or floor-seat options for those with functioning knees), orange atmosphere, and well lettered signage create the most delightful dining aura. More expensive than a hole in the wall, ordering the bean pancake, Bi Bim Bap, traditional Korean sides, tea, and their house made ice cream. really are worth it.
Happy, satiated, and just plain old delicious — YamYam satiated the love for Korean food I discovered when I tried it for the first time. I’m in no rush to find a YamYam rival spot.
If you know me, you’ll have no objection to the distinction between a Cafe and a “food” specific location. Coffee is one thing, but I seek out a cafe for the illusion it brings to my day, the cuteness factor it exudes, and — the baked goods. Maybe to work, maybe to sip coffee, maybe to listen to a podcast, cafes are an entirely different experience, good food is just a positive bonus.
A German “chain”, but a loved one at that. In case you forgot the cinnamon bun intentions, Zeit für Brot brings you back. Translating to “time for bread” in German, this bakery and cafe brings freshly made cinnamon rolls of all kinds, the best cardamom bun I’ve had outside Scandinavia, and loaves upon loaves of fresh German bread. Not to mention other baked goods, sandwiches, and consistently good coffee.
With five (!) locations in the city, I’ve rarely turned down a wonderfully moist, usually enormous, Zimtshnecke for 3 euros.
If you had to model a cafe after me, I’d hope it to look something like The Greens. This cafe, plant-shop hybrid in an alley on the eastern side of the Spree brings the coziest atmosphere possible to an archetypal Berlin day. Warm and full of plants on every surface, The Greens serves great coffee and lunch options, and keeps some spaces laptop-free (which I love despite always coming there with the intentions of productivity).
Its loft feature might be the icing on the cake of this adorably lush space, but nothing beats the rotating selection of plants that accompany you on every visit.
Neukölln’s coziest cafe! The atmosphere in Leuchstoff evokes a neighborly familiarity — welcoming, in progress, and glowingly warm. Chock-full of vintage seats and plywood tables, the main room’s overhanging loft seats customers on a couch only a few feet away from the ceiling. Not for the tall.
Their coffee is some of the best I’ve had in Berlin, and the rich touches of their signature blue grace signs across the cafe, looking wonderfuly quaint in the (rare) winter sunlight. Read a newspaper, work on your laptop, chat with friends on a cramped couch, Leuchstoff makes me yearn for a shorter commute to Neukölln.
Another cozy hit, Cafe Odor makes you feel like you know the owners well after descending its short staircase from street level. Once inside, the Harvard library-esque green lamps, the cozy seats, and the adorable dog perched in the corner place an unrivaled sense of calm over the room.
Along with the best matcha I’ve had in the city, founders Dani and Heo can offer you an assortment of small treats be it rosemary-topped carrot cake, matcha bread, sandwiches. While the two South Korean founders put a sense of distinctly Korean aesthetics into their edible offerings, the cafe’s environment is entirely its own: cozy, sweet, serene.
Whew, consumerism was getting a little worried it would be left out of this list! Worry not, because Berlin’s eclectic, individual, stereotypically grunge, anything-but-German style has to come from somewhere.
Like many cities in Europe — or honestly anywhere except the US — flea markets boast stalls and streets overflowing with treasures of all kinds. Berlin’s flea market scene is astounding, exhausting. Its curated vintage shops offer a refuge from the bustle of markets, but tend to lack their anonymity and charm. Buckle up for bargaining or hum along to the German music agonizingly well dressed teens play in shops.
No household name recognition like its famous counterpart Mauerpark, RAW flea market is its own beast. You could easily spend hours wandering the seemingly endless stalls which mix professional vendors with kids selling their old clothes, the occasional vintage-influencer, and artists. Food is easy to grab too, because you’ll be gone so long hunger is destined to strike.
I’ve snagged a handful of treasures here — some great deals and a few less great, but all trophies of a Sunday activity that makes you feel, well, cool.
Less established than large park fleas, Maybachufer is a street in Kreuzberg along the Spree with a food market that takes place during the weekdays and flea markets on weekends. Another gathering of community where neighborhood residents line the cobblestones with their possessions adjacent to the food stalls and coffee carts.
Nothing beats a 1 Euro bin from a Berliner with copious amounts of tattoos after grabbing a croissant or vegan donut at one of the many and popular nearby cafes.
A blast from the past if I’ve ever seen one, VEB Orange brings East Germany to vivid color with authentic items from the GDR. Clothes, kitchenware, sewing supplies, household items, cards, and almost everything you can think of with color-blocked 70’s patterns is crammed on their shelves. On my favorite street in Berlin, this spot is worth a visit whether you come away with a souvenier or not. The counter-top cat (a real one, not from the GDR) adds to the cuteness of an overly crowded room.
My favorite store in the city, this multi-level art heaven has every creative material I can dream of, and doesn’t help to keep money in my pocket. Walking around with no project on hand is as legitimate as any endeavor, and the adjoining bookshop cafe might extend your visit. Their supplies strike wonder into my heart every time I walk out of the U-Bahn 8 and up their steps.
Just as much of a sight as a shop, the Berlin charity shops of Humana are not few and far between. The one on Frankfurter Tor however, is 5 stories tall. With more floors than you’ll ever need, the shop has got it all.
Alexander Platz’s Humana doesn’t rival in size, but its contents have never let me down — in fact the opposite. While locals frequent Humana, it can be a tad bit pricier than the even more locally-frequented ReSales. Worth a shot if you want to see how much stuff this world really has!
There’s not much to say on Soul & Style except that their 4 locations are full of nicley curated but approachable clothes and accessories. Priced accordingly, you won’t find the same deals as flea markets, but they’re worth a browse if you want cool and unique pieces or have something particular in mind.
I rarely find myself in Berlin’s northern district of Wedding, but one of its truly hidden gems is Bar Henriette. The flat, conjoined walls of the surrounding flats disguise the soft glow from Henriette’s windows as nothing other than a home on a winter night. But when you’re in front of it, the candles emanating from wine bottles and the consistent moody glow draw you immediately in.
Quiet and comfortable, their drinks are affordable, house specials picked with care, and the atmosphere restores years to one’s life that may have been lost in the endurance-sport that is Berlin clubbing. Grab a bottle of wine and you can easily spend hours sinking into their chairs as if it were your own living room.
Cafe by day, bar by night, An Einem Sonntag Im August is well known for good reason. With tiered step-seating, couches, and tables, the interior blends seamlessly from day to night as lights switch off. The cocktails are just as good as the fresh tees and coffee and the bustle all week long does nothing to detract from the intimate feelings wherever you sit. When the weather is warm, outdoor seating and bench swings host you under awnings, giving the best people watching view in Prenzlauer Berg.
Pub culture in Berlin is harder to find than you might think. Real Kneipes are all the better for it. While dive bar culture provides a night of fun in its own right, Shurke’s small space gives you the feel for a Kneipe that I fear may be slipping from Berlin’s landscape.
If there’s no space, move on! But if you find a spot to rest, the air is cloudy, the beer is German, and the energy is classic.
A recent recommendation brought me to Mano unsuccsesfully. Even the slanted hallway with old wooden auditorium seats smashed against the wall was crowded. Next time around we were lucky enough to land a little nook by the window, which required a step up above the lower seating and a pretzel-maneuver to sit comfortably. But the small details in this place from the tree-loft area in the main room to the delicious house cocktails and well worn pillows made this an instant favorite.
There are some aspects of cities that don’t necessarily fill a typical “activity” slot, but end up being the best ways to spend your time. A few of my favorite pastimes, for Sundays when the markets are closed so you can’t (and shouldn’t) do your grocery run; for when it’s raining and cabin fever strikes; or when the weather is grey and something needs to happen.
Airport turned public space, Tempelhofer Feld is my favorite place in Berlin. Rich in history and contemporary activity, Tempelhof information could fill a thesis project.
Go for a run, bike, walk, skate, rollerblade, or wind-sport (yes — an entire green is dedicated to wind sports), and find a community doing the same, usually with music, too! Check out the art mini-golf course or the kids carnival area, read the historical tour plaques, admire the real airplane on display in the center, or walk through the community gardens. Start with a coffee and pastry at a nearby cafe and find a spot to picnic near the bird-breeding grounds, apple tree cultivation, or sheep grazing when it’s the season.
Nothing is so exceptional as this urban oasis, smack dab in the center of Berlin, bordering more than three neighborhoods and connecting a city through recreation.
Off the otherwise unremarkable area of S-Bahnhof Bellevue, Park am Präsidentendreieck is a fantastic place to soak up any rare piece of Berlin sun by the water. Or pick up a paddle at the public ping-pong tables and reignite a competitive fervor only found in Kita playgrounds.
While I continue to note nearly every worthy location I visit in Berlin, I’m haunted by the knowledge that I’ll forever be missing endless experiences in this wide city. Here’s to four more months of exploration!

The spectrum only has two ends. No in between. People hate or love Berlin. The city hosts the most colorful contradictions: Snobby districts, fucked up districts. Start-up career character or totally lost. Techno drug scene, sober yoga class society. Grey in grey or wild nature. Go home with understatement, the city screams. Choose your mix of extremes!
Describing Berlin as a whole is merely feasible. It makes me say ‘anarchy’. Not in a purely chaotic sense. Rather with a tiny sparkle. ✨ I just don’t recognize a concept in Berlin. There is no average reference point. Which is probably the most remarkable thing about the city.
“In Berlin, anti conformance is a default” — my old roomie, who lives there
If you are an outlier in your hometown, you’re gonna feel pretty normal in Berlin. Therefore, outliers are wildly attracted to the city: The city makes non-average the new average. And people are proud of it. “I live in Berlin” is rather a phrase to describe an identity than a residence.
Everything, also the tyniest, most unremarkable part of Berlin seems unique. Even the train sound when arriving at a station was dedicated an anthem to by famous Berlin DJ Paul Kalkbrenner. It’s called Train. As if that would be the most normal thing.
And I love it. 🖤

Title: A Lesbian’s Guide to Berlin: 3 must-visit places (disability friendly)
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
I’ll be honest, when I first got to Berlin, I was underwhelmed. For years, my friends had told me how much I would love it in the German capital — it’s the gay centre of Europe after all. Perhaps my expectations of rainbow bunting hanging from every balcony and LGBTQ+ museums dominating the streets were set a little too high.
I did find some lesbian history in the obvious places; the recognition of the suffering and slaughter endured by homosexuals in war-time Germany is poignant and moving, and the video memorial in Tiergarten is beautiful. Only, in the so-called gay capital of the continent, I expected to find, well… more. I should have taken the title at face value. While there are lots of events, bars and even sections of parks dedicated to the getting together of gay, cisgender men, the scene for women-loving-women and non-binary people (FLINTA* as it’s known in German) is scarce, under-advertised and according to one server I met in a lesbian-owned cafe, “disappearing fast”. The events that do exist for lesbians are almost exclusively weekly club nights. While fun for dancing, drinking and mixing with other FLINTA folk, these events are, at best, a little dull after your 51st Lesbian Tuesday of the year and at worst, are exclusionary to whole sections of the disabled community. I’ve included the club nights I encountered at the bottom of this post, so feel free to skip ahead if that’s more your scene. But the main purpose of this post is to shine a light on the few FLINTA-focused places I, a disabled lesbian, sought out when visiting Berlin.
Hands down, this is the best place to go if you’re looking for a lesbian crowd, without the partying and alcohol. Run by a British/American lesbian couple, Lonely Hearts Cafe is a fusion of both countries’ breakfast staples. Pancakes and fry-ups sit side-by-side on the menu and they have extensive allergen info readily available for my IBS buddies. Coeliacs can also enjoy food here — they were happy to prepare my order on a separate surface and brought out gluten free toast and vegan butter for me to enjoy with my fry-up.
When I walk in, the place is full of eccentrically-dressed people who (call it gaydar) I immediately assume to be queer. I take a seat along a bench under a neon sign that reads Lonely Hearts and from the back of the room, admire the other quirks this restaurant has to offer. It’s a cosy cafe, which mashes together British and American aesthetics so well, from the black and white letterboard for hot drinks, which looks like it might belong in a chippy, to the hand-drawn sign advertising iced tea. The teaspoons are in Marmite jars, the knives and forks in a large Coleman’s mustard tin, but there’s Tabasco in the condiment container. The red wooden benches have you believing you’re in a 50s American diner until you look at the throw pillows, which place you more in a granny-owned cafe in Surrey. My server, Amy, brings me iced water in a jug and I order a pot of Yorkshire Tea and a Full English. The bandana in her hair screams cottagecore lesbian who abandoned home to run off to a European city and set up a café with her wife... which seems to be exactly what happened. After eating, I use the bathroom. Opening the door is a queer cultural experience in itself. The small room I find myself in is decorated floor-to-ceiling with pictures of Dolly Parton. Even the toilet is Dolly-themed. I have to stop and laugh, take pictures and smile at my reflection in the neon-clad mirror. When I go back out to pay, I spend all my pocket change on merchandise — a t-shirt, mug and sticker set — to remember the queerest café I ever did meet.
It’s impossible to tell what this place is from the outside. The blue canopy is like a red herring for heterosexual people to be lured in, suspecting a green grocer’s and then you see the pink signage, graffiti and rainbow doormat and know they’ve got LGBerlin to a T. Inside, Keller Kreuzberg is full to bursting with art, clothing, cards, tarot decks, books, badges and so much more. I’ve never seen so much merchandise dedicated to LGBTQ+ people in one place. The store does a good job at catering to women as well; the kink section in the basement level has a good range of products for all body types and artwork that bares the same diversity. It’s got a furry pink ceiling which is beside the point but cool. I loved the sex-positive merchandise all around. Though the spiciest stuff remains downstairs, the shop isn’t shy about its stance on sex. My favourite items were a keychain that read, ‘it’s vulva not vagina’ and two naked women in a car painted on a coaster. The only thing I was a little disappointed in was a slight lack of lesbian-specific merchandise in the store, though there was some — I found a hat with the lesbian flag and some prints and cards featuring two women. The main focus was on queer-centered merchandise, which I understand from a business perspective sells better to the masses. But the owner of this shop also agreed with the Lonely Hearts team: the lesbian scene in Berlin is slim pickings. They did give me a tip on a good place to spend some time though, so I headed there next.
Lesbian pal of mine, how many times a day do you think about abandoning your desk job to start a female-focused, bookshop-cum-coffee shop? Five times a day? Nine times a day? Just fifteen minutes from Keller Kreuzberg on foot is She Said bookshop, which specialises in queer, literature written by women. And it’s got a café. They did it folks, they really did it. I spent over an hour wandering around here, picking up books in English and in German — partly to test whether or not I could still remember vocabulary from A-level German. (Spoilers, reader: I could not.) The level of diversity across the shelves is what you want from all bookstores, all written by FLINTA on a wide variety of subjects from fiction to memoir to poetry. I ended up walking away with a bundle of titles I hadn’t heard of before and devoured them on my night train to Brussels the next evening. With its cute café serving sandwiches, cakes and hot drinks, you could easily spend an afternoon here browsing the shelves, consuming coffee and queer literature ’til closing time.
Thanks to the wonderful small business owners I spoke to in the places listed above for these recommendations!
Other Nature — “a queer-feminist, sex-positive, eco-friendly and vegan sex shop” specialising in body-safe sex toys, locally-made kink gear, natural lubes and feminine hygiene products (amongst other wonderful things!)
Siegessäule — an online resource dedicated to queer information, events and guides in Berlin.
Schwules Museum — Berlin’s LGBTQ+ museum and art gallery. I did actually visit this museum but it didn’t make my top three purely because of its size. I paid almost the same entrance fee for this museum as I did for entry to Museum Island, and as far as I could see there was just one, small exhibition room. The exhibition itself was fantastic, full of lesbian artwork which I loved and bought prints of, but it would have been nice to see more! The tea in the cafe, however, was some of the best I’ve ever had. Their website states that admission is free on the first Sunday of the month, so I’d advise taking advantage of this when planning your trip.
I didn’t visit one myself but a lesbian friend of mine who lives in Berlin recommended the Tuesday lesbian night at Möbel Olfe — a bar widely known in Berlin for its gay scene. As far as I’m aware, Tuesday seems to be the night for bars and clubs to lesbi-fy, so bear this in mind if you’re planning a party trip!
Notes:
*Meaning “Frauen, Lesben, Intergeschlechtliche, Nichtbinäre, Trans und Agender”. Or in English, “Women, Lesbians, Intersex, Non-binary, Trans and Agenda”.

Title: Berlin: A City Shaped by History, Innovation, and Urban Diversity
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
Share
Berlin has a complex history that has significantly shaped its urban landscape and development. As the capital of Germany, it has experienced monumental shifts over the centuries—transforming from a Prussian capital into a divided city during the Cold War and now into one of Europe’s most dynamic and modern cities. What makes Berlin so captivating is how its infrastructure and urban planning tell the story of a city constantly rebuilding and reinventing itself.
Berlin’s modern identity is rooted in a unique combination of historical events and urban resilience. Initially, Berlin was a modest settlement along the River Spree, but it gradually became a trade center during the Middle Ages. By the 18th century, Berlin had become the capital of Prussia, a major European power, and it underwent significant development under the rule of Frederick the Great. However, it wasn’t until the Industrial Revolution of the 19th century that Berlin truly began to transform into a major European metropolis. Factories, railroads, and grand boulevards like Unter den Linden were constructed, making Berlin a vital economic and cultural hub.

Berlin is a big city. Of course, compared to Beijing, Tokyo, London, or New York, it is not intimidating at all. But still, by German standard, it is pretty huge.
A friend of mine once told me that Berlin is pretty big because its tourist sites are scattered across the city, and they can be far away from one another. Indeed, no tourist would try to walk from The Brandenburg Gate to East Side Gallery since, according to Google Map, it takes around one hour.
Another friend argued that Berlin is big, and that is why it can host so many gigantic things; big streets (e.g. Straße des 17. Juni and Karl-Marx-Allee), large parks (e.g. Tiergarten and Tempelhofer Feld), huge buildings (e.g. Berliner Fernsehturm and Berliner Schloss), just to name a few.

Title: Having a baby in Berlin
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

5
Listen
Share
When you walk into my Friedrichshain apartment, there’s a room labeled “Kinderwagen-Rollstuhle” next to the elevator. On the door, a paper reads:
“Only for strollers. Do not use this room for bikes!”
This was my first inkling that Friedrichshain was a neighborhood for more than hipsters and its club scene.
When I first moved to Berlin in 2019, stroller rooms and family policies were the last thing on my mind. My husband and I moved here to live in a big city, travel across Europe, and start a new adventure. As we stayed longer though, more of our friends started popping out pandemic babies. We soon decided to start our family here as well.
Americans love praising Scandinavian countries' utopian family policies. The NY Times recently touted Finland for giving all new parents the same leave, following Sweden’s example. Bringing up Bebe, which explores the differences between American and French child rearing, has become standard pregnancy reading. Achtung Baby is the German equivalent. I also read these books during pregnancy in my quest to glean child-rearing wisdom.
This post is my version: a personal story about my 22 months of pregnancy, birth, postpartum, and parental leave in Berlin. This isn’t a how-to guide, and I’m not promising to confer any wisdom. But I’d like to show what it’s like to live in a city built with both physical and social infrastructure for families, during one of life’s most tender junctures.
At my first appointment with my Frauenartz (OB/GYN), I received a little book called the Mutterpass (Mother’s pass). All the tests and examinations throughout my pregnancy and birth were recorded in it. Although it may seem archaic to bring a paper booklet with you to every appointment, it actually made a lot of sense in practice. During my pregnancy, I received care from a disparate group of doctors and midwives. Instead of transferring electronic medical records, I simply handed over my Mutterpass at the start of each appointment.
Holistic medicine is more widely accepted in Germany and supported by the medical establishment. Like in the US, I went to routine OB/GYN checkups where I would do a urinanalysis, blood pressure check, weigh-in, periodic blood tests, and consultation at each appointment. I did ultrasounds and genetic testing at predetermined weeks. Unlike the US, I also went to a Hebammenpraxis, a midwife clinic.
One of the downsides I experienced with public health insurance was that my OG/GYN was often overbooked and rushed—sometimes my appointments started one to two hours late. But at the Hebammenpraxis, the midwives took their time. They explained each test in my Mutterpass, making sure I understood each result. They also recommended acupuncture and acupressure for my debilitating first trimester nausea. This was all covered by my public health insurance.
I split the costs of my public health insurance with my employer—I pay around €‎440 per month. This is calculated based on your income level. Health insurance is mandatory for everyone living in Germany. Some people pay for private health insurance if they don’t qualify for public, or want greater control of their providers. See here for more details.
My favorite part of the German medical system is the hebamme, a personal midwife. Hebammen are trained medical professionals that can perform examinations on the mother and the baby. They also guide parents through this huge life transition. In Berlin they work hyper-locally — usually only in one neighborhood. My other mom friends advised me to start looking for a hebamme as soon as my pregnancy was confirmed.
Unfortunately there is a shortage of hebammen in Berlin. To find one, I posted in facebook groups, registered for search websites, visited Hebammenpraxes, and asked friends of friends. Finally, by the end of the first trimester I found my match: Mandy.
Mandy only worked in my zip code, and took a handful of new mothers each month. She visited homes by biking from apartment to apartment — sometimes up to 8–10 homes a day! After our initial meeting at the end of my first trimester, we signed a contract. We didn’t talk for a while, and then around week 35, she came for a few home visits. She checked out my baby room and recommended a few items I might need postpartum. She was also available on call if I thought I was going into labor, and could advise me on when to go to the hospital.
In Berlin, you have a couple of options on where to give birth: a hospital, a Geburtshaus (birthing center), or Hausgeburt (home birth). All options are mostly covered by insurance. In birthing centers, you are attended to by a 1-on-1 midwife in a more “home-like” environment. Doctors are not on-site and there is not the option for epidurals or other drugs. At home, a Beleghebamme (personal birthing midwife) supervises your delivery.
I chose to deliver in a hospital because I wanted the option to have an epidural, and probably because of my American tendencies. I registered at Charité Mitte, a top teaching hospital 20 minutes away, where most doctors and nurses spoke English.
Germans believe that all pregnant women are entitled to not only adequate medical care, but also mental and physical preparations for birth. My public health insurance, Die Techniker, reimbursed me for yoga classes and a Geburtsvorbereitungskurs (birth class). Although most couples take a weekly birth class in their neighborhood, we chose a weekend online course because of COVID. It was also challenging to find one in English.
The German system acknowledges that pregnant mothers not only need a physical break, but also a mental break. They respect the experience of pregnancy and motherhood.
In Germany, your maternal leave starts six weeks before your due date, with the statutory maternity leave, called Mutterschutz. During this time, you receive full pay, and are expected to relax and focus on preparing for the baby. At first I wasn’t sure if I wanted to take that much time off. I felt extreme FOMO — worried that I’d miss out on important moments at work.
However, since I’d be paid the same whether I worked or not, I embraced the German benefits and stopped working. I spent the first few weeks off “nesting” — preparing the baby room, washing and sorting hand-me-down clothes, and stocking our freezer. I also tried to stay active by doing prenatal yoga and going for walks with other moms on leave. One of the benefits of longer maternity leaves is that there is a higher likelihood that your friends are also on leave.
After my due date came and went, I went for daily check-ups and CTG (electronic fetal monitor, EFM) scans at my Frauenartz. Five days after my due date, I had a blood test at the hospital and they decided to have me stay to be induced. While I waited for the induction pills to work, I waited in a separate hospital room in the maternity ward.
German hospitals provide a range of equipment to support vaginal deliveries. Charite’s delivery rooms had specialised equipment such as an exercise ball, birthing stools, ropes attached to the ceiling and walls, and adjustable birthing tables. Some even had a bathtub for water delivery. The midwives embrace moving around and changing positions to help the baby “spin” down the birth canal.
I had the fortune of a quiet delivery ward, which allowed a midwife to accompany me the entire time I was in active labor. Oftentimes in a hospital a midwife splits her time between two or three women. One downside of giving birth in a hospital though is that you may need to change midwives mid-delivery. This happened to me 6 hours in. But in the end, I had a positive experience as I liked the different approach of both midwives. I didn’t see a doctor until the very end, just a few minutes before I delivered my baby boy.
Grant was born after 9 hours of labor.
After birth, I stayed in the hospital for 3 days. This allowed us to have Grant’s U2 appointment at the hospital, which needs to happen between the third and tenth day of life in Germany. Similar to US wellness checkups, Germans have a set of preventive medical check-ups from the first day of birth through adolescence.
We were lucky to get a “family room” after birth, where my husband was able to stay with us in his own bed. We were supported by postpartum midwives 24–7, who were just a button press away. Charite doesn’t have that many family rooms though, so most people need to share a room post delivery. Other families choose to leave the hospital as soon as possible, because their hebamme can also support them at home.
The one downside of staying in the hospital was the German food. This was what I was served for dinner on the first night. Yes, that’s a raw tomato in the corner and a large pickled cucumber in the other.
I had heard the hardest trimester isn’t the 3rd, it’s actually the “4th trimester”, otherwise known as postpartum. I was worried about sleepless nights and how my body would recover. But after reading the book “The First Forty Days,” I learned it could be a magical time if you’re prepared and have a strong support system.
The Germans also have a culture of resting after birth called Wochenbett which literally means “weeks in bed.” The new mother is supposed to stay in bed to recover and focus on skin-on-skin and feeding the new baby.
This is actually quite similar to the Chinese tradition of Zuo Yuezi (坐月子), which literally translates to confinement. During this time, new mothers aren’t supposed to leave the house or touch cold water.
My parents came to Berlin for my Zuo Yuezi, and rented an apartment a block from my apartment. My mom made me warm Chinese soups, didn’t let me touch cold water, and helped take care of Grant. I didn’t leave the house for almost 30 days, which wasn’t that hard for me as it was in the middle of winter.
As I mentioned before, my favorite German benefit is the hebamme. My midwife Mandy came the first day we got home, and visited every day for the first few weeks. Each visit started by weighing Grant, tracking his progress to regaining his birth weight. She also checked and cleaned his umbilical cord stub, and showed us how to bathe him once it fell off.
At the beginning she also supported me in breastfeeding: teaching me different positions, helping wake Grant up mid-feed (his breastfeeding persona was a “dinner dozer” / “rester”), and teaching me how to use the pump (which I only used before my supply came in). This was invaluable, as it prevented common breastfeeding problems like mastitis and nipple pain. If I had any major issues, Mandy could have also referred me to a lactation consultant.
Each day, my husband and I would write down all our questions to review with her. Are his hands too hot or too cold? How should we dress him at night? Should we start vitamin D drops? When will he get over his jetlag? Are we doing tummy time right? Is this a normal amount of spit up? I think she single-handedly prevented us from having postpartum anxiety. :)
She also checked on my health — both physical and mental. She asked about my bleeding, checked my stitches, and examined my abs for diastasis recti. It was such a blessing to get maternal care without having to leave the house with a newborn. Oftentimes, there is so much focus on the baby, not on the mother’s recovery. I didn’t feel this way.
All German employees (people with a German employment contract) are entitled to parental leave. There are two concepts: Elternzeit (parental time off) and Elterngeld (parental allowance / money).
In my circle of friends, most mothers took at least a year off — usually until their child went to Kita. This also lines up with how long women are recommended to breastfeed for, about one year. Babies can start drinking cow’s milk after one year of age. I noticed that most fathers took a few weeks off at the start with the mother, and then some weeks later when the baby is older. Many took it during the summer holiday so the whole family could vacation together.
In a bit of a tangent, I’m going to compare Germany’s policy to Sweden’s. Unlike Sweden’s equality focused policy, Germany doesn’t have a minimum number of days each parent must take. In Sweden, their 90 days of “use-it-or-lose-it” time for fathers incentivizes men to take their full parental leave. Sweden also has an “equality bonus” of 50 kr each per day if you share your parental leave equally. This has led more Swedish men to take more paternal leave than other countries, and even created a “latte pappa” culture.
While I was pregnant, we visited our friends in Sweden with a 1 year old. The couple took the first month off together. The mom then took the next 6 months on her own, and then the father took the next 6 months on his own. Leaving the baby with the father made it easier for my friend to go back to work, and helped them establish a more equal division of household and child rearing. In the US, studies have shown that when a baby arrives, working couples no longer share their housework equally, even when they did before (study). This was a pattern I didn’t want us to fall into.
So what did we do? My husband and I both took the first month off. Then I became the primary caregiver from months 2–10, though my husband took off 6 weeks of vacation throughout that time. He also works from home, and was able to support me during the day when needed. He will become primary caregiver when Grant is 10 months, and plans to take at least 3 months of paternity leave. We chose this split because I wanted to take about one year off of work, and because by the time Grant is 10 months he’ll be breastfeeding less and less dependent on me. I also wanted us to both experience being primary caregiver to develop our own parenting styles and build empathy for each other.
The thing I appreciate the most about this experience, is that I had the privilege of going back to work when I was ready. I took a total of 12 months off — something I never would be able to take, or even thought I’d want, in the US. Some moms are ready to return to work after 3 months, and others at 3 years. I didn’t have to choose between being a “stay-at-home-mom” or a “working mom” when I wasn’t ready. And throughout my leave, even though my day to day was being a full time caregiver, I considered myself a UX designer. This is an important part of my identity.
So what did I do with my time?
Not going back to work allowed me to continue breastfeeding on-demand. I didn’t need to pump, though I used the passive Haaka pump to collect extra milk for bottles.
Women in Berlin breastfeed practically everywhere– restaurants, playground, the Ubahn… No one bats an eye!
Around 6–8 weeks after birth, many German women take a Rückbildungskurs to strengthen their pelvic floor. Pregnancy and childbirth can stress, stretch, and weaken the muscles in your pelvic floor and abdomen, which can cause pain and urinary incontinence. Germans don’t wait for a doctor’s diagnosis. Almost all women sign up for a course after their hebamme clears them. In the class, a physiotherapist walks you through a series of breathing and muscle exercises. This is also covered by health insurance.
This can also be a great way to get out of the house with your baby and meet other new moms in the neighborhood. Unfortunately I was only able to find an English course online.
A few months after birth, a social worker contacted us for a home visit. I had never met a social worker before, and wasn’t sure what to expect. I was pleasantly surprised though! The woman came with a large folder of flyers: lists of pediatricians, local hospitals, family centers, and kitas (day cares). She reassured us that the local town hall could put us on a waitlist for kita (daycare), if we weren’t able to find a spot ourselves. This is a common concern of parents, as kita spots can be notoriously hard to find in Berlin. She also made sure we how to fill out all of the required German paperwork and navigate the bureaucracy.
As Ali Wong said in Hard Knock Wife, “when you’re a new mom on maternity leave it’s like The Walking Dead. You’ve just gotta hook up with a crew to survive.” Neighborhood family centers saved me, and helped me find my survival crew. All around Friedrichshain there are family centers with programming for kids and their parents. Many have free play times and classes such as “baby massage” and “yoga with baby.”
When Grant was around 4 months old, I started going to a “baby time” every Friday. With a facilitator, we went around sharing how each of our weeks went — recounting what’s changed with the baby, and checking in on how we are each doing. We sang some German songs and did some playful activities. It ended with a lovely breakfast and tea. The whole class was donation based.
Although it was tough for me to always understand what was going on in German, I managed to make one good friend from the group. When the class ended, we started going to drop-in “open play times.” Grant loved playing with all the new toys and structures, and I enjoyed some adult socialization. It can be incredibly lonely and isolating to be caring for your baby at home alone all day.
I’m not going to say much about Kita (daycare), because unfortunately we will be leaving Germany before Grant can go to Kita (at one year of age). The most important fact though is that Kita is free. Yes, daycare is free in Berlin. Well, except for a €23 / month lunch fee.
Parents apply for a Kitagutschein voucher that determines the number of hours you qualify for based on their age and the number of hours the parents work. Most kitas don’t take babies under the age of one though. If you’re curious to learn more, this is a great guide.
What?! You’re leaving Berlin? You might be surprised to learn after describing this seeming family utopia, we’ve decided to return to the US — the only rich country without federally mandated paid parental leave.
We miss our family.I had a really hard time the weeks after my parents left Germany when Grant was three months old. My relationship with my parents, and my in-laws, has completely changed since becoming a parent myself. I call my parents almost every day, and can’t imagine having them only see Grant once or twice a year. I think that one of the best things we can do for Grant, and for our sanity, is to surround him with people that love him — which means moving closer to my family in the Bay Area.
We miss our friends.Although it was hard to make many friends during the pandemic, we managed to make a few good friends in the past three years. However, almost all of them have now moved away as many were also expats, and went onto their next location. We know how important friendship is to our happiness, and how lonely and isolating parenting can be. Back in the bay area we have friends we’ve known for 10–20 years, and many of them are now having kids too. We’re actually planning to co-live with a friend I’ve known since birth!
We’re tired of speaking bad German.We had grand plans to learn at least conversational German when we first moved here. We took a month-long intensive course, and then biweekly classes for the first year. But after a year we only made it to A.2, at best. When I got pregnant, I lacked the energy and motivation to continue. In the area we live in, we’re able to use English in our day-to-day encounters, but when we hit bureaucracy, it is all German. And becoming a parent doubled the amount of bureaucracy we’ve hit. I also couldn’t imagine not being able to speak to Grant’s daycare teachers fluently.
We want to continue working with our American employers, but want family friendly hours.My husband and I continued to work for American companies when we moved to Berlin. He stayed with his previous company, and I started at Google Berlin. This meant we worked somewhat shifted hours, usually 10 am to 7 or 8pm, with a healthy midday break. This is not compatible with a baby’s schedule (3pm kita pickup, 5:30pm dinner, 7pm bedtime). From my experience, most Googlers in leadership positions based in Europe take a break to watch their kids, and then go back online from 8–10pm. This is not the lifestyle we want.
We want to establish a permanent home base.To my husband’s dismay, the idea of moving back to the bay and staying there for the rest of our lives terrifies me. I’m not ready to stop our adventures! But I do agree that we’d like to establish a home base and permanent community. Maybe we’ll move to Taiwan or Singapore in 5 years though :)
I’m extremely thankful for my experience from pregnancy to parental leave in Berlin. I know how lucky we are to be able to move here, have our parents stay with us, and work at well paying jobs. We are extremely privileged to get this new perspective on what having a baby can look like. I’ve had friends in the US who had to fight for time off from their employers or beg their doctors to take their pain seriously to get a PT referral. It would have been hard for me to advocate for myself during this tender and vulnerable time.
I am grateful that Germany welcomed us as a temporary residents (we have EU Blue Cards), and allowed me to qualify and pay for public health insurance. I’ve felt supported by the city and healthcare system, with community spaces and services that I didn’t even know I needed.
After 12 months off, I feel ready to return to work, and step aside to let my husband become the primary caregiver. Love you dear! :)
Thank you Owen and Kalvin for the edits, and Alana Range for the lovely photos.
--
--
5
UX designer trying to slow climate change. Currently based in Berlin. www.suelynyu.com
