Title: Captivating Interwar Modernism in Berlin. Part 1
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Street photography about overlooked architecture. Ukraine, Germany, Netherlands, etc.

--
2
Listen
Share
A hundred years ago, Berlin was among the biggest cities in the world as its population rapidly grew from 2 to 4,5 million. Just imagine the demand for new housing at that time! Eventually, the city became a testing ground for architectors’ creativity and social experiments.
Passionate about the ideas of affordable mass housing, modernists were trying to make utopia come true — create cheap, standard, and, if possible, lovely houses. Not to mention, it was also a time of the Nazi’s rise to power. Nowadays, pretty small apartments and compact blocks are concealed by colored plaster, original door patterns, and manicured lawns. I’m sure that living in these houses may feel totally different from the careless meditation of a passerby. We are privileged to observe modernist estates from a distance of decades and draw our own conclusions.
This piece should have started with a bird’s-eye view of the horseshoe-shaped building, but let’s leave it to the birds. City explorers like you and me, not aided by drones or helicopters, see this site differently. When I came, the frost was gleaming on the grass in shadows, and the sun shone gently through a gap between “horseshoe” edges.
The Horseshoe Colony is a complex of townhouses and 3-story blocks of flats, and the central one — as you might have guessed — is curved like a horseshoe. A humble memorial stone at the pond tells this estate was designed by Bruno Taut and built between 1925 and 1933.
I was lucky enough to visit the Horseshoe Colony twice, at dawn and dusk, although it took me an hour to reach Britz, a part of the Neukölln district. As I left the metro, sunlit rosy-and-tartare houses with fiery doors popped up. At first, I was walking past them pretty fast, not realizing they were also part of the architectural ensemble — not just the shaped block.
I didn’t expect such a burst of color either because the whole modernist architecture (and Bauhaus in particular) had always seemed minimalistic and monochrome to me before.
Although this estate appeared as affordable housing for rapidly growing Berlin, it was designed with privacy in mind, thus feeling neither fully urban nor entirely rural. In this densely populated area, you’ll notice a lot of hedged yards with lovely arbors, swings, braziers, beds of flowers, and other attributes of carefree leisure.
The Horseshoe Colony doesn’t look luxurious; however, it gives space for individuality and embodies a passion for detail. I spotted a dozen door variations. My favorite ones are the black-framed ones with colorful rectangles in the middle. You can hardly find the same building color and door pattern combination twice.
But let’s turn back to the horseshoe building for a while. What amazed me the most about it was the optical effect of using sky-blue paint. Loggias look like holes in the building, and you can pretend to see the sky through them. As a result, this pretty massive building doesn’t feel overwhelming.
I noticed something about color that would also be relevant to other housing estates in this article. So, color is probably, the cheapest way to convey style, whereas columns or sculptures require a lot of work and material. It’s remarkable how modernists used the power of color, creating affordable yet original housing.
And the icing on the cake — a crimson wall, which turned out to be just the opposite side of those tartare houses I mentioned at the beginning. The setting sun cast its light on the wall, and the windows and balcony frames got lilac. After all this, I did realize why this settlement gained its status as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
I left the Horseshoe Colony after sunset. Black silhouettes emerged from the gloom but didn’t obstruct the sky view. If you stand on the stairs between the horseshoe edges, you’ll see magnificent scenery — the sun sets behind the building, people switch on the lamps, and this light reflects on the surface of the inner pond.
You can easily spot the White City from afar. Its white minimalist geometry stands out among yellowish houses nearby, and the five-story corner towers, like guardians, stand on both sides of the street, Aroser Allee. This housing estate in the district of Reinickendorf was built in 1928–1931 and turned out to be the last modernist quarter of the Weimar era.
The key role in the White City design belongs to Otto Rudolf Salvisberg. The central structure of this ensemble is like a sea resort hotel hovering above the street. I hate when parked cars spoil the picture, so I squatted in the middle of the boulevard and shot through a hole in the hedge, thus “hiding” the vehicles behind the bushes.
And how can an authentic German building be without a clock on its top?
Look! Another clock on the opposite side of the same building. I adore how classical modernist architects could create a style with the simplest geometric shapes: squares, circles, and rectangles. Although all the buildings generally look uniform, they have numerous unique parts — like these clocks.
Now, the doors. Doors are where modernist architects burst into various color combinations and rectangle compositions. Bright red and blue doors look incredibly vivid on the white facades.
Not to mention gorgeous blue windows along the staircase, an eye-catching stripe of volume on a flat facade.
A couple of paragraphs above, I mentioned so-called “towers,” higher parts of the corner buildings. So, I found five of them: two large towers on both sides of Aroser Allee and three narrow ones at the corner of Emmentaler Straße and Genfer Straße. They create a distinctive border with other buildings and hold the borders of this settlement.
I had visited the White City before chestnuts and poplars started blooming and one more time after trees went green. In spring, there is a short period when the sun is bright enough to make the walls sparkle, but the trees, still leafless, don’t obstruct the view. I was happy to enjoy this contrast between glaring facades and black trunks.
My final unexpected observation was red and blue bands underneath the roofs. On the one side of the street — blue; on the other side — red. Pre-war architects used to leave numerous unobvious details, aesthetic gifts for an attentive urban wanderer. By the way, White City also is UNESCO-protected and part of the Berlin modernism heritage.
Call me old-fashioned, but the number of floors in a residential building should be a one-digit number. For example, five. It seems compact enough and doesn’t turn a house into an ugly “anthill” similar to Soviet-time quarters in East Berlin. I decided to check the Carl Legien Settlement late in the evening, just before sunset.
This housing estate is located a 5-minute walk from the station Prenzlauer Berg in a district of the same name. Like many buildings displayed in this article, it appeared between 1928 and 1930 and was designed by Bruno Taut and Franz Hillinger.
Carl Legien estate is more uniform than, for instance, Horseshoe Colony, but belongs to UNESCO World Heritage, too. Its buildings don’t have varying characteristics like doors or facade colors. What fascinated me the most was the pinkish tint of the walls and, of course, red, yellow, and blue frames. Gazing at them, I immediately recalled paintings by Piet Mondrian.
And again, we observe the same simplicity and minimal expressive means — no columns, no sculptures, no molding. Rounded balconies and loggias are all facing the inner yard, and I guess it must create a feeling of privacy and own space for the dwellers.
Not many buildings in Berlin have bare brick facades. Brick is typical for factories and warehouses, but most residential estates are plastered and painted in pastel colors. However, the UNESCO World Heritage complex at Shiller Park stands out; the exposed concrete grid of balconies and ochre walls immediately drew my attention. It was designed by our good old friend Bruno Taut and constructed in 1924–1930.
I noticed a bright green car on the street between the historic houses and decided to look closer. Like the settlement itself, the car turned out to be also vintage. Citroën 2CV was a popular economy vehicle in the 1950s, and it fitted in here so well. The phrase on the car, “I fly bleifrei,” is a pun. In German, “bleifrei” means “lead-free” or “unleaded” (without added tetraethyl lead), which is a characteristic of petrol or paint. This motto and a cute duck mascot made me smile.
I noticed the streets where this estate stood were named after English cities — Bristolstraße, Dubliner Straße, Oxforer Straße, and Windsorer Straße. Later I understood why — in Google Maps, this area was called the English Quarter. Except for the car and street names, there were some other beautiful details, like a white doily in one of the windows.
The way how I instantly spot historically significant buildings in Berlin is by well-preserved wooden doors and windows. Look at these bold red frames. If the door is original, not a later replacement, the paint must have been scratched off and carefully repainted a dozen times. Paint sagging and overshooting on the glass look so heartwarming and naive when you can visualize the story behind it.
At the end of that walk, I was thinking about the balconies, which were half-glazed and half-opened. Large windows with white “skeletons” created the impression of porches. Maybe this is why so many local dwellers have beds of flowers, sun umbrellas, and chairs on their balconies. It’s a blessing when your home has a special place to meditate, sipping coffee to the sounds of birds’ songs.
It’s getting more challenging to impress you with Berlin modernism, but I’ll try. The ace up my sleeve is this lovely settlement on the southeastern outskirts of Berlin. It was built a bit earlier than most estates introduced here, in 1913–1916, and the design belongs to — surprise! — Bruno Taut.
While walking and taking pictures, I felt uncomfortable — like an obnoxious intruder or a guy chewing popcorn and slurping beer at the museum. Fortunately, there is little chance you disturb someone at 6 a.m. on Saturday because people (except for me though) prefer to bask in bed a bit longer. But my weird pleasure is to stay one-on-one with architecture and avoid city dwellers casting suspicious glances at me.
This settlement is probably the richest in styles and colors and feels specially designed for vacationing. Not surprisingly, it’s called “Gartenstadt” (garden city) in German and belongs to UNESCO World Heritage.
All the buildings have two or three floors, bright wooden shutters, and terraces. Even though most houses are arranged in blocks, they don’t feel like dull clones.
On some doors, I saw eye-shaped stickers with a silhouette of a thief and a phrase in German, “Neighbours are watching.” I don’t know about you, folks, but to me, this is a typical village security system when people notice more than any video surveillance from highly urbanized districts.
So far, the “garden city” was primarily painted in warm colors: orange, red, and yellow; however, it has a winter-cold section, too. If I happened to choose my favorite building here, I’d choose this stunning blue villa. The tree, in the shade of which it stands, seems to be at least a century old, planted at the times of settlement construction.
Sorry, I cannot overcome a desire to show you the lovely doors of Falkenberg once again in detail. See how carefully a trellis (this white frame for supporting climbing plants) is covered with a sheet of glass. Residents’ needs might have changed over time, but they didn’t spoil the initial design with a massive overhang. And the red door below, besides being amazingly beautiful, has a sticker I’ve already told you about.
Did you think there was just one blue house in the garden city of Falkenberg? Here is another one. You can compare how differently the same tone looks in the sun and after the sunset. In the light, it is glossy, and in the gloom, it gets matte and soft like a gouache drawing.
It was pretty late when I headed back to the station, yet I couldn’t miss an opportunity to take one more picture. What a combination of a cold-blue sky and pavement and orange-warm lights and a bush.
I’m not overwhelming you with historical facts from Wikipedia, so you should have some energy left to cope with the last chapter. This so-called “Waldsiedlung” (forest settlement) is located in one of the most picturesque districts of Berlin, Zehlendorf. You cannot take a single photo here without capturing at least one pine.
All the previous modernist settlements were located 5–10 minutes from the nearest train stations, but this one surrounds the station with an unusual name, “Uncle Tom’s Hut.” These beautiful 2–3-story blocks of flats and townhouses were finished between 1926 and 1931. Could it happen without Bruno Taut? Of course, no, folks. And Taut was accompanied by fellow architects Hugo Häring and Otto Rudolf Salvisber, whom I mentioned many times in this and previous articles.
Onkel Toms Hütte, unfortunately, hasn’t been (yet?) honored with the status of UNESCO World Heritage and remains the only settlement in this article without this status. However, it doesn’t mean city authorities neglect its preservation. All the buildings look well-maintained and don’t have noticeable stains on their bright facades.
In childhood, my granny dressed me in not-so-new grey and brown stuff because she knew I’d be dirty by the end of the day. A residential building is something people “use” very often, and why the hell do you make it so bright? I admire the courage of architects who cared about the dwellers’ moods, too. It is much more pleasant to live in a place that also pleases your eyes than just a practical and robust apartment!
My poor German skills, though, were sufficient to interpret gorgeous letters on the building below. It must have been a hairdresser’s workplace, but now it looks unoccupied by any business.
The shadows were growing higher and getting longer. Time to return home and view all the photos taken that day…
The second part →

Title: Elite Bakery in Berlin: Albatross and Slow Food Philosophy
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Right before Christmas, I had a wonderful chat with the Italian pastry chef Riccardo about baking, gastronomy, and quality over quantity food philosophy.
Navigating past two Turkish kiosks, an abandoned Uzbek restaurant, and a vibrant Argentinian empanada eatery, I finally reached the acclaimed Albatross Bakery on a rainy December afternoon. Culture fusion continued as I could see a fridge full of Italian sausages and cheeses along with organic German eggs from the outskirts of Berlin right beside a display proudly showcasing Panettones and German mulled wine. This imagery of flavours gives a snippet into the multicultural essence of Berlin; through food, you can journey through its history, learn and experience different communities that call this free-spirited city home.
Walking into the snug space of this Kreuzberg gem, the rich aroma of espresso notes hit my nose right away. Good coffee is not the main star here, though very important to accompany the praised Queen B pastry or a phenomenal and totally unexpected crem brulee croissant. Everything I tried was bursting with flavour and I didn’t even get to breads yet.
Pastry sizes are generously big here, and most would be happy about it. My partner had a different opinion, which I contemplated and eventually agreed with. The issue with regular pastry sizes in highly rated and ‘viral’ bakeries is that you want to try bits and pieces of each of them and not get stuffed. Has anyone ever considered mini-bite-sized pastries? The ones you get at the hotel breakfast buffet?!
One of the skilled Italian pastry chefs welcomed me warmly and showed me around as I introduced myself and my obsession with local bakeries. Riccardo proudly said that almost 90% of the produce in the bakery is organic and most come from Germany. Germans are real appreciators of bread and sourcing local ingredients is surely important for the younger generation, especially in a progressive city like Berlin.
Almond Croissant
Almond Croissant is a classic for me. The key is not to oversweeten it and make the almond paste flavour shine. Albatross made it work for my taste. The croissant was soft and not too crunchy on top. Sometimes I feel like bakeries overbake them until the hard biscuit-like texture forms on top, which I am not a fan of. If you feel like almond, marzipan and a soft pleasantly sweet buttery croissant — I’d say you’ve got some of the best in Berlin Almond Croissants here at Albatross Bakery.
Crem Brulee Croissant
I wasn’t the fan of a cronut — a well-known attempt to marry two unrelated in my humble opinion pastries. But it turned out to be surprisingly scrumptious. Not an overly sweet and well-balanced creation. I just love seeing such creative combinations of two fantastic on-its-own desserts It’s an act of courage. I recently saw a combo of cheesecake + baklava and I am still thinking about it. It can go either wrong or oddly good. This was the latter and I would certainly come back for more.
Queen B
This one I saw raving reviews about and had to test it. It was good. Really good. For the crunchy pastry fans especially. Unless you consider it cookie then. The pastry is quite well-baked and not much softness left inside. It was more like a combo of a buttery flaky caramelised cookie and a pastry. It was salty on top with sea salt flakes enhancing the caramel flavour. I loved the combination of flavours and would highly recommend trying it. For my preference, I do enjoy a variety of textures in a pastry and this one had the crunch dominating the entire experience.
Brownie
If you like your brownies fudgy and not spongy, this one is for you. It was like eating a fudge yummy candy. It is accidentally gluten-free as they use a tiny bit of starch instead of flour to attain the gooey texture.
Panettone
I am sure I wasn’t the only one attacked by panettone videos this year. I was curious to understand what is so special about panettone and maybe replace the usual “kučiukai” we eat during Christmas in Lithuania with the proud Italian sweet brioche.
What’s special about panettone?
Panettone is a rich and flavourful sweet brioche usually made from first class flour, egg yolks, lots of butter & raisins. Quality ingredients is the key here, no shortcuts. The one I tested had Sicilian mandarines and extra dark chocolate on top.
Italians also have Pandoro, which is kind of a brother of panettone. It is a bit more plain in flavour, without a filling inside.
For the artisanal panettone, stiff Italian sourdough is usually used, which requires much more skill and time than traditional bread sourdough. The long fermentation process, special skill required and top-quality ingredients are what make a price difference.
The best tip from an Italian pastry chef was to make sure you heat your panettone for a little bit so it becomes more fragrant and soft.
I picked one up and my family ended up with three different panettones this year. It was so soft and fluffy that we ate it easily on its own. I had some recipes in mind on how to use up ‘old’ panettone (french toasting it or whipping up mascarpone as a spread). Safe to say that no ‘old’ panettone was left in our house. And I am already thinking about the flavour I want to try next year, which is a pistachio-filled one.
Albatross Bakery also has a Pistachio Croissant that I didn’t try and a rotating Seasonal Danish that changes every few months depending on the local ingredients.
Have a flaky weekend and a buttery Monday:)

Title: Believing the Unbelievable: Berlin at 80
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I was in Berlin, Germany, on May 8th; the 80th anniversary of the day that German forces surrendered unconditionally to the Allies, marking the end of WW2 in Europe. This day is sometimes referred to as “VE Day” (Victory in Europe Day). What a fitting place to be for this momentous occasion.
I have been in Berlin twice before. My first visit, in the summer of 1963 when I was 15 years old, was as part of a “teen tour” of Europe. Asleep in a Berlin hotel, I was awakened by gunfire. The construction of the Berlin Wall (at first, a barbed wire fence) began in August 1961 and in the years following, many people were shot as they tried to escape from East into West Berlin.
My second visit was 24 years ago, as part of a small group from the US Holocaust Memorial Museum, visiting historic sites in Eastern Europe that included memorials, museums, and several concentration camps. Sachsenhausen, one such camp near Berlin, is in the village of Oranienburg. It began as a slave labor camp for “political prisoners” with many subcamps. Still visible are barracks and the ruins of buildings in which remain the remnants of a gas chamber, medical experimentation areas, torture and killing areas, and several crematoria. Prisoners were treated inhumanely, inadequately fed, and openly killed. If you are reading this article, you probably know the list of who would be considered enemies of the state. A partial list includes those against the Reich whether they were Christian, Protestant, Jewish, Coptic, Roma, Communists, Gays, and anyone who was perceived to be mentally or physically disabled. This camp, not unlike others, was not on the outskirts of town. It was in the town. An alleyway separates the town from the gates to the camp with the words “Arbeit Macht Frei” (Works Sets You Free) welded into the gate. This place was not hidden. Quite the contrary, it was wide open to view and more importantly to odor. With several crematoria where bodies were burned, the smell and the ash wafted over the town, falling onto people’s rose gardens as well as onto the town residents themselves.
But I digress. Twenty four years ago, when I visited this camp, there was a person with us who, as a young man, had been a prisoner in Sachsenhausen. Somehow, miraculously, he survived. A Christian man, he had been a journalist, soon to be married, but that did not happen. It was a privilege to see the camp through his eyes, and listen as he recounted his experiences, some of which he had thought he buried along with his fellow inmates.
This was a sacred place whose stories were told to keep alive the memory of those who perished and those who survived. For decades after the war ended, “Never Again” was repeated to ensure that this kind of unleashed hatred and vitriol, resulting in these sorts of inhuman actions, would never happen again. And most of us in the world were confident that nothing like this could ever happen again!
This visit was different.
First, I am different. I am 24 years older. What I try to convince myself of is “unbelievable.” I need to believe.
Second, the world is different. Hatred, vitriol, and cruelty have become normalized. The vile antisemitic tropes that were used to degrade and denigrate people are not only ripe, but they are blossoming. Regrettably, in many places, they are in full bloom. This kind of hate flourishes on the dark web, and in the full light of day. Repulsive speech and actions have become acceptable. Throughout the world we see the rise of political parties with slogans reminiscent of a world which we thought could never be resurrected. And not only is it resurrected, but these parties have also gained representation in congresses and parliaments in the same countries where brave citizens sacrificed and fought against this to make the world safe for all.
Third, the camp is not the same. Shockingly, there are some people who visit the camp, stand next to the crematory ruins, on the rim of the entrance of the first experiment for a gas chamber, beside the remains of a barracks, who say: “this did not happen.” When you tell a lie often enough, people tend to believe it. That’s what happened prior to and during World War II. And in many parts of our world, it is happening now.
I am at a time in my life when more people than not ask me “When are you going to retire?” Here’s my response. Not only am I not going to retire, I am also committing to rededicate myself to engaging in education programs and social justice issues concerning basic human rights related to antisemitism and anti-LGBTQ hatred. All in, in my “golden years” I will not stand by and silently witness the normalization of hatred.
I write this article with both a heavy and a hopeful heart. When I say things are unbelievable, I reinforce in my own mind that I shouldn’t believe them. I am awake to the reality and the knowledge that I must believe what I see, hear, and witness. When I believe it, I will be able to address it in ways that, hopefully, will change where we are, and where we can go as a civil society.
We can choose hate, or we can choose to stand up to hate. We can be silent, or we can call people out when they say or do things that are rooted in prejudice and hate. Each of us can use our voice and our platform for good. We can choose to make excuses for bad behavior, or we can call it out. We can acquaint ourselves with history. We can familiarize ourselves with the consequences when hate is permitted to run amok. We can call out when we see lies presented as truth. And we can challenge people who are fearful or intimidated into saying and behaving in ways that are unacceptable.
When we sit by as people are being dehumanized, referred to as the “other,” we are at the entrance to the gates of Hell. I went through those gates as a tourist. I’ve listened to and read testimonies, seen films and photographs of what Hell looks like. If we consider ourselves members of the human race, we need to take that membership seriously and be aware of what it means to be human. To have hope in the future we need to discover compassion within and speak out against antisemitism and all forms of hate. We cannot excuse the inexcusable and we must believe the unbelievable.
In life’s most challenging moments, how we respond influences both our immediate wellbeing and long-term recovery. Crises arrive uninvited, testing our resilience when we feel most vulnerable. The following tips offer guidance through the turbulence, toward steadier ground.
Remain Calm: When crisis emerges, take a gentle body scan — notice your breathing, pulse, and physical sensations. Do not judge, just observe. Then begin to breathe and focus on your breath. The key is to avoid panic. When we panic, we cannot solve problems effectively. The goal is to think clearly while being aware of what is happening in your body. During this process, pause, take more slow, deep breaths. For some people, repeating prayers that offer solace, doing mindful practice, mindfulness, or engaging playfully with a pet can help.
Assess The Situation: From this centered state notice where you are physically, mentally, and emotionally. Then, identify the elements defining the crisis. What risks exist? What consequences might follow different actions? This assessment doesn’t require perfect information — only honest recognition of what is known and unknown in this moment.
Create Safety: Do what you need to get out of harm’s way. Look around, listen attentively, and notice your surroundings with fresh eyes. Take actions that move you toward greater security, extending this same protective attention to others if they’re with you.
Gather Your Support Circle: Reach out to those whose compassion brings calm — trusted friends, family members, professionals, or others who have walked similar paths. Seek those who offer the support you need rather than imposing what they believe you should want. Throughout the situation, maintain connection with beloved others. Consider engaging in creative activities that redirect mental energy — photography, gardening, music, reading, or writing — offering your mind the opportunity to “reset.”
Communicate with Transparency: Share information others need to hear to assist you, especially during medical emergencies when providers need accurate knowledge of your condition to offer effective care with minimal risk. Honest communication about symptoms, relevant medical history, concerns, and needs, creates the foundation for receiving proper assistance.
Create a Crisis Plan: Consider creating a simple emergency kit kept in your vehicle or near an exit. Maintain accessible records of essential medications, identification, and emergency contacts — both digitally and physically. Identify people who might assist with temporary housing, caregiving, pet-care, or other practical needs that could arise.
Honor Your Fundamental Needs: In crisis, the basics become precious: adequate rest, nourishment, hydration, and moments of quiet. Reflect on what essentials you require and consider how to ensure access to these necessities even during disruption. Tending to these fundamental needs becomes an act of self-compassion during challenging times.
Remember that getting through times of crisis times isn’t about handling everything perfectly. It’s about showing up as best we can, being kind to ourselves, and figuring things out as we go. Sometimes the hardest moments teach us what we’re made of and connect us more deeply to what matters. We might surprise ourselves with what we can handle, even when it feels impossible at first.
I’ve co-authored a book about kindness. I believe deeply in the lasting effects of love. It is in that context that I share my own daily habit. Each morning, I say thank you for another day and ask for an opportunity to make a difference in this world.
To that end, I look for signs of connection to those who came before me — a robin reminds me that my father is near, a butterfly reminds me of my mother. I feel their presence and listen for their guidance. Certain songs transport me to moments in my past, conjuring places, people, and, sometimes, lessons learned.
This daily habit provides continuity to my life. I’m grateful that my journey has been a healthy one so far. Though everything is unpredictable, I express gratitude however I can and move through the world appreciating all the companions I’ve known along the way.
Dr. Dale Atkinsdale@drdaleatkins.comwww.drdaleatkins.com

Title: How the Most Famous Street Food in Berlin Arrived From England (and the U.S. and India)
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Currywurst is available on practically every block in Berlin. But, this seemingly quintessential German food only dates to the Allied occupation of the city.
With a name like Currywurst, you’d think this was a traditional German dish. But, it’s not. Unlike other Wursts, (Bratwurst, Knackwurst, Liverwurst) Currywurst is a recent addition to the cuisine of Germany.
After World War II, Germany lay in ruins. Berlin was divvied up into sections, occupied by the victorious Russian, American, French, and British armies.
Herta Heuwer, a local Berliner, was selling food from a kiosk in West Berlin to the hungry construction workers who were rebuilding the city. She noticed the British soldiers carrying around items like curry powder and Worcestershire sauce. Curry powder’s popularity, of course, came from the British occupation of India.
American soldiers were partial to ketchup (an American invention) as a condiment.
So, Ms. Heuwer began experimenting. She hit upon the idea of mixing ketchup, Curry powder, and Worcestershire sauce which she used to top sausages. She called her sauce Chillip and the product took off!
Today, it seems like there are Currywurst stands on every block in Berlin. An order of Currywurst and fries is cheap, fast, and filling, so you’ll see lines of hungry office workers at Currywurst stands all over Berlin during lunch hour. And, drunken revelers will get their fix after the bars and clubs close. In fact, Currywurst is so popular that a plaque was placed at the corner of Kant and Kaiser Friedrich Streets to commemorate where Herta Heuwer’s food stall was located decades ago.
If you want to try Currywurst for yourself, it’s not hard to find. My favorite place is Curry at the Wall. It’s a few blocks from Checkpoint Charlie and the vegetarian Currywurst is terrific.
Curry 61 is also very good, but their main attraction is the hilarious and kitschy mural featuring Cold War era politicians. Ten kilometers south of the Berlin’s center is Krasselt’s Imbiss, where you’ll get an excellent Currywurst topped with homemade sauce (a secret recipe!). Since the location is away from the tourist areas of Berlin, you’ll be dining with locals. Still, expect lines, especially at lunchtime.
Originally published at https://destinationeatdrink.com on February 7, 2020.
About the Author
Brent Petersen is the Editor in Chief at Destination Eat Drink, the travel website and podcast for foodies. He has also written the novel Truffle Hunt (Eckhartz Press) and short story collection That Bird.

Title: Week 1: Berlin
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Traveling from Europe to Asia. Will he make it? Find out next week.

--
2
Listen
Share
Everyone I know who visited Berlin came back saying the same thing:
“Berlin is a magical city.”
They weren’t lying. It’s hard to capture the essence of this place with just a few words, but there’s something really special happening here. Every block is teeming with energy and creativity. Walls are plastered with interesting graffiti and residential balconies are bursting with floral arrangements. Sidewalks are wide enough to accommodate outdoor seating for cafes and restaurants, pedestrians, and bikes all at once, and the streets are bustling with people at all hours.
The cultural atmosphere feels leisurely and less profit-driven, and people seem to be actively enjoying living and working in their city. There’s a sense of civic harmony here I haven’t experienced anywhere else. Most importantly, beer is suuuper cheap, sometimes cheaper than bottled water. It’s also legal to drink in public which makes it tempting to buy a drink for the road (any road). I was afraid I’d bankrupt myself on booze if I stayed any longer.
My German experience began before my plane touched down. The stewardesses on my flight were dressed like beer maidens and handing out free schnitzel and brews for Oktoberfest. A yodeling contest was held at the front of the plane moments later. I arrived in Berlin around 10pm and took a train to my hostel.
I spent the first half of the week touring the city together with some floor-mates from the U.K. We wandered Berlin’s deceptively large streets and hopping on and off public transportation (which had a pretty high learning curve) to visit public squares, churches, and landmarks. Luckily for me, my hostel-mates had a local friend who showed us some fantastic spots, like a rooftop bar called the Klunker Kranich that sat atop a seven-story parking structure and overlooked the city. The most memorable was a mind-blowing place night club called Sisyphos. Here’s my journal entry if you’ve got some time to kill.
On the days I wandered by myself, I joined random walking tours, ate at an African food collective that helped re-integrate refugees into Germany, and went to a bar where all the furniture was upside-down and attached to the ceiling. I visited the Holocaust Memorial at sundown and walked in silence between the large concrete blocks, thinking about the United States and the path we’re headed towards if we don’t remain proactive and vigilant of our bubbling fascism.
I walked around Templehoff Regional Park, an abandoned airfield with old hangars and dilapidated planes. It was a bit surreal seeing kids riding bikes and flying kites on airstrips where bombers used to take off. I strolled through Tiergarten, Berlin’s central park, on my last day. It was raining on and off, but when the sun finally came through, the trees shimmered like verdant jewels.
On my last night, I met up with five other travelers through the Couchsurfing app and we drank late into the morning, (which made for a very rough trek to the bus station a few hours later).
One week doesn’t feel like enough time to do Berlin justice, but I guess that gives me a reason to come back. I’ve got the rest of the world ahead of me and it felt like the right time to get going. I still feel a bit timid whenever I enter a new hostel or restaurant, especially when I can’t speak the language, but I’m slowing getting more comfortable with the discomfort. Getting by in a multi-cultural city like Berlin wasn’t too difficult, but I know the language barrier will only become more challenging as I travel east. At least I’ve got time to ease myself into it. My phone has been an invaluable companion, allowing me to book tickets and hostels in the same sitting and save maps for offline use. I purchased my first international SIM card today, but all of the instructions are in German. So I’ll have to figure that out at some point.
I’m writing you from a hostel in Dresden now, where I’ll be staying for at least the next few days. I’m waking up early tomorrow to visit one of Germany’s national parks. I’ve been craving some nature after being immersed in such rich urban environments for the past few days.
Thanks for taking the time to read this. I’ll be trying to post weekly, so shoot me a message if there’s something in these you’d like to hear/see more or less of in the future. Any feedback is deeply appreciated.
Until next time!

Title: How to have the perfect lunch: Sweden’s Daniel Berlin Krog
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
Share
It’s not simply a restaurant, it’s an experience. You’ll find it in Sweden’s agricultural heartland, about an hour from Copenhagen’s airport. Daniel Berlin Krog, a dining experience worthy of 2 Michelin stars.
To call it a restaurant doesn’t do justice to the careful preparation and exquisite presentation of locally sourced ingredients in the hands of a team who respect the palate’s power to delight, nurture, comfort and celebrate.
Paired with 5 wines hailing from France, Germany, and Spain — from dry whites to a sweeter varietal that foreshadowed the close of the meal — the lunch tasting menu was a taste bud explosion.
I was lucky enough to enjoy the experience on a brilliant autumn afternoon. Read this and you’ll be planning a visit, I promise.
Nestled in the hamlet of Skåne-Tranås, in an unassuming farmhouse with an ample farm garden in the back, luncheon guests are greeted with a glass of champagne to start. Because, well, why not.

Title: Quirky, Grungy, Cool: Berlin
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

This publication is dedicated to learning about the world around us. The topics covered here range from travel and geography to languages and cultures.

--
1
Listen
Share
One day I found myself on a flight to Berlin, Germany. Berlin didn’t even rank within the top ten places to visit on my list but I had to go for work, so why not enjoy this obligatory adventure? I had heard that Berlin was moody and grungy, like the emo child of Europe except it’s not “just a phase”. I was prepared to be met with a lot of punk rock and broody, techno vibes but (as is custom when traveling) I discovered the unexpected.
I landed in the mid evening in Berlin and my colleagues and I were starving and excited to sample Berlin cuisine. Three of us were American and were humbly disappointed that many restaurants nearby were already closed — how inconvenient! It’s usually good to be humbled like this as an American abroad, it definitely enriches one’s character. We did manage to find — what else —but a McDonalds. At this moment, I was less than dazzled by Berlin’s seemingly inaccessible evening meal options but figured it could only get better from here.
In the days that followed, I found Berlin to be a fascinating albeit (at times) icy, bustling city of natives, expats and tourists with cool modern buildings and large boulevards. While the overtone of German austerity, order and efficiency was undeniable, there were surprising pockets of whimsy mixed in here and there.
My personal favorite site was the Brandenburg Gate. A stunning piece of architecture with a lot of history and easily one of the most recognizable landmarks of Berlin.
I also visited Checkpoint Charlie, which was historically the Berlin Wall crossing point. This was a quirky museum overflowing with objects large and small, significant to a major turning point in German history. Not too far from the Brandenburg Gate was the beautiful, lush state park called the Tiergarten. Dense with trees, I would describe the Tiergarten as “Central Park with European elegance” — definitely another favorite location.
While Berlin certainly had highlights of grunge, some parts were charming and even rather quirky with fun thrift stores, local farmer’s markets and the unexpected hipster-style cafe.
Before traveling to Berlin, I was looking forward to sampling famous local fare (currywurst and sauerkraut of course) but Berlin also had much to offer in terms of international cuisine, with a lot of Turkish influences. I made it a priority to sample at least one döner kebab (something I would describe as a cross between shawarma and a sub sandwich) and it did not disappoint. To date, one of the best breakfasts of my life (avocado toast, covered in sautéed mushrooms over thick, fresh bread) was at a highly aesthetic cafe called Kaffee Karamell Berlin. And when I finally got my fork into some local sauerkraut, I knew that I was ruined for any canned, store-bought variety…forever. At the end of my trip I discovered that Berlin was certainly more complex than I had originally imagined. Quirky, grungy, cool, refined, steeped in history yet unapologetically modern, a bit edgy with it’s soft sides as well. Snag your ticket to Berlin and see for yourself!

Title: Berlin’s Ghost Stations
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I’ve been fascinated by the subway all my life. Maybe it’s the fact that there’s nothing outside the windows; that when sitting in a subway carriage one has no other choice than to focus on the other passengers – how they look, what they’re doing, what they’re reading – or, god forbid, oneself.
There’s also that unique feeling of descending into the bowels of a city and being propelled from one brightly-lit station to the next through dark, mysterious tunnels.
In Berlin, there is the additional sensation of stepping out of the present and directly into subterranean history, since the city’s U-Bahn and S-Bahn were both complicit in transporting border traffic between West Germany and the GDR.
The fact that the city was divided along apparently randomly-drawn borders meant that some of the U-Bahn lines from West Berlin actually travelled beneath East Berlin, though passengers were not able to leave the train until it reached West Berlin again. The stations those trains passed soon became known as ‘ghost stations’ amongst Berliners – dimly lit stops where armed East German border guards would peer at passengers through slits in bricked up huts.
Due to the geography of the boroughs of Wedding in the West and Mitte in the East, the U6 had, after the U8, the second highest number of ghost stations, namely the five stations from Schwartzkopfstraße to Stadtmitte. On a cold March day in a still snow-covered Berlin, I decided to ride the U6 to Friedrichstrasse. I wanted to get a feel for what the underground city may have looked and felt like during those Cold War days, and to simulate a journey from West to East, if only in my head.
I start right at the beginning of the U6, at Alt-Tegel, which opened as ‘Tegel’ station in 1958 as part of a northern extension of the U6, which had existed since 1923 as the North-South Line between Seestrasse and Tempelhof. In 1992, the station was renamed Alt-Tegel (Old Tegel). As it’s the end of the line, it comprises eight exits, and is an important feeder in summer for people visiting the nearby Tegeler See to explore its pleasure boats and beaches.
On this cold, winter day though, the area reminds me of the small, boring town in West Germany I grew up in: all 1980s plastic and concrete with sharp edges, a Commerzbank, and a C&A next to a café full of huddled, grey-haired pensioners.
GDR U-Bahn and S-Bahn. West Berlin does not exist on this map.
Borsigwerke, Holzhauser Straße, Otisstraße and Scharnweberstraße are the next stops on the line, and also part of the 1958-extension.
Due to the very high water table, the track was raised onto an embankment, meaning passengers can view the quintessential urban scenery: business parks, small estates, grey and brown houses from the 80s.
The only excitement for me is at Scharnweberstrasse, where one can see glimpses of the planes rolling along the runway of Tegel Airport.
Speaking of planes: Kurt-Schumacher-Platz must be the best place in Berlin for plane spotting. There’s something genuinely appealing about standing at the bus stop near the kebab stands and Chinese restaurants and watching the planes roar just 50 metres over your hand on their final approach to Tegel airport.
The locals, long used to the noise and the sight of planes with the landing gear extended, continue strolling and feeding the pidgeons without blinking. For visitors like me, it’s hard not to imagine the plane careening into the bus stop rather than the runway behind it.
From Kurt-Schumacher-Platz, the U-Bahn runs underground again, traveling through “wild” Wedding (formerly in the French occupation sector) along Afrikanische Straße (with the nearby Centre Culturel Français and its very own Eiffel Tower replica), Rehberge (the best stop to explore the Siedlung Schillerpark, a modernist housing estate and UNESCO World Heritage site), Seestraße and Leopoldplatz — a.k.a. the heart of Wedding, with its Brutalist town hall, Schinkel-designed church — and to Reinickendorfer Straße, the former ‘last stop in Berlin West’.
From 1961 on, when the wall was erected, trains from Reinickendorfer Strasse did not stop until Friedrichstrasse.The line was then called the C-line, and its trains would pass under the border and through Schwartzkopfstraße then Stadion der Weltjugend, Naturkundenmuseum then Nordbahnhof and Oranienburger Tor at a snail’s pace.
All the station exits were bricked up, and armed border guards or police patrolled the platforms vigilantly. There was barbed wire beneath the platform edge to prevent fugitives from crawling along the tracks, and even the emergency exists were blocked: the only way to leave when a train broke down was to walk along the tracks to the nearest western station.
On the surface, all references to these stations were removed; the GDR did not want to remind its citizens that there were trains rumbling in and out of the capitalist West right beneath their feet.
Naturkundemuseum, decorated in cheerful yellows. Image by Kate Seabrook.
Today, nothing reminds passengers that these stations, now cheerfully painted in yellows and greens, had once been in another country – except maybe a vaguely claustrophobic atmosphere.
The stations seem smaller and more crowded than the ones further up the line, but that could admittedly be my imagination. The atmosphere doesn’t seem to affect the school classes alighting at Naturkundemuseum, nor the noisy group of Spanish tourists entering the carriage at Oranienburger Tor for the short hop to Friedrichstrasse.
Bahnhof Friedrichstrasse is one of the most important stations in Berlin history. Different to the other GDR ghost stations, it was transformed from a former central station for subway, commuter and regional trains into a major border crossing, and became a bottleneck where people from the capitalist west and from the workers’ and peasants’ state passed each other unseen.
The station’s facilities and the underground station were only accessible for passengers from the western sectors transferring here. West Berlin citizens could also avail of the border crossing and enter the GDR here, after passing through a labyrinthine maze of tunnels and walkways designed to prevent any direct contact with GDR-citizens.
East Berliners, on the other hand, could not enter the U- or S- Bahn – the only way to leave the GDR was to get on a long-distance train to West Germany. To do so, GDR citizens had to pass through the so-called ”Tränenpalast,” the palace of tears, a building on the square north of the station erected in 1962. The expression is derived from the tearful goodbyes that took place in front of the building, where family members with travel permits had to say farewell to their relatives.
After the fall of the wall, the blue glass pavilion of Friedrichstrasse became a cultural center for concerts and readings, and was eventually turned into the Tränenpalast museum in 2006, enabling visitors to relive the experience of officially crossing from the GDR to West Berlin.
Originally published at www.slowtravelberlin.com.

Title: The Battle of Berlin.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
2
Listen
Share
Almost three-quarters of a century ago, the German Army had been pushed back to Berlin. Six years of war culminated in fierce fighting through the streets of Berlin. Adolf Hitler claimed his Third Reich would last for a thousand years, yet by the end of the battle his army was depleted, and his right-hand men had begun to abandon him.
The battle, which was predominantly between German and Soviet Union soldiers, was the last stand of the Nazi regime. Yet the swift advancement of the Allies on both the Eastern and Western Front meant that by the time the Battle of Berlin began, the war was coming to a gradual and bloody end.
A battle which resulted in Germany’s surrender came at a significant human cost. Over three-quarters of a million people, soldiers and civilians were either killed or wounded. Society within Berlin was almost destroyed. Destruction of the city began on the 19th April 1945. The Soviet Union began shelling the city in preparation for the tank and infantry assault. Six days later, led by General Zhukov, the first Russian soldiers broke through to the Berlin suburbs. Day by day, more and more of outer-Berlin fell into Soviet hands.
The counter-attack which was desperately needed by the Germans came from the 12th army, commanded by General Wenck, on April 27th. Yet the sheer number of Soviet soldiers, the lack of resources at Wenck’s disposal and tactical bombing from the Royal Air Force to delay the German reinforcements ultimately made sure that the counter-attack had no real impact. Wenck was halted and the Soviet forces were just 15 miles from the centre of the city. By early May, the Third Reich and everything which Nazism stood for was on the brink of total collapse.
In the meantime, Hitler was deep in his bunker underneath the streets where his people were being slaughtered by an invading force. One of his final acts as German leader was to send members of the Hitler youth out onto the bombed-out streets of Berlin. Many of these would fall during the dying days of the Third Reich.
The people who had followed him, often so loyally, for many years had been left to die by Hitler at the hands of the Soviet Union. When British and American troops made their way into the city from the west, Berlin was surrounded by the Allied forces. The Reichstag lay in ruins, as did the Nazi regime.
It had taken the Allies almost five years to regain a foothold in continental Europe, with Britain and France suffering greatly in the process. Millions of lives were lost in the struggle to crush fascism and the slaughter had been taken to the streets of a city previously considered impregnable by Allied command.
Berliners were, like at the end of the First World War, left with their governments in ruin. Thousands of people lay dead in Berlin, over a million were without power and clean water, yet for many, the worst was yet to come. Although the Second World War was over, the fear an all-new type of warfare was beginning to grip the continent.

Title: Before and After the Wall: My Life in Berlin
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Twenty five years ago this week, TV images flashed on screen of people singing and dancing atop the Berlin Wall.
It seemed almost impossible. I gulped, smiled and felt all tingly.
The fall of the Berlin Wall on Nov. 9, 1989, was emotional and personal for me. Years earlier, I had lived on the free side of the divided city at the height of the Cold War as an American military high school student. Were our neighbors trapped in the East now free after nearly three decades of Soviet control?
To stem the flow of East Berliners who wanted to escape, a jagged 27-mile wall cut the city into two halves, and 100 miles of barbed wire encircled the back half of West Berlin, making it an island city. But as American military dependents, we enjoyed a good life and freedom in a cosmopolitan half protected by American, British and French soldiers.
Those in East Berlin experienced a daily existence that was dreary and drab behind a 13-foot-tall concrete barrier. Although all roads in West Berlin ended at the wall, we couldn’t help but see the oppression on the other side. “This wall is an illusion,” read graffiti painted on the free side. “You stand like a scab, an unhealing wound,” were scrawled words I still remember today.
With my father’s U.S. Air Force status we were allowed to venture into the East. We occasionally drove through the famous Checkpoint Charlie border crossing in our gigantic1962 Pontiac Star Chief. During day trips, we would purchase camera gear, crystal glassware and wall clocks in shops intended for visiting communist dignitaries.
We avoided the regular markets with no fresh fruit, and shoe stores with only one size, style and color.
On one outing my family returned to our car to find people standing by the trunk, which was large enough to hold three people. They asked us to take them over to the West.
My father just shook his head “no” and told us to get in the car. He had heard of other GI’s who had smuggled East Berliners back to the West and were caught by the American military police. U.S. officials would immediately transfer those soldiers who risked an international incident. They would be sent from West Berlin (a plum assignment) to a desolate outpost in South Korea as punishment the next day, or so the rumor went.
On my 16th birthday, my father took me over to the East for dinner at the Moscow Haus, a high-end restaurant frequented by communist officials. Within minutes, a man in a Russian uniform joined us at the table. In decent English, he asked about the stripes on my father’s uniform and what they meant.
I remember great awkwardness and a racing heartbeat as the soldier continued to sit with us as we remained silent. Finally the Soviet officer returned to his own table. Who was he? Where did he come from? Could we have disappeared that night, deep in the heart of East Berlin?
Another time we tried to buy a motorcycle in a showroom full of choices, or so we thought. The clerk pulled a big book from behind the counter and asked us to write in our name and address. “Three years,” he told us. “What about these in the store?” we asked. No, those were just for display, he said. We would need to get on a list and wait, so we declined.
While the Soviet east sat basically untouched and neglected for 28 years, the fall of the Wall led to massive, but slow, renovations.
The former districts of East Berlin today are festive places, full of upscale townhouses, offbeat art galleries and ethnic restaurants. Playhouses host performances that rival those of New York and Las Vegas, and American celebrities like Matt Damon and Tom Cruise turn up weekly for vacations or movie premieres.
The former swath that cut through the center of city has provided prime real estate for development again, especially along the Spree River. The city’s subway systems are united and provide seamless and efficient transportation for Berlin’s 3.5 million people.
Everything happens on a grand scale, whether it’s a massive fireworks display at the Brandenburg Gate on New Year’s Eve or the opening of Europe’s largest train station days before the 2006 World Cup soccer tournament began. The main government building, Der Reichstag, is a contrast of visions — with old style below and a futurist glass dome above that allows visitors to peer into the legislative chamber below.
By guiding University of Florida student journalists the past 10 years on study-abroad trips, I have been privileged to help tell the story of a reborn Berlin. Armed with digital cameras, voice recorders and laptops, UF students have spent two weeks every May since 2005 reporting on a cross-section of Berliners. From the city where I discovered my interest in photojournalism, we document some of the people and places that exemplify Berlin’s ongoing spirit of freedom. It’s a subtle revelation as the students come to understand the significance of what they are seeing and feeling.
Many return to Florida saying they’ve been changed; they have felt the underlying spirit of survival, transformation, creativity and openness. Most are surprised and enthralled that the city lives up its reputation of “anything goes.” Some students feel more patriotic after learning and seeing first-hand how American forces kept the city alive following World War II. Some say they want to return to Berlin and open a coffee shop – or work for the Fat Tire Bike Tour company. Most have heard the expression first-hand from Berliners that “you can be who you want to be in Berlin.”
All remember Dr. Pong — a virtually unmarked club where the only entertainment is a single ping-pong table and loud music. Holding a beverage in one hand and a paddle in the other, up to 30 partiers circle the table in a counter-clockwise motion, enjoying a group game that shrinks in size as players miss and have to sit out. After the final two players battle for the championship, the winner bangs the table three times with his paddle, and everyone starts up again. It’s a happy mix – a free-for-all of ages, styles, religions and politics.
Dr. Pong is only a hole-in-the-wall pub, a relic in the former East. It’s poorly lit, has unadorned concrete walls and is full of choking smoke. Yet it speaks volumes about the edginess of Berlin, the acceptance of others and the freedom that the united city now enjoys.
Twenty-five years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, Germany’s capital continues to reinvent itself, balancing between an historic past and an optimistic future to remain one of the world’s leading cities. I’m proud to be a part of that transformation every year.
John has been teaching photojournalism at the University of Florida since 1991. Each summer, he organizes a trip to Berlin for students interested in documentary journalism.

Title: Beating the Winter Doldrums with Inspiration from the Past and Present
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
By Annie Mark-Westfall
My column is due in two days, and I am staring into a panicked abyss. To inspire myself, I take a brisk walk while my husband puts the kids to bed. As I set out, I narrate and write in my head, badly. I get stuck on whether the word “brisk” is meant to describe the pace or the biting cold, and roll my eyes. For the duration of the walk, I will wrestle my thoughts, alternately trying to focus and to let my mind empty itself. Think. Don’t think. Think.
It gives me flashbacks to being a middle-schooler at a mall in middle America, standing in front of a large display of those 3-D hidden image posters. Those posters were the fake news of the 1990s, I am sure of it. My friends always claimed to see a floating sailboat, while I stood there dumbly.
“Just focus on one spot. Do you see it?”
“No, no! Don’t focus on anything, just let your vision get blurry. Do you see it now?”
My thoughts return to the present, where I am walking quickly in the freezing cold of January in Berlin, musing now on the cliché “waste not, want not.” For a year, I have been rolling this concept over in my head, wondering at the direction of causation. How a refrigerator full of leftovers does seem to reduce my appetite. Just don’t think, Annie.
I pause at the site of Albert Einstein’s old apartment building. It was destroyed in the war. In Berlin, we say “the war” the way New Yorkers say “the city” — as if there is only one. An etched sign marks the location. Berlin does not light its streets the way US cities do, and my neighborhood is particularly residential, so the sign is barely visible. We bring all our visitors here, so I know that it details, both in German and English, how Einstein used to host famous and talented guests. How they would spend evenings discussing the secrets of the universe and other urgent and important matters. Here, he wrote his theory of relativity. THINK, Annie!
The numbness is setting in. I forget how cold Berlin is, and should have worn a longer coat. It was almost 60 degrees when we were back in Ohio for the holidays. A friend who attends the climate negotiations texted me from Katowice, Poland in December, “We are all f*cked. Learn survival skills and move to higher ground.” Don’t think about that.
On the move again, I return to another friend’s idea to relaunch a Berlin salon, reminiscent of the ones run by Jewish women starting from the late 18thcentury. I am desperate for her to do this, and to include me. I think about my living room: its warmth from the radiator, inviting Persian rugs, and soft floor lamps. Our 12-foot ceilings and stained-glass windows. I am a Jewish woman. Can I make this happen? I chasten myself to sit back and stop it. It was not my idea. And my living room is not my own. It has French doors that connect to the kids’ room, and is perpetually strewn with baby dolls, mateless socks, child-size kitchen supplies.
Approaching home now, I recall how earlier in the evening, my 3-year-old asked, “How do you say ‘salad’ in Polish?” I vow that 2019 will be a year of delighting at these questions, rather than a sighed, “I don’t know, baby, eat your dinner.” Think.
I grab my computer and thaw out on the couch. I go online and am both relieved and dismayed to read that my column from last January similarly noted this soul-level exhaustion and lack of inspiration. Think, dammit!
Next to me on the couch is the latest unopened letter from Grandma Bea, her familiar cursive handwriting shaky across the envelope. I adore these letters and their everyday non-news. The essence of her character leaps off the page even as she claims she has nothing to write. This letter once again recounts her delight from a deer’s visit to her backyard bird feeder a few weeks ago. The event has found its way into three letters over the weeks, along with a detailed weather report. “My freezer is full and my fridge is stocked, so let it snow!” Grandma Bea knows how to warm a soul, even from across an ocean.
To start my year, I read When Breath Becomes Air by Paul Kalanithi, the terminally ill brain surgeon on a quest for the meaning of life. His memoir intersperses quotes from literature and facts from neuroscience, and left me bereft when I turned the last page at the solitary hour of 2:00 am. Thinking now about Dr. Kalanithi’s calling as a doctor, and Grandma Bea’s notes on substituting gluten-free flour in her famous banana cake recipe, my breath catches at their hyper-focused sense of purpose.
Last summer, while I was still on maternity leave, I met up with a friend from college who was passing through Berlin. We sat in a café together, and as I shushed my baby, I hungrily asked questions about her life as a writer, feeling pangs of jealousy. Although I have meticulously crafted my dream life here in Berlin, I admittedly had hoped writing would play more of a role in my life than it currently does.
The conversation turned to one of her award-winning essays, on the topic of whales and something else brilliant and divergent like prison reform. The combination came to her after a professor urged her to return to a subject that she was “passionate about as a child.”
As I sit on my couch now, eight months later, trying again to conjure something that inspired me as a child, I hear the baby cry in the next room, followed by my husband’s voice, urgent, patient, frustrated, calm. I google “3-D image posters” and try to focus.

Title: Welcome to Marzahn, a German neighborhood of the far right
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

International journalism students report from Berlin, the heart of Europe.

--
1
Listen
Share
BERLIN — Berlin is gritty and urbane, where techno music throbs against the graffitied walls of sex clubs and drag bars. The city is known for being progressive and tolerant — but hop on the S-Bahn to one of the last stations in the East and you’ve entered Marzahn.
This is the other Berlin.
Marzahn is tucked in the northeast corner of Berlin, a working class industrial region, dotted with high-rise flats dating from the Communist era. Far-right politics find fertile ground here. After the Berlin Wall fell, Marzahn became a hub for skinheads and swastikas in the 1990s, an area rife with nationalism and populism.
Today, Marzahn is a stronghold of the country’s most successful nationalist party, the Alternative for Germany or AfD. The party embraces a platform of familiar right-wing causes — anti-immigration, isolationism, anti-LGBTQ, anti-vaccine, antisemitism and climate change denial — which are part of the American political landscape as well. Like former U.S. President Donald Trump, some in the AfD have grudging admiration for Russian leader Vladimir Putin. They oppose supplying arms to Ukraine to defend itself against Moscow’s recent invasion.
Although AfD support slipped in the most recent elections last year, its formerly fringe politics are moving deeper into the mainstream —in Germany as abroad.
Jorn Geissler, treasurer of the Marzahn branch, is keen to explain himself and his views to American readers. He invited me into his office, projecting a voice that exuded his buoyant demeanor as he walked me through the local city hall. This German nationalist wore a pair of gray khakis and greeted me with vanilla wafers and black coffee.
“You are now leaving the politically correct sector,” reads a mousepad on a desk in the AfD Marzahn office. This is a party that trades inclusive policy and progress on human rights — or political correctness — for nationalist and anti-immigrant sentiment.
Of course, speaking to an American journalist, Geissler presented the polished rendition of the far-right faction, meticulously packaged as socially acceptable. Geissler wanted to make this remarkably clear.
“I’m not a Nazi and I’m not a racist,” said Geissler. “We hear so much about fascists and Nazis in Germany, in Berlin, in Marzahn, but I’ve never seen a Nazi.”
The AfD party was founded in 2013 by mainstream Christian Democrats, who wished to abolish the euro as Germany’s currency. It adopted a clear anti-immigration platform amid the influx of Muslim refugees in 2015, when the party’s popularity rose.
Supporters are primarily from the former Communist eastern part of the country, where the political divide today reflects a split along the former Iron Curtain. During the AfD’s peak in the 2017 election, only 11.1% of western German voters cast a vote for the AfD as compared to 22.5% in the eastern states, according to tracking carried out by the German publication FOCUS.
Right wing parties have made strong inroads in the former East Germany, a phenomenon attributed to high unemployment and loss of identity after the collapse of the Berlin Wall in 1989, what Germans call the Wende, which means ‘Turn.’
“The whole East lost its political orientation in 1989,” Geissler said. “The former parties collapsed and all people in East Germany had to orient in a new way because we had no strong connection with the existing parties.”
Upon its creation in 2013, the AfD did not meet the five percent threshold to elect members to the German parliament. Very quickly, however, party support skyrocketed due to its feisty social conservative politics and its opposition to an influx of asylum seekers from the Middle East and Africa.
In Marzahn, support in 2021 hovered around 16%, maintaining the right-leaning reputation of the neighborhood. In the 2017 national election, 20.6% of Marzahn voters chose the AfD in the first round of voting, the party’s peak year.
Geissler, a construction engineer, joined the far-right party in 2014, attracted to its nationalist stance against the euro. He came to appreciate the party’s disruptive politics, seeing it as the German counterpart to Trumpism.
“We are not controlled by the system,’’ he said.
Even as a young man, growing up in the Germany Democratic Republic, or East Germany, Geissler was the rebellious type, dissatisfied with the living conditions maintained by the ruling Communists.
The same goes for Jeannette Auricht, 62, a member of the Berlin Senate who as a child danced around her room to Michael Jackson and Earth, Wind & Fire on the radio. In all areas of Berlin, TV and radio channels were left unrestricted which also gave her and other East Berliners access to the American Forces Network, a U.S. Army-run radio channel that contributed to her rising angst over lack of freedoms in the East.
Auricht was arrested in her teen years for demonstrating against the Berlin Wall. Now, she represents the AfD in Berlin and says she has “learned to read between the lines” in German politics, meaning she has a long-standing mistrust of government.
As she pledges to hold onto her center-right stance, not all of her party co-members do the same, instead drifting further right.
The alternative ideology of the party has attracted many extremist members, prompting the German courts in March 2021 uphold the government-declared designation of the AfD as a “suspicious entity,” which makes it legal to monitor groups who may be engaging in anti-constitutional activities.
Germany’s attempt to put the AfD under surveillance for extremism does not phase Auricht, who said she does not fear wiretapping because she has nothing to hide.
“I’m not planning a revolution,” she said. “Criticizing the government is a job you have to do and that is nothing against the country or the democratic ways.”
Within the party, leaders try to push out extremists by researching whether they have a racist or fascist history, Geissler said. However, German laws make it difficult to remove members from their parties and this proactive measure was only implemented a couple years into AfD’s existence, he said.
So, extremists do still exist here. And while the party is currently split between center-right and far-right directions, the far-right fringe casts a dark shadow on the reputation of the party.
In late 2020, former AfD party official Christian Lueth was recorded saying that to allow more migrants into Germany would be better for the party because it would attract more membership. As for the immigrants, he said, they can “shoot them all afterwards.”
“Or gas them, whichever you like. I don’t care either way,” the Lueth was quoted as saying.
Geissler said that other political parties in the governing coalition fight against the AfD because of some outspoken extremists, and he also blames the media for misrepresenting the party, due to what he considers a journalistic lean to the left.
He also points out that most party officials are beginners in the political scene.
“AfD members are mostly newbies,” Geissler said. “Most people have no political experience compared to other political parties. And you have to go a long way to get to the top.”
The fringe is gaining ground not only in Germany but in other parts of Europe, where voters in countries like Hungary and Poland are also continuing to accept the far-right in their political mainstream. Despite the AfD’s drop in votes in Germany’s most recent parliamentary election, the nationalist movement is gaining traction among the general public.
“Far-right groups are starting to share straight-out white supremacist ideas that used to be unacceptable in ‘mainstream’ politics,” said Heidi Beirich, co-founder of the U.S.-based Global Project Against Hate and Extremism.
The AfD’s social platform places it far into the political edges with its subversive ideology on human rights, she says, adding that its populist platform reflects the shifting political climate in Germany.
“There is a hard move to the right built mostly on anti-immigrant positions, a simultaneous collapse of the left, and a scramble at the center to keep the fringe out,” Beirich said.
Far-right anti-immigration sentiment is the most obvious example of social conservatism that has the potential to turn dangerous — as it has on a few other occasions in the three decades since German reunification. The AfD platform pushes for strictly regulated borders, especially for Muslim migrants who “don’t take up German culture,” said Marzahn party treasurer Geissler.
He says there is a stronger opposition to Muslim refugees than to Ukrainian refugees fleeing the Russian invasion because the new arrivals are of European descent and share Christian principles and other cultural norms.
“Migrants from Islamic countries are completely different from European countries like Ukraine,” Geissler said. “The culture is more similar, such as how to speak to women, and the family culture.”
The AfD is vocal about its anti-immigrant stance, but its antisemitism is more hidden. It does not support certain inclusive laws and regulations, such as those governing circumcision and animal slaughter rituals — some of which affect both Muslims and Jews, said Sigmount Koenigsberg, Commissioner Against Antisemitism at the Jewish Community of Berlin.
“The AfD is pretending to be pro-Jewish and pro-Israel,” Koenigsberg said. “It’s a fig leaf to hide their anti-Muslim sentiment. The far right parties are all antisemitic and that is clear.”
In July, the state of Brandenburg, outside Berlin, voted to amend its constitution to include stronger language banning discrimination against Jews, and specifically naming the Sinti and Roma diaspora for protection, codifying a commitment to fight antisemitism and antigypsyism.
The AfD was the only party to vote against it.
Beirich, of the global anti-hate project says the AfD’s populist rhetoric is now part of a global fabric, and she cites parallels between the German AfD and the American Republican Party.
“There’s a lot of political science work that’s been done about where the Republican party sits now and AfD is one of the parties that they most compare our GOP to nowadays,” Beirich said. “So it just shows how far the Republicans have moved to the right.”
She said the GOP and AfD dovetail most on their anti-immigrant positioning, seeking to deny benefits to migrants and cut back on numbers.
But while abortion laws are politically charged in the United States , especially after the Supreme Court reversed the Roe v. Wade right to abortion, the German right has maintained a more ambiguous stance.
“Every woman should make their own decision about their body,” said Auricht, who represents the AfD in Berlin. “With vaccinations too, you cannot say ‘my body my choice’ and then not hold that same principle with receiving the vaccine.”
Gun rights and regulation is also a hot topic for polarized America, and the AfD spokespeople cannot understand the American obsession with guns.
While the far-right narratives are similar worldwide — anti-lockdown fervor, dangerous conspiracy theories, and opposition to gay rights, just to name a few — the U.S. might be in more danger of veering into reactionary politics than Europe is, say analysts.
“There are some parallels with a hard shift to the right and openness by regular conservatives, especially here in the United States, to white supremacy and street movements,” American anti-extremism activist Beirich said. “I think the situation actually is worse here in the United States than it is in Germany.”
Because of Germany’s Nazi past, democracy is better protected by a state that is highly concerned with anti-democratic movements and hate speech, she said.
Beirich points out that far-right wing parties tend to be opportunistic, attaching themselves to crises such as the pandemic to keep their numbers up. If there is another social or economic crisis tomorrow, she said, party support would likely reflect the country’s circumstances.
“They are going to rise and fall in various ways depending on the mood of the country,” Beirich said. “The fringe is not disappearing like they did in previous eras. They seem to have a foothold now and are surviving.”
So the AfD may have lost some ground electorally, but its ideas have seeped into mainstream politics, strengthening the broader array of rightist parties.
Annemarie Schmidt, 74, a retired teacher from Marzahn who identifies herself as left-leaning, admits that she shares the AfD’s concerns over refugees, over rising housing and energy costs and the financial burdens of the war in Ukraine.
Schmidt thinks the climate is ripe for the AfD to do well in the future.
“Poor people here get nothing and the refugees get a lot, so the state makes it difficult for everyone to get along,” Schmidt said. “Though the AfD is taking advantage of these problems, they could be right on this topic. I wouldn’t vote for them, but during the next election the AfD will be very strong.”
Alexandra Goldberg is a Communication and Journalism student at UC Santa Barbara, reporting from Berlin this summer.
--
--
