Title: Characters in Berlin
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
But what exactly is Pictoplasma? Similar to the question posed in “The Matrix,” I found myself needing to discover the answer for myself. Let me explain: In 2004, I bought the first Pictoplasma character book in a bookstore in Switzerland and was completely captivated. I also visited their very informative website at the time and gathered that it was a meeting for character designers. Since that day, I wanted to attend Pictoplasma myself. However, it took me 20 years to finally make it. So in May 2024, I attended the conference in Berlin. On the first day, I felt a bit overwhelmed, not because of what was offered, but due to the organization. Everyone had to wait patiently until they could register. I felt a bit lost, but around 3:30 PM, things finally got started. I went to the registration and then directly to the first exhibitions by the artists who would be giving talks in the coming days. I saw some of the works and took them in. Then I wandered around the venue for a while.
The next day, the conference truly kicked off. According to the program, some highly renowned artists from the scene had gathered in Berlin. I attended talks by Joe Bennett, a young designer and animator from the USA. He recently made waves with his series “Scavenger Reign” on HBOMax, a sci-fi series that looks like it could have come from the mind of the artist Moebius. He has been working on this series for over seven years, and it will be available on Netflix in the coming months. His other works for Adult Swim and Fox also stand out, characterized by a quirky but endearing sense of humor.
Additionally, the artist duo “Los Calladitos” really impressed me. Their stunning murals depicting a fantastical world centered around the preservation of light captivated me. They work on their pieces with incredible care and creativity. They also showed some animations from their own film, which brought even more life to their characters and world. Unfortunately, I missed a talk by Peter The Roman, an artist known for experimenting with AI in his 3D worlds. However, I saw some of his works in the exhibitions spread across various locations in Berlin. Overall, 20 artists participated, giving talks and workshops.
But what sets Pictoplasma apart? It’s not merely a stage for artists; it’s also one of the largest communities in the realm of character art and animation. The “Artist Talks” provided profound insights into the world of artists: their methodologies, how they develop ideas and strategies, and how they publish, sell, and make a living from their art. It’s a platform for exchange and collaboration, bringing creatives from diverse backgrounds together. Moreover, the conference reflects the zeitgeist of 2024. In a world dominated by AI, Pictoplasma artists emphasize the importance of emotion and craftsmanship. It became evident that while AI is a valuable tool for ideation, the execution of most artists’ works remains in human hands. This realization, which I suspected before Pictoplasma, was confirmed and reinforced during the event. Indeed, the use of AI elevates the significance of handmade art. Consider, for instance, the wooden figures crafted by artist Parn “Ani” Aniwat, who carves more than 30 charming characters each month. Or reflect on Los Calladitos, who seamlessly transfer their unique style from the vast walls of their murals to their animated films. Even the ceramic lamps crafted by Portuguese artist and entrepreneur Ana Seixas demonstrate how handmade artworks garner special relevance and appreciation. Ultimately, one desires to touch the art that inundates our digital world.
All the days at Pictoplasma were incredibly lively and full of inspiration. One of the most interesting talks was by Philip Hunt, a creative director at AKA Studios from the UK. He shared his experiences and insights about design and art, particularly regarding the film industry and the challenges of adapting a children’s book like “Here We Are” by Oliver Jeffers into a film. He discussed the extensive thought and effort required to translate beautifully drawn 2D characters into a 3D medium. After many ideas and experiments, he and his team successfully turned the book into a beautiful film, which can be admired on Apple TV. By chance, I met Philip on Sunday, the last day of Pictoplasma, at a small flea market in Berlin. I approached him because I didn’t get the chance to talk to him at the event. We had a pleasant conversation about the industry, covering topics like advertising, films, and other media. He asked me how I found Pictoplasma, and I told him that initially, I didn’t know what to expect or what I would take away from it. He responded that each year, he takes away inspiration and a reminder of why he continues his work. He loves attending Pictoplasma, getting inspired by other artists, and gaining a perspective beyond commercial work. He also shared that he attended the first Pictoplasma 20 years ago and didn’t know what it was about back then either. Now, he teaches workshops and helps lead the Pictoplasma Academy. It was a very enjoyable conversation. So, what makes Pictoplasma so special? It’s the chance to see designers and artists doing something different from just working on commercial projects. This is something I can definitely take away from it. I was deeply moved by the following artist talks. One of them was by the artist Parn “Ani” Aniwat. Out of necessity, he began carving small figures out of wood. Now, he makes 30 pieces a month — small, cute characters that he sells to collectors and exhibitors. It has become his business. He gave us a glimpse into his workday, which runs from 9 to 5, after which he spends time with his family, sketches ideas, and watches Netflix. The same goes for the Portuguese artist and entrepreneur Ana Seixas. During the pandemic, she started working with pottery and created clay lamp characters that sold faster in her shop than she could make them.
Of course, even at a conference focused on hand-drawn, painted, or crafted characters, the topic of artificial intelligence can’t be avoided. Some artists use AI as a tool to support their ideas. However, despite the technology and digital capabilities that AI offers, traditional craftsmanship remains one of the most important aspects. While no one insists that art must be created by hand, most artists still find themselves holding a pencil or an Apple Pencil. One of the most memorable statements about AI came from Philip Hunt. A young designer from the audience asked him whether she should focus more on AI. He responded that she should focus on drawing, as AI will inevitably come. But drawing with a pencil would always convey ideas better (or something along those lines; I’m not certain of the exact wording). Another artist, possibly Christopher Rutledge, mentioned that AI is a useful tool but compared it to mastering image databases or programs like Photoshop or After Effects. Artists have shown that they engage with AI, but in the end, it’s their ideas and visions that they bring to life. For the past few months, I’ve felt that we are returning to an era of “handmade” artistry, especially in art, film, and design. With the overproduction of AI-generated images and texts, which now look and read quite well, the personal touch is often missing. A good example is animator Joe Taylor, who makes his style unmistakable with hand-drawn loops that resemble flat designs from claymation. He showcased a commercial clip for the ProCreate app, which he both drew and animated using their software.
Aside from the talks, there were workshops, exhibitions, and parties. Unfortunately, I couldn’t attend all the talks or everything that was offered. Given that Berlin is a very large city and the event organizers thought it would be a good idea to use various locations across the city, it wasn’t easy to be everywhere. There was also an AR scavenger hunt called Character Hunt, where participants had to travel around Berlin using the Adobe Aero app to view the characters. Great ideas, but too little time to experience everything. Attending Pictoplasma was a fascinating journey into the realm of art, characters, and animation. It was far more than I could have ever imagined back then. For me, it was a significant source of inspiration for my work as a designer. Here, I could discover new perspectives and gain a wealth of inspiration.
The most captivating talk was also the last one of Pictoplasma. It was by Mila Useche from Colombia. She is an artist and filmmaker who had a tough journey. She had to fight hard in the working world, including working for a game company where she worked up to 15 hours a day. She then became a freelancer, working for studios like Disney, Warner Brothers, Nickelodeon, and Netflix. She also worked on her own concepts and film ideas. One of these is currently being realized in a German-Colombian co-production.
Recently, there has been a crisis in many animation studios in the USA, with widespread layoffs and job cuts. Adding to this were the aftermath of the pandemic and the surge of companies eager to use AI. Mila needed to find a way out, so she began sharing her hand-drawn images on Instagram, reaching many people who celebrated her art. She now lives in Japan, where she produces her art and characters. That was Pictoplasma 2024. A few days in another world, a world full of inspiration, art, characters, and animated films. Just a different kind of matrix.

Title: Running the Berlin Marathon
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Fancy taking on a fast, flat World Major Marathon where world records are made? Here’s what you can expect if you’re thinking about running the Berlin Marathon!
The Berlin Marathon is one of the six Abbott World Major Marathons and is the fastest of them all. With only 285ft (87m) of elevation gain it’s not surprising Eliud Kipchoge ran world records here in 2018 and 2021, clocking a massive 2:01:09 at the latter.
So if you’re thinking about taking on a race that’s renowned for producing PBs, here’s what you can expect from running the Berlin Marathon.
Berlin Marathon sends lots of comms, but many were only in German. Yes, yes, I know it’s a race in Germany, but I’d signed up in English, selected my communication preference as ‘English’ so I didn’t understand why I was getting emails in German.
The pre-race programme was terrible — one of those useless digital e-books that was impossible to flip through a single page when using a mobile phone. And as the first half was in German (again, no issues with that) and second half in English, it was almost impossible to easily find the details you were looking for. Even a pdf would’ve been a big improvement on this, but for anyone with digital accessibility needs it would’ve been virtually impossible to find any information.
It was disappointing.
The Berlin Marathon Expo took place at Tempelhof Airport to the south of the city, an easy ride there on the U-bahn (which was free to ride for marathon runners during the whole time the Expo was open and on race day).
I arrived about 08:00 so I could take part in the Generali Berlin Marathon Shakeout Run. It was free to enter and anyone could attend, so if you were with family or friends (and they were happy running about 6k!) everyone could run (althought from 2023, the shakeout run has moved back to its usual spot at the Olympic Stadium, starting at 09:30).
It was very relaxed, I’d highly recommend taking part.
The Expo itself was inside several old airport hangars. It had quite an old-skool, Cold War-era vibe to it, which just added to the atmosphere of running in Berlin.
To enter, I had to show my race card (I’d added mine to my iPhone so it was quick and easy) and photographic ID, then they heat-sealed a wrist band to my wrist. I was told I needed to keep this on until after the race, but very frankly after the Expo, no-one asked for it — my race bib was enough. That said, I wouldn’t tamper with it, just in case… even though I had to cut mine off as there was no way it’d come loose by itself!
Race bib pickup was at the very back of the Expo and once there was quick and easy. If you’d bought a finisher’s t-shirt, you had to pick that up at another counter, where you had to go outside, join a queue, then come back inside the hangar. It again was quick, but not very intuitive.
Adidas had loads of official gear for sale, so if you liked the Berlin Marathon merchandise you could load up before you left.
My family had come with me to Berlin so I’d signed the kids up to do the kids’ races taking place on the Saturday. The first was the Bambini Run for my 5 year-old, which also took place at Tempelhof.
It was pretty congested getting the kids to the start line and they didn’t allow parents through for our age category (parents could accompany the 0–2 year olds and 3–4 year olds, but not the 5–6 year olds onwards). I was a concerned my Little Girl would freak out being by herself — especially as most of the announcements were only in German — but she was fine, the marshals were great at herding the kids around and she finished with a beaming smile on her face!
Her run was only about 500m, but it was enough so she felt like she had taken part.
On the Saturday afternoon, there was a Mini-Marathon for older kids, starting at Potsdamer Platz. There was very little information about it online — and nothing in English — so I’d emailed the organisers and asked how I could sign up my son and they were very quick to get back to me with a link and a code.
Apparently the Mini-Marathon — which covers the last 4.195km of the main Berlin Marathon route — is a big schools event, with around 10,000 schoolchildren from all over Germany participating. We had a bit of a nightmare trying to pickup my son’s race bib as apparently pickup at the Expo had ended on the Thursday and when we got there on Saturday, no-one at SCC (the event organiser) knew what was happening. We eventually found the bib pickup area but it was closed down.
So we headed to the start line in Potsdamer Platz and asked SCC there, and got Little Man’s bib in about 60 seconds — very easy! Although by this point they only had large finisher’s t-shirts left, so he’s got a good few years to grow into it!
He absolutely loved the race, it was by far the largest he’d participated in and he even got to run through the Brandenburg Gate before I did!
Collecting him afterwards was hugely stressful, however. There was no clear signage on where to go — all the parents headed into the Berlin Marathon finisher’s area but the actual end of the Mini-Marathon was further down the road. There were also two exits, so we were freaking out a bit as we didn’t anticipate that so had no idea where Little Man would emerge. I took one exit and my wife took the other, and thankfully I found him pretty quickly.
So from his perspective, the Mini-Marathon was awesome… I’m so happy he enjoyed it but as a parent it was a massive stress from start to finish.
On Marathon Day itself, getting to the start line of the Berlin Marathon was one of the easiest experiences I’ve ever had.
No need to get up in the middle of the night to catch a ferry to Staten Island like you do when running the New York Marathon, or jumping on a bus from pretty much the finish line to the start if you run the Athens Authentic Marathon or Boston Marathon.
Berlin Marathon starts in Tiergarten near the Reichstag and travel by U-bahn and S-bahn is free, with the trains run every few minutes.
There’s not much there at the start village of the Berlin Marathon.
I only recall massive queues for toilets (until the men discovered they had outdoor urinals). There were also many bag drop areas, which you could walk up to and drop-off without queuing.
Before entering my corral, I found a small piece of ground to run some warm-up loops, then saw a team mate from my running club so we headed into the corrals together.
There are no toilets in the corrals, but there are more toilets and urinals just before you enter. And if you’re tempted to go in the bushes you’ll be out of luck — literally everywhere was fenced off, so it was either go in the toilets/ urinals or not at all.
Berlin Marathon is a loop, starting and finishing in Tiergarten in the city centre.
You start in the park just beyond the Reichstag parliament building and head west past Victory Monument before turning right and looping round Tiergarten and into Mitte.
There are a couple of small bridges over the Spree but you’ll barely feel them. The first ‘uphill’ segment is around Mile 4, with an elevation gain of +25ft (7.6m). There’s another +22ft (6.7m) segment in Mile 6, then the course is virtually flat until Mile 19 when there’s a -26ft (7.9m) segment and another downhill -24ft (7.3m) segment in Mile 21.
So bottom line is, you’re not really going to feel any of the elevation gain, but there are a couple of nice (but short!) downhill sections later in the race.
The Berlin Marathon begins to draw to a close running through Potsdamer Platz, where the crowds become thronging again. Support is great along the entire marathon course, and even though for 90% of the race it’s thin, the crowd gives off a welcoming vibe.
Lots of families were out supporting, with dozens of kids looking for high-fives, which was really motivating. Berlin Marathon also prints your name on your bib, and even though my name is difficult for non-English speakers to pronounce I had more personal shout-outs running the Berlin Marathon than any other race. You really feel a close connection with the crowd.
The final stretch of the Berlin Marathon has you running through the famous Brandenburg Gate and past the Reichstag to the finish line. But as the Brandenburg Gate is still a good 400m from the finish line, it’s prudent to hold off that sprint finish until you get a little closer!
Water and aid stations are plentiful along the course, the first set are at the 5k mark and then every 2.5k afterwards. Just watch out for the brown liquid — it’s cold, sweet tea, so not to everyone’s liking!
Eliud Kipchoge may have ran a new world record that day, but I knew I wasn’t going to PB at the Berlin Marathon.
I’d had a terrible training block over the summer with two consecutive injuries that put me out for five weeks, then two weeks before the Berlin Marathon I caught COVID-19.
I also had to think about running the Chicago Marathon two weeks later, so for me the Berlin Marathon was going to be an exercise in discipline.
I decided to try to run negative splits for the first time at this distance, running the first 20 miles between 7:20 and 7:40 min/ mile, then seeing what I could give for the last 10k.
I managed to clock my first 5 miles at an average pace of 7:35 mins/ mile, then upped it to 7:20 mins/ mile up to Mile 20. I felt surprisingly good at this point, so cracked on to average 6:50 mins/ mile for the last 10k, with a sprint finish peaking at 4:59 mins/ mile at the end.
Without any hills or other notable terrain to contend with — unlike the monster hill in the middle of the Athens Authentic Marathon or the ups and downs of the New York Marathon over the many bridges — Berlin Marathon lets you focus on what pace you’d like to run to achieve your goal.
I can see why it’s so fast!
The Chicago Marathon may be flatter, but Chicago suffers from poor GPS coverage through The Loop, which makes it hard to know exactly how fast you’re going at the start and the halfway point, plus all those 90-degree bends mean you slow down at every corner.
Berlin Marathon, on the other hand, just flows, and bar one sharp turn just before Mile 3 when the two lanes of runners merge, the rest was easy going.
Post-race was excellent!
There was a massive positive vibe as Kipchoge had just ran a new world record, then the sun started to peep out. It had been a comfortable 12C (54F) for the race, so the timing (for me at least) was perfect.
You get your medal pretty much right after you finish, then water and a few other bits and pieces. It’s about a 1km walk to the end of the finish area, where it’s extremely important NOT to miss the Erdinger tents giving out their Alkoholfrei beer!
I headed to the grassed area in front of the Reichstag and sat on my poncho, drinking in the sun and my ice cold beer. I could’ve stayed there much longer, but besides the Erdinger tents there wasn’t much else going on. So after half an hour to chill, I headed back to the U-bahn station and my hotel for a well-earned bath.
I really, really enjoyed running the Berlin Marathon.
Even though the organisation wasn’t always been plain sailing up until race day, the Berlin Marathon itself was superb.
The atmosphere was relaxed, the support had a real warmth to it and the course lets you concentrate on your race.
One thing I will say about the Berlin Marathon is that it’s hard to notice anything specific about many of the areas you run through as they all kinda blend into one. Sure, the downtown area around Potsdamer Platz had a unique vibe to it, but bar the final mile through the Brandenburg Gate I had no idea where in the city I was at any given time. For sure that’s mostly on me for not being very familiar with Berlin, but I didn’t have the same issues when running the New York Marathon or running the Chicago Marathon, where it’s very clear when you move from one borough or neighbourhood to another.
This isn’t really a criticism, just an observation, and it certainly hasn’t put me off wanting to run the Berlin Marathon again.
As one of the six Abbott World Major Marathons, Berlin Marathon always sells out every year. So if you’re thinking about entering, you’ll need to be fast!
Odds through the lottery are decent — I got in on my first attempt — and it opens right after the race finishes, so one year ahead. Time qualifiers need to meet a pretty tough standard — a sub-2:45 for men aged 44 and under and a sub-3:00 for women in the same age bracket.
But if you’re looking for a marathon PB on a fast, flat course with amazing support, give running the Berlin Marathon a go!
If you’ve liked this race report, you can check out my other reports on Running the New York Marathon, Running the Chicago Marathon and Running the Athens Authentic Marathon.
Follow me on Instagram and share your own running journey with me.
--
--
Long distance runner with an unhealthy obsession for marathons!

Title: The Berlin Philharmonic Logo Is an Example of Design Excellence
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

A publication by and for marketers. We publish marketing inspiration, case studies, career advice, tutorials, industry news, and more.

--
3
Listen
Share
One of my favorite hobbies is collecting inspirations of art and design I come across while browsing the internet. Thanks to those new “save” features in apps like Pinterest or Instagram, I’m able to build little digital art museums for myself. I have thousands of “saved” pictures, from vintage photography to exotic art collage. One day I caught myself amused by the simple, elegant, extremely creative logo of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra.
Whatever your career is, imagine yourself designing an orchestra logotype. First, you’d take a look at previous creations: mostly elegant curve-shaped designs with ornamental details or typographies. In color patterns, you’d see a majority of red, black and white, sometimes blue or green.
Second, you’d might brainstorm general aspects of orchestras. I’ll help: Tradition. Old Style. Chic. Elegant. Perfection. Beauty. Cult. Deep emotions. Beethoven. The frequency of sound wave. Instruments. Symphonies. The treble clef. The air-drawn lines of a baton.
The ordinary “elegant curve-shaped designs” illustrates these round elements of an orchestra. Music is not “straight”. Emotions are not “straight”. What about the color pattern? They are clearly trying to call attention, communicate passion (red tones) in a classic and elegant way (black, white tones) with notes of respectfulness or loyalty (blue, green tones).
The access to a huge source of inspiration enables the creation of my little digital museums, but it also harms uniqueness. You can create something beautiful and well constructed, but it’s easy to fall into ordinary. You can find many “how-to-do-a-beautiful-orchestra-logo-in-10-steps”, but the real challenge is to be creative and unique and still carry the message you are trying to transmit.
Well, here is why the Berlin Philharmonic logotype owned it:
This overlapped series of pentagon forms (straight lines), instead of illustrating common aspects of an orchestra, communicates the masterful architectural work of Hans Scharoun (1832–1972) for the orchestra’s concert hall, previously all fan or shoebox shaped.
The chosen yellow, a color that’s uncommon for this market, grabs attention, transmits creativity, motivation, optimism, and warmth. That conveys the Berlin Philharmonic is a modern, vivid, joyful orchestra but also warm — musically and emotionally deep.
There is also an easter egg: The overlapped pentagons clearly but not perfectly represent the floor plan of the concert hall. These overlapped pentagons suggest, besides all, a circular movement:
Yes. Circular. Do I have to say more? The logotype merges, in an exquisite way, an architectural uniqueness that characterizes the Berlin Philharmonic, without forgetting the musicality, elegancy, and round elements that surrounds an orchestra. All of those represented, with not a single curve.
“Good design is obvious. Great design is transparent.”
— Joe Sparano

Title: “God Bless America”: Celebrating Irving Berlin and Military Veterans
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Follow publication
A not-for-profit organization dedicated to enriching the cultural life of Los Angeles through plays and educational programs that inform, entertain and inspire. www.geffenplayhouse.org
Follow publication
--
Listen
Share
You might expect a 91-year-old to have plenty of leisure hours. Not Francis Kilduff. The WWII veteran is so busy putting the final touches on his latest docudrama and hobnobbing at the USO headquarters, he barely made it to the theater. Though he managed to carve some time out of his weekend to enjoy a pre-performance meal at the Geffen Playhouse, he’s hurriedly slicing into his beef and hoping he doesn’t miss curtain.
It’s the Sunday night before Veteran’s Day, and Geffen has invited military vets not only to take in the final dress rehearsal of Hershey Felder as Irving Berlin, but also to enjoy a catered dinner buffet. Partnering with the Gary Sinise Foundation (Sinise and Randall Arney, Geffen’s Artistic Director, are pals from their days working together at Chicago’s Steppenwolf Theatre), the Geffen celebrates veterans by hosting these special veterans nights for every Gil Cates Theater subscription production. As a proud partner of Blue Star Theatres, the Geffen Playhouse also offers veterans free tickets to season productions year-round.
But tonight is extra special. For most of these vets, Irving Berlin composed the soundtracks to their lives.
Seated at the table with Kilduff is Alan Bertik, an affable vet who was on a Navy destroyer in the Korean War (“It was 30 below,” he says, chuckling). He and his wife used to usher at the Geffen. They saw Felder perform one New Year’s Eve, but he’s especially excited about this show for the simple reason that he knows most of the music. Of course, everyone knows the biggies: “White Christmas,” “There’s No Business Like Show Business,” “Oh! How I Hate to Get Up in the Morning.” Still, Berlin’s catalog is so expansive — he wrote at least 1,500 songs — there are many that history has forgotten. Yet the men and women who fell in love, broke up and fell in love again remember them fondly.
“Of course I’m excited!” Kilduff chimes in. “That’s my era.”
Hershey Felder has crafted one-man shows based on Gershwin, Chopin, Beethoven and Bernstein, creating experiences that are half concerto, half stage play. In fact, they’re so unique he’s become quite famous not only in Southern California, with many premieres at the Geffen, plus performances at Pasadena Playhouse, Laguna Playhouse, San Diego Rep and the Old Globe, but also across the nation and world. (You can read more about his work in a recent American Theatre magazine article that is also re-published as the program note for the show.)
For Hershey Felder as Irving Berlin, Felder recounts Berlin’s life story by weaving memories into songs. During the peformance, Felder plays one of Berlin’s most famous songs, “God Bless America,” and invites the audience to sing along. As voices surged with pride during the dress rehearsal, there were more than a few eyes filled with tears. The one constant in Berlin’s life — from being an immigrant baby to a “singing waiter” to Fred Astaire’s best bud to a lonely recluse — was that he found comfort in music. Berlin may be America’s most famous composer, but to that end, he’s not so different than the rest of us.

Title: Believing the Unbelievable: Berlin at 80
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I was in Berlin, Germany, on May 8th; the 80th anniversary of the day that German forces surrendered unconditionally to the Allies, marking the end of WW2 in Europe. This day is sometimes referred to as “VE Day” (Victory in Europe Day). What a fitting place to be for this momentous occasion.
I have been in Berlin twice before. My first visit, in the summer of 1963 when I was 15 years old, was as part of a “teen tour” of Europe. Asleep in a Berlin hotel, I was awakened by gunfire. The construction of the Berlin Wall (at first, a barbed wire fence) began in August 1961 and in the years following, many people were shot as they tried to escape from East into West Berlin.
My second visit was 24 years ago, as part of a small group from the US Holocaust Memorial Museum, visiting historic sites in Eastern Europe that included memorials, museums, and several concentration camps. Sachsenhausen, one such camp near Berlin, is in the village of Oranienburg. It began as a slave labor camp for “political prisoners” with many subcamps. Still visible are barracks and the ruins of buildings in which remain the remnants of a gas chamber, medical experimentation areas, torture and killing areas, and several crematoria. Prisoners were treated inhumanely, inadequately fed, and openly killed. If you are reading this article, you probably know the list of who would be considered enemies of the state. A partial list includes those against the Reich whether they were Christian, Protestant, Jewish, Coptic, Roma, Communists, Gays, and anyone who was perceived to be mentally or physically disabled. This camp, not unlike others, was not on the outskirts of town. It was in the town. An alleyway separates the town from the gates to the camp with the words “Arbeit Macht Frei” (Works Sets You Free) welded into the gate. This place was not hidden. Quite the contrary, it was wide open to view and more importantly to odor. With several crematoria where bodies were burned, the smell and the ash wafted over the town, falling onto people’s rose gardens as well as onto the town residents themselves.
But I digress. Twenty four years ago, when I visited this camp, there was a person with us who, as a young man, had been a prisoner in Sachsenhausen. Somehow, miraculously, he survived. A Christian man, he had been a journalist, soon to be married, but that did not happen. It was a privilege to see the camp through his eyes, and listen as he recounted his experiences, some of which he had thought he buried along with his fellow inmates.
This was a sacred place whose stories were told to keep alive the memory of those who perished and those who survived. For decades after the war ended, “Never Again” was repeated to ensure that this kind of unleashed hatred and vitriol, resulting in these sorts of inhuman actions, would never happen again. And most of us in the world were confident that nothing like this could ever happen again!
This visit was different.
First, I am different. I am 24 years older. What I try to convince myself of is “unbelievable.” I need to believe.
Second, the world is different. Hatred, vitriol, and cruelty have become normalized. The vile antisemitic tropes that were used to degrade and denigrate people are not only ripe, but they are blossoming. Regrettably, in many places, they are in full bloom. This kind of hate flourishes on the dark web, and in the full light of day. Repulsive speech and actions have become acceptable. Throughout the world we see the rise of political parties with slogans reminiscent of a world which we thought could never be resurrected. And not only is it resurrected, but these parties have also gained representation in congresses and parliaments in the same countries where brave citizens sacrificed and fought against this to make the world safe for all.
Third, the camp is not the same. Shockingly, there are some people who visit the camp, stand next to the crematory ruins, on the rim of the entrance of the first experiment for a gas chamber, beside the remains of a barracks, who say: “this did not happen.” When you tell a lie often enough, people tend to believe it. That’s what happened prior to and during World War II. And in many parts of our world, it is happening now.
I am at a time in my life when more people than not ask me “When are you going to retire?” Here’s my response. Not only am I not going to retire, I am also committing to rededicate myself to engaging in education programs and social justice issues concerning basic human rights related to antisemitism and anti-LGBTQ hatred. All in, in my “golden years” I will not stand by and silently witness the normalization of hatred.
I write this article with both a heavy and a hopeful heart. When I say things are unbelievable, I reinforce in my own mind that I shouldn’t believe them. I am awake to the reality and the knowledge that I must believe what I see, hear, and witness. When I believe it, I will be able to address it in ways that, hopefully, will change where we are, and where we can go as a civil society.
We can choose hate, or we can choose to stand up to hate. We can be silent, or we can call people out when they say or do things that are rooted in prejudice and hate. Each of us can use our voice and our platform for good. We can choose to make excuses for bad behavior, or we can call it out. We can acquaint ourselves with history. We can familiarize ourselves with the consequences when hate is permitted to run amok. We can call out when we see lies presented as truth. And we can challenge people who are fearful or intimidated into saying and behaving in ways that are unacceptable.
When we sit by as people are being dehumanized, referred to as the “other,” we are at the entrance to the gates of Hell. I went through those gates as a tourist. I’ve listened to and read testimonies, seen films and photographs of what Hell looks like. If we consider ourselves members of the human race, we need to take that membership seriously and be aware of what it means to be human. To have hope in the future we need to discover compassion within and speak out against antisemitism and all forms of hate. We cannot excuse the inexcusable and we must believe the unbelievable.
In life’s most challenging moments, how we respond influences both our immediate wellbeing and long-term recovery. Crises arrive uninvited, testing our resilience when we feel most vulnerable. The following tips offer guidance through the turbulence, toward steadier ground.
Remain Calm: When crisis emerges, take a gentle body scan — notice your breathing, pulse, and physical sensations. Do not judge, just observe. Then begin to breathe and focus on your breath. The key is to avoid panic. When we panic, we cannot solve problems effectively. The goal is to think clearly while being aware of what is happening in your body. During this process, pause, take more slow, deep breaths. For some people, repeating prayers that offer solace, doing mindful practice, mindfulness, or engaging playfully with a pet can help.
Assess The Situation: From this centered state notice where you are physically, mentally, and emotionally. Then, identify the elements defining the crisis. What risks exist? What consequences might follow different actions? This assessment doesn’t require perfect information — only honest recognition of what is known and unknown in this moment.
Create Safety: Do what you need to get out of harm’s way. Look around, listen attentively, and notice your surroundings with fresh eyes. Take actions that move you toward greater security, extending this same protective attention to others if they’re with you.
Gather Your Support Circle: Reach out to those whose compassion brings calm — trusted friends, family members, professionals, or others who have walked similar paths. Seek those who offer the support you need rather than imposing what they believe you should want. Throughout the situation, maintain connection with beloved others. Consider engaging in creative activities that redirect mental energy — photography, gardening, music, reading, or writing — offering your mind the opportunity to “reset.”
Communicate with Transparency: Share information others need to hear to assist you, especially during medical emergencies when providers need accurate knowledge of your condition to offer effective care with minimal risk. Honest communication about symptoms, relevant medical history, concerns, and needs, creates the foundation for receiving proper assistance.
Create a Crisis Plan: Consider creating a simple emergency kit kept in your vehicle or near an exit. Maintain accessible records of essential medications, identification, and emergency contacts — both digitally and physically. Identify people who might assist with temporary housing, caregiving, pet-care, or other practical needs that could arise.
Honor Your Fundamental Needs: In crisis, the basics become precious: adequate rest, nourishment, hydration, and moments of quiet. Reflect on what essentials you require and consider how to ensure access to these necessities even during disruption. Tending to these fundamental needs becomes an act of self-compassion during challenging times.
Remember that getting through times of crisis times isn’t about handling everything perfectly. It’s about showing up as best we can, being kind to ourselves, and figuring things out as we go. Sometimes the hardest moments teach us what we’re made of and connect us more deeply to what matters. We might surprise ourselves with what we can handle, even when it feels impossible at first.
I’ve co-authored a book about kindness. I believe deeply in the lasting effects of love. It is in that context that I share my own daily habit. Each morning, I say thank you for another day and ask for an opportunity to make a difference in this world.
To that end, I look for signs of connection to those who came before me — a robin reminds me that my father is near, a butterfly reminds me of my mother. I feel their presence and listen for their guidance. Certain songs transport me to moments in my past, conjuring places, people, and, sometimes, lessons learned.
This daily habit provides continuity to my life. I’m grateful that my journey has been a healthy one so far. Though everything is unpredictable, I express gratitude however I can and move through the world appreciating all the companions I’ve known along the way.
Dr. Dale Atkinsdale@drdaleatkins.comwww.drdaleatkins.com

Title: How to have the perfect lunch: Sweden’s Daniel Berlin Krog
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--

It’s not simply a restaurant, it’s an experience. You’ll find it in Sweden’s agricultural heartland, about an hour from Copenhagen’s airport. Daniel Berlin Krog, a dining experience worthy of 2 Michelin stars.
To call it a restaurant doesn’t do justice to the careful preparation and exquisite presentation of locally sourced ingredients in the hands of a team who respect the palate’s power to delight, nurture, comfort and celebrate.
Paired with 5 wines hailing from France, Germany, and Spain — from dry whites to a sweeter varietal that foreshadowed the close of the meal — the lunch tasting menu was a taste bud explosion.
I was lucky enough to enjoy the experience on a brilliant autumn afternoon. Read this and you’ll be planning a visit, I promise.
Nestled in the hamlet of Skåne-Tranås, in an unassuming farmhouse with an ample farm garden in the back, luncheon guests are greeted with a glass of champagne to start. Because, well, why not.

Title: Before and After the Wall: My Life in Berlin
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Twenty five years ago this week, TV images flashed on screen of people singing and dancing atop the Berlin Wall.
It seemed almost impossible. I gulped, smiled and felt all tingly.
The fall of the Berlin Wall on Nov. 9, 1989, was emotional and personal for me. Years earlier, I had lived on the free side of the divided city at the height of the Cold War as an American military high school student. Were our neighbors trapped in the East now free after nearly three decades of Soviet control?
To stem the flow of East Berliners who wanted to escape, a jagged 27-mile wall cut the city into two halves, and 100 miles of barbed wire encircled the back half of West Berlin, making it an island city. But as American military dependents, we enjoyed a good life and freedom in a cosmopolitan half protected by American, British and French soldiers.
Those in East Berlin experienced a daily existence that was dreary and drab behind a 13-foot-tall concrete barrier. Although all roads in West Berlin ended at the wall, we couldn’t help but see the oppression on the other side. “This wall is an illusion,” read graffiti painted on the free side. “You stand like a scab, an unhealing wound,” were scrawled words I still remember today.
With my father’s U.S. Air Force status we were allowed to venture into the East. We occasionally drove through the famous Checkpoint Charlie border crossing in our gigantic1962 Pontiac Star Chief. During day trips, we would purchase camera gear, crystal glassware and wall clocks in shops intended for visiting communist dignitaries.
We avoided the regular markets with no fresh fruit, and shoe stores with only one size, style and color.
On one outing my family returned to our car to find people standing by the trunk, which was large enough to hold three people. They asked us to take them over to the West.
My father just shook his head “no” and told us to get in the car. He had heard of other GI’s who had smuggled East Berliners back to the West and were caught by the American military police. U.S. officials would immediately transfer those soldiers who risked an international incident. They would be sent from West Berlin (a plum assignment) to a desolate outpost in South Korea as punishment the next day, or so the rumor went.
On my 16th birthday, my father took me over to the East for dinner at the Moscow Haus, a high-end restaurant frequented by communist officials. Within minutes, a man in a Russian uniform joined us at the table. In decent English, he asked about the stripes on my father’s uniform and what they meant.
I remember great awkwardness and a racing heartbeat as the soldier continued to sit with us as we remained silent. Finally the Soviet officer returned to his own table. Who was he? Where did he come from? Could we have disappeared that night, deep in the heart of East Berlin?
Another time we tried to buy a motorcycle in a showroom full of choices, or so we thought. The clerk pulled a big book from behind the counter and asked us to write in our name and address. “Three years,” he told us. “What about these in the store?” we asked. No, those were just for display, he said. We would need to get on a list and wait, so we declined.
While the Soviet east sat basically untouched and neglected for 28 years, the fall of the Wall led to massive, but slow, renovations.
The former districts of East Berlin today are festive places, full of upscale townhouses, offbeat art galleries and ethnic restaurants. Playhouses host performances that rival those of New York and Las Vegas, and American celebrities like Matt Damon and Tom Cruise turn up weekly for vacations or movie premieres.
The former swath that cut through the center of city has provided prime real estate for development again, especially along the Spree River. The city’s subway systems are united and provide seamless and efficient transportation for Berlin’s 3.5 million people.
Everything happens on a grand scale, whether it’s a massive fireworks display at the Brandenburg Gate on New Year’s Eve or the opening of Europe’s largest train station days before the 2006 World Cup soccer tournament began. The main government building, Der Reichstag, is a contrast of visions — with old style below and a futurist glass dome above that allows visitors to peer into the legislative chamber below.
By guiding University of Florida student journalists the past 10 years on study-abroad trips, I have been privileged to help tell the story of a reborn Berlin. Armed with digital cameras, voice recorders and laptops, UF students have spent two weeks every May since 2005 reporting on a cross-section of Berliners. From the city where I discovered my interest in photojournalism, we document some of the people and places that exemplify Berlin’s ongoing spirit of freedom. It’s a subtle revelation as the students come to understand the significance of what they are seeing and feeling.
Many return to Florida saying they’ve been changed; they have felt the underlying spirit of survival, transformation, creativity and openness. Most are surprised and enthralled that the city lives up its reputation of “anything goes.” Some students feel more patriotic after learning and seeing first-hand how American forces kept the city alive following World War II. Some say they want to return to Berlin and open a coffee shop – or work for the Fat Tire Bike Tour company. Most have heard the expression first-hand from Berliners that “you can be who you want to be in Berlin.”
All remember Dr. Pong — a virtually unmarked club where the only entertainment is a single ping-pong table and loud music. Holding a beverage in one hand and a paddle in the other, up to 30 partiers circle the table in a counter-clockwise motion, enjoying a group game that shrinks in size as players miss and have to sit out. After the final two players battle for the championship, the winner bangs the table three times with his paddle, and everyone starts up again. It’s a happy mix – a free-for-all of ages, styles, religions and politics.
Dr. Pong is only a hole-in-the-wall pub, a relic in the former East. It’s poorly lit, has unadorned concrete walls and is full of choking smoke. Yet it speaks volumes about the edginess of Berlin, the acceptance of others and the freedom that the united city now enjoys.
Twenty-five years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, Germany’s capital continues to reinvent itself, balancing between an historic past and an optimistic future to remain one of the world’s leading cities. I’m proud to be a part of that transformation every year.
John has been teaching photojournalism at the University of Florida since 1991. Each summer, he organizes a trip to Berlin for students interested in documentary journalism.

Title: Money Heist Spin off: Berlin Series Review
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
La Casa De Papel or Money Heist was the Picasso of Heist series with a powerful cast, sky-high stakes, and a plot with more twists than a DNA strand. Berlin on the other hand is a series that softens the psychopathic image of the enigmatic heist player in Money Heist.
Make no mistake, Berlin in La Casa de Papel was a monster who raped, killed, and looted just because he could do it. But the Money Heist Spinoff Berlin series portrays his human side that is slightly empathetic, pathologically romantic, and mindful.
Berlin opens with Pedro Alonso saying goodbye to his third wife, in true Bollywood style — it’s raining when this happens and the mood is somber. This immediately cuts to Berlin figuratively AND literally stepping into a heist with his key players.
[Andrés de Fonollosa is the true name of the fictional character Berlin, played to perfection by Pedro Alonso in this mild heist series. But to stay true to the theme of this review we shall refer to our protagonist as the titular Berlin.]
There’s Keila, the electronics engineering wizard who is pathologically shy, Roi the misanthrope, Damian the genius absent-minded professor, and Bruce the point man who is good at everything in general.
Later on, Berlin introduces us to the unstable bombshell Cameron. So begins the grand heist that involves the theft of 44 Million euros worth of jewels. The cliched heist music is a bit too on the nose, but definitely not out of place in the first episode.
The heist in itself is pretty simple by Money Heist standards, where Berlin’s team tunnels into a Parisian vault to steal jewels. There is a Rick and Morty episode that echoes the same visuals as this series with a hand holding a red jewel.
The main antagonist in this series is Berlin’s romanticism and foolhardiness. It is also necessary to make the plot interesting, else there would be nothing to make this heist really exciting. He falls for the wife of the mark whom they are targeting which becomes most of the plot as you continue watching.
Damian represents the brains of the operation as the professor did in the Money Heist seasons. He also goes through issues with his wife but handles it way better than the impulsive and still-human Berlin.
Read Love and Monsters (2020) Movie Review
The visuals in this series are beautiful although not as amazing as the ones in Money Heist. There is one particular scene where Berlin rejects Camille at first but then walks in to kiss her in a lift chamber with his approach shown from a mirror in the lift. This scene is particularly well done.
Apart from great shots of Paris, the vault, and the tunnel they take to reach the vault there is not much else to look forward to. I am not saying these are not great but, compared to La Casa de Papel it’s not mind-blowing.
You might like The Mission Impossible Franchise So Far
There are three characters that the plot revolves around with the rest of the characters having subplots that are not that interesting. There is Berlin, his love interest Camille played by Samantha Siqueiros, and Tristán Ulloa as Damián the professor.
While Berlin seems almost sane in this series, Damian is undergoing a lot of turmoil in his marital life. Camille plays a clueless, daydreaming, 1.5-dimensional wife of a wealthy man who is ready to be swept off her feet by Berlin.
I have to single out Begoña Vargas playing Cameron as she is beautiful and rugged both in real life and as her character. She could have been given a meatier role, but none of the characters in this series have a substantial role apart from being a background for Berlin’s origin story.
Read The Boys Series on Prime Video — A Reality Check for Superheroes
If you have not watched Money Heist and are into romance, then go for it. If you have watched La Casa de Papel and don’t mind a Heist series that is mediocre and has time to kill, then sure, you can watch it as well.
In case you are a hardcore fan of the Money Heist series or even Money Heist Korea, and love how layered they are then don’t. Do not expect any plot twists, fantastic heist set-ups, or even complex characters.
Like this review? Subscribe for more!

Title: I Love Berlin
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
November 9, 2014, marked the 25th anniversary of one of the happiest events in recent history: The fall of the Berlin Wall.
“The greatest cultural extravaganza that one could imagine.”
–David Bowie
“Berlin is more a part of the world than a city. ”
–Jean Paul, Writer, 1800
“You are crazy, my child. You must go to Berlin.”
–Franz von Suppe, Composer, 1800
“Berlin is the newest city I have come across. Even Chicago would appear old and gray in comparison.”
–Mark Twain, Chicago Daily Tribune, 1892
“I still keep a suitcase in Berlin.”
–Line from a 1957 song by Marlene Dietrich
“Berlin is a city condemned forever to becoming and never to being.”
–Karl Scheffler, Author of Berlin: Ein Stadtschicksal, 1910
“Nobody intends to put up a wall! ”
–Walter Ulbricht, Leader of the GDR, June, 1961, two months before the Berlin Wall was built
“Berlin is the testicle of the West. When I want the West to scream, I squeeze on Berlin.”
–Nikita Khrushchev, First Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, Aug. 24, 1963, speech in Yugoslavia
“All free men, wherever they may live, are citizens of Berlin. And therefore, as a free man, I take pride in the words, ‘Ich bin ein Berliner!’”
– U.S. President John F. Kennedy, speaking at the wall in West Berlin, June 1963 (Kennedy was later criticized for using the word “Berliner,” which literally means, “jelly doughnut” in German.)
“When you come to Germany as a Jew you have an uneasy feeling, but I’ve always felt okay in Berlin.”
–Mel Brooks, American Film Director
“Paris is always Paris and Berlin is never Berlin! ”
–Jack Lang, Former Culture Minister of France, 2001
“Berlin is poor, but sexy.”
–Klaus Wowereit, Governing Mayor of Berlin, 2004
“Berlin combines the culture of New York, the traffic system of Tokyo, the nature of Seattle, and the historical treasures of, well, Berlin.”
–Hiroshi Montomura, U.S. Law professor, 2004
“Berlin is a pulsing, exciting city with so many varied and distinctive neighborhoods, iconic history all around, great food at all levels and from every corner of the world … an excellent place to set up camp and make a great record.”
–Member of the Music Group, R.E.M., 2010
“People of Berlin, people of the world, this is our moment. This is our time.”
–Barack Obama, U.S. President, Speech at Berlin Wall, July 24, 2008
Ellen Girardeau Kempler’s articles and essays have been published in the Los Angeles Times, the Christian Science Monitor, Westways and many other publications. She writes about balance, travel and the metaphorical journey on her website, Gold Boat Journeys, and shares short, sweet tweets @goodnewsmuse. A shorter version of this article appeared on Gold Boat Journeys Ship’s Log (aka the slog).

Title: Welcome to Cyber Berlin
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

The future is already here — it’s just not very evenly distributed. Stories about cyberpunk becoming our modern reality.

--
Listen
Share
I travel the world exploring high tech low life places. Most of these places are in Asia, but what about Europe? Wikipedia Cyberpunk page mentioned Sony Center in Berlin as an example of cyberpunk-influenced cityscape. Modern incarnations of cyberpunk are exact focus of this blog, so we’re going to Germany!
First place we’ll visit is Potsdamer Platz in Berlin’s central borough called Mitte.
This place is awesome and looks more like Manhattan than a German city.
Being a kid in late 90s I loved a TV show called “Total Recall 2070”. It was loosely based on Philip K. Dick works. Plots of most episodes are quite cheesy, but its futuristic atmosphere was so damn dark and sinister! And you know what? Potsdamer Platz looks and feels exactly like Total Recall 2070.
As I know, no cyberpunk books or movies are based in Berlin, but they definitely should!
Berlin is worth visiting just for Potsdamer Platz, but let’s proceed to the Sony Center, which is nearby.
It is easy to approach Sony Center from Potsdamer Platz, just go where all the neon lights are.
This area consists mostly of shopping malls, offices, restaurants. But who cares? For me it looks exactly like William Gibson’s 80s vision of the future.
Large shining dome reminds me of Highlander 2 movie. By the way, the movie was very much high tech and low life.
Offices on the sides of Sony Center looks super futuristic even without glowing neon lights.
The area of Sony Center and nearby office buildings is quite crowded and noisy. Walk couple of minutes westward and suddenly the streets become empty.
Approaching Tiergarten, Berlin’s central park. It is completely empty at 8pm.
Going to Unter den Linden street, which passes Mitte horizontally. Westernmost part of the street is a place of famous Brandenburg Gate and different government building.
But let’s go east, where Berlin looks more hi tech and noire.
Probably low life is not what you’ll find here, but central Berlin still has its dark vibe at night with techno clubs and dark cold streets.
Mitte reminds me both Manhattan and Moscow, but feels darker than each of them.
Speaking of Moscow, we’re approaching Alexanderplatz which looks a lot like large soviet city, rather than Western Europe.
Which is quite obvious, since this district was a part of Eastern Germany.
When it is foggy, Alexanderplatz feels like a vampire movie.
Visiting Berlin is definitely a good idea for dark future fans. Other districts look less dark, but still interesting to explore. Berlin is easy to reach via major airlines (sometimes with connection in Frankfurt or Munich) and its relatively cheap, comparing to other Western Europe capital cities.
--

The future is already here — it’s just not very evenly distributed. Stories about cyberpunk becoming our modern reality.

Title: #4 Berlin: Journey Through a City’s Wartime Past in Autumn
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Travel Date: Oct 25, 2022Trip Duration: 4 daysLocation: BerlinCountry: Germany
It was late October, and autumn had fully embraced Europe. The air was crisp, the leaves were golden, and I found myself in a refreshed state of mind after months of routine in the Netherlands. My last adventure had been to Belgium, and I felt the need for another break — a chance to both recharge and reconnect with a close friend living in Berlin. With that in mind, I booked a BlaBla car, a budget-friendly option, for the 7-hour drive. It was a journey shared with strangers, but the ride turned out to be quite enjoyable, with pleasant conversations and the excitement of traveling to a new place.
As we approached Berlin in the evening, my first glimpse of the city was the iconic Fernsehturm, the famous TV Tower. Bathed in the soft evening light, it loomed over the skyline like a symbol of Berlin’s complex past. Once a broadcasting tower and a proud symbol of Communist power, today it stands as one of the city’s most recognizable landmarks. My first impression of the city was a blend of awe and anticipation.
Eager to experience Berlin, I spent some time wandering the lively streets, soaking in the urban energy and the distinct buzz of the city. The streets were a blend of old and new, modern cafes and shops nestled between centuries-old buildings that told their own stories of Berlin’s history. Eventually, I made my way to my friend’s apartment. It had been years since we last saw each other, so catching up felt like a breath of fresh air. After settling in and relaxing for a bit, my friend decided it was time to introduce me to Berlin’s legendary nightlife. The city came alive after dark, and we hopped from one lively spot to another, enjoying the pulse of the city.
The next day, on the 26th of October, I had planned something a little more structured — a walking tour booked through GuruWalk. The morning air was chilly but refreshing, and I made it to the meeting point just in time. Our guide, knowledgeable and passionate, took us on a historical journey through Berlin’s war-torn past. One of the first stops was Checkpoint Charlie, the best-known crossing point between East and West Berlin during the Cold War. Standing there, I could almost feel the tension and uncertainty that must have hung in the air during those days of division.
As we moved on, we visited the site of Hitler’s final bunker, the very place where he spent the last moments of his life. It was a sobering experience, knowing that beneath the unassuming ground lay a chapter of history that shaped the world. The tour continued, and soon we found ourselves at the Brandenburg Gate, standing tall and proud. This grand monument, once a symbol of division, now stands for unity and peace. Under the unexpectedly warm autumn sun, I took a few photos, trying to capture the magnificence of the gate with its classical columns and rich history. After lingering there for a bit, basking in the sun, I met a traveler from the United States. We clicked immediately, and together, we decided to continue exploring.
Our next destination was the Konzerthaus Berlin, an elegant concert hall known for its neoclassical architecture. The grandeur of the place was awe-inspiring, and I could almost imagine the musical performances that must have filled the air with harmony and culture. We walked the historical streets, each corner revealing layers of Berlin’s rich and sometimes tumultuous past. Eventually, we found ourselves at Berlin Cathedral, a majestic structure that has stood since the 1800s. The cathedral was imposing, with its grand dome and intricate details. Inside, it houses a massive organ with 7,269 pipes, a royal tomb, and offers breathtaking views of the city from its dome. We admired the architecture and strolled through its quiet interior, feeling the weight of history within its walls.
By late afternoon, it was time for me to meet up with some old colleagues from a previous job. Around 5 p.m., I grabbed a quick bite and made my way to Alexanderplatz, one of Berlin’s busiest and most famous squares. We spent the next few hours at Museum Island, a tranquil spot surrounded by stunning museums, and it was the perfect place to catch up and relax. As evening fell, we headed to a cozy bar nearby, where we shared stories, laughed, and reminisced about old times. The hours slipped away effortlessly — there’s nothing quite like the ease of conversation with familiar faces after so long apart.
The next day, October 27th, my friend had some time off, and he suggested we visit Teufelsberg, a unique and slightly offbeat destination. It was once a U.S. listening station during the Cold War, perched atop an artificial hill made from the rubble of WWII. Today, it’s known for its panoramic views and vibrant street art. We hopped on a train and made our way through the city, the excitement of exploring something new bubbling between us. After getting off at the station, we hiked through the Grunewald Forest. The autumn colors were at their peak, and the forest was alive with shades of amber, gold, and crimson. It was a peaceful walk, and the beauty of the season made it all the more special.
Teufelsberg itself was a fascinating place. The structure, abandoned and worn by time, was now a canvas for street artists. The walls were covered in colorful, intricate graffiti, each piece telling its own story. We spent hours wandering around, taking in both the art and the history of the place. The view from the top was breathtaking, offering a sweeping panorama of the city and the surrounding forest. It felt like a hidden gem, a place that not every tourist would think to visit.
Before heading back, we grabbed some Indian snacks at a nearby spot. Later that evening, we decided to make a simple but delicious dinner at home — Aglio olio. My friend had perfected the recipe, and it turned out to be a delightful meal.
The following day was more relaxed. After a leisurely breakfast, my friend gave me a mini-tour of his apartment, which had a fantastic view of the street below and a spacious terrace perfect for parties. The weather continued to surprise us, warm and sunny, which is rare for October in Germany. I spent the day revisiting some of the places I had already seen, this time at my own pace. Walking through the streets with my earphones in, I listened to Rick Steeve’s videos., taking in more of the city’s history and architecture. There’s something deeply satisfying about exploring a city on your own, taking the time to absorb its energy and appreciate its stories.
That evening, my friend invited me to dinner at a fancy Greek restaurant. It was my first time trying Greek food, and the dishes were amazing — rich, flavorful, and hearty. We were joined by a friend of his who was Greek, which made the experience even better as he explained the origins and significance of each dish. After our meal, we took a final stroll through the streets of Berlin. The city had left a lasting impression on me, with its mix of history, culture, and modern vibrancy.
The next morning, I caught my bus back to the Netherlands, reflecting on the incredible experiences of the past few days. Berlin had been everything I hoped for and more — both a journey through history and a personal adventure that I wouldn’t soon forget.

Title: Pope’s Revenge
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
This is the Fernsehturm Berlin, the TV tower. Built in the late ’60s, at 1206 feet it is the tallest structure in Germany and third tallest in Europe.
During the Cold War, there were two independent Germanies:
Berlin was entirely within East Germany but was divided into sectors, the US, French, British, and Soviet. Westerners were limited in going to Berlin in the first place, but getting to East Berlin was a major hassle.
There were three roads from West Germany to Berlin, and they were carefully monitored. None of my friends even considered trying that drive. There was also a rail service from Frankfurt to Berlin, the Berlin Duty Train. Like the three highways, carefully planning and getting the required approvals was essential for the train.
However, I did get to East Berlin for a couple of days in 1981. Co-worker Bill (of the Vienna trip fame) and I got a military hop from our base in West Germany to Berlin. Melinda, one of our friends, had just been transferred there as a protocol officer. Clever of us to have a friend in that business, wasn’t it? She had arranged rooms for us in the huge hotel at Tempelhof airport.
Because the city was still occupied, you couldn’t just go into East Berlin and wander around. We had to wear our military uniforms so you know how much we stood out among the locals.
My first thought when we started sightseeing was how stern all the people looked. Not that they disliked us, but like they were not enjoying life there. We saw lots of rubble still there from the war years. Guess I’d have expected more repair work to have been done by then, 1981.
Checkpoint Charlie was and is still known as a major symbol of the Cold War so we wanted to see it. It was the only approved checkpoint, walking or driving, for foreigners and military personnel. (Sorry, my picture isn’t too good; couldn’t Photoshop it enough.)
This is me, in uniform, at the Brandenburg Gate in the Soviet zone. People and vehicles could use it freely until August 1961 when the Berlin Wall was built. The Wall enclosed the entire city, passing right by the west side of the gate. President Ronald Reagan gave his famous ‘Tear down this wall’ speech near the Gate in June 1987. As you may remember, the Wall was ended in December 1989.
Thanks again to Melinda; we got a tour of West Berlin, the Wall, and even into East Berlin just a bit. She’d arranged a helicopter tour for a visiting US Air Force general. You know biggies often get special treatment and opportunities.
Since the General’s aide was the only other passenger, Melinda asked the General to take two visiting USAF officers. He kindly agreed. I’d been in a helicopter before, even saw the Tucson home of a mafioso kingpin from one! This trip was unique, a matter of international law, I guess. Flying over the Wall into the Soviet Zone was a huge no-no. But the crew said they did it regularly, just a brief crossover, to maintain US rights!
Is this cheating? It’s me at the Berlin Wall from the good guy side, on a different trip.
Now, about that TV tower…
Like the Brandenburg Gate, it is one of the most prominent symbols of Berlin. When the sun shines (as it does once in a while in Germany) it reflects on the tower’s dome in the shape of a Greek cross, a symbol against the East German removal of crosses from churches during the Cold War!
--
--
I’m an ex-teacher, WAF, newsletter writer, pseudo-techie, cancer survivor, cat mom. To paraphrase Jose Marti, before I die I want to send my little stories out.

Title: Berlin Beyond Borders
Berlin: A City Shaped by History, Innovation, and Urban Diversity
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
Share
Berlin has a complex history that has significantly shaped its urban landscape and development. As the capital of Germany, it has experienced monumental shifts over the centuries—transforming from a Prussian capital into a divided city during the Cold War and now into one of Europe’s most dynamic and modern cities. What makes Berlin so captivating is how its infrastructure and urban planning tell the story of a city constantly rebuilding and reinventing itself.
Berlin’s modern identity is rooted in a unique combination of historical events and urban resilience. Initially, Berlin was a modest settlement along the River Spree, but it gradually became a trade center during the Middle Ages. By the 18th century, Berlin had become the capital of Prussia, a major European power, and it underwent significant development under the rule of Frederick the Great. However, it wasn’t until the Industrial Revolution of the 19th century that Berlin truly began to transform into a major European metropolis. Factories, railroads, and grand boulevards like Unter den Linden were constructed, making Berlin a vital economic and cultural hub.

Title: Living History [Berlin, Germany]
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
My feeling about Berlin is still very conflicted. The city is full of culture, history and character, and yet, I can’t say that I love it. This surprises me given how many friends have only raved about Berlin. I fully expected to be a Berlin-lover, too. A week before we move onto our next stop, I still feel like we have so much to see. And we do. Even in 3.5 weeks, we haven’t ventured anywhere near all the nooks and crannies we know are worth seeing. One more weekend to make the most of! On the list: Mauerpark, the Pergamon or DDR Museum, graffiti tours, underworld visits, and other recommended bars and haunts.
One thing we have had the privilege of living through is the most recent German elections. I say “living through” lightly as we didn’t vote and honestly didn’t experience much fuss around the city other than some people demonstrating in front of Brandenburg Gate when we biked past it a couple of weeks ago. (Going to go by again this weekend to see what’s brewing now.) As you may know, Angela Merkel won another tenure as Chancellor of Germany but the relatively new far-right party of AfD (Alternative for Germany) garnered a whopping 12.6% of votes, making it Germany’s third largest party and marking the first time in 60 years that a far-right party has entered Parliament.
I won’t make this an in-depth political post, so I’ll pause here to recommend some reading if you’re interested in finding out more about how the AfD came about and some of the tactics it used to make its historical entry into the Bundestag (parliament).
What strikes me is that just last week, I was talking about how Germany’s efforts to remember its history and specifically its mistakes throughout history felt omnipresent throughout Berlin. I mentioned how the country makes a point to honor the victims of its past rather than their perpetrators. And then I read about how the AfD is rebelling against this practice, calling it weak and encouraging Germany to “take a more positive attitude towards its history.”
I had thought this attitude was quite positive already… How many countries are so open about their mistakes and actually make (sometimes unpopular) political decisions that demonstrate it has learned from them? Seeing Germany step up as the European country to accept the most refugees in need of a home at the peak of the refugee crisis in 2015 was a powerful moment for me. My family suffered first-hand from the Holocaust — 3 of my grandparents were in Auschwitz and lost their entire families. I never want any race or religion to suffer the same kind of persecution the Holocaust embodied. It’s not just the Holocaust — genocides in Rwanda and Armenia and Apartheid in South Africa are other recent examples of racism we in hindsight condemn and critique. The American Civil War and fight against slavery may have been over 150 years ago, but we still witness undeniable expressions of racism and rejection in the United States today.
That history is cyclical should not stand as an excuse to let it repeat itself. As I live through the repercussions of the Brexit vote, read about exaggerated travel bans and unsanctioned white nationalist/neo-nazi rallies, watch outspoken discriminating politicians slowly but surely claim more power in the Netherlands, France, Austria, now Germany under the guise of ‘nationalism’ and ‘identity’… I’m terrified kids one or two generations from now will be learning about these events as catalysts towards a larger global conflict I don’t even want to put a name on.
What does nationalism even mean today?
When talking about diversity in Germany with a couple of friends recently, they matter-of-factly stated that for example Russians and Turks are a central part of today’s Germany. You can’t imagine Berlin without kebab stands at every corner, they justly remarked.
The makeup of a country changes over time and what may have been a “pure” (debatable) population centuries ago is now mixed and enriched. To be nationalistic can mean to embrace this growth and diversity, rather than long for a past that alienates new- and otherness. With open economical borders, refugees escaping war-torn areas, broadening spirits and more informed, less fearful constituents, I would hope that European countries (and North American, and Middle Eastern…) choose to welcome and even promote this now globalized reality. Of course, there will always be people clamoring for “the good old days” and yes, some of the old days do have value and a country’s identity and history should also be preserved. I just hope we can work together to find a balance that doesn’t conflate identity with discrimination, and sadly the advancement of the AfD and the shift in its policy since its creation represent an upsetting setback.
I acknowledge this post is by no means a complete political commentary that compares both sides of the argument. It represents a few thoughts and concerns that have been weighing on my mind, and I welcome any comments or feedback to continue the discussion.
In the meantime, I’ll leave you with some of my favorite recent campaigns for acceptance and diversity before I resume my explorations of Berlin:

Thinking of making Berlin your new home?
Take these things into account for a smoother move.
A “Wahlberlinerin” (Berlin citizen by choice) explains.
Visiting my hometown in Groningen, the Netherlands feels like a breath of fresh air, as if I’m walking through a village. Most pedestrians on the street greet me with a smile and a nod.
It doesn’t work like that in Berlin.
You ignore one another. Some neighbors who accepted my packages in the past and certainly know who I am ignore me in any other setting.
It’s no different when walking on the street. No one greets you, you greet no one. If you do, expect frowns, very confused, or even scared looks.
The temperatures drop to or below zero during the winter months. People get moody, sulky, and the city turns bleak.
The only good thing about Berlin winters from the perspective of a Dutch person: it doesn’t rain…
