Title: What It’s Like to Volunteer at a Refugee Shelter in Berlin
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
2
Listen
Share
Have you ever wondered what it’s like to volunteer at a refugee shelter in Berlin?
I’ve been volunteering with the Berliner Stadtmission for the better part of a year now and work a shift at their shelter in Moabit almost every weekend. There’s a number of duties you can choose from, such as helping with laundry, to handing out hygiene products like shampoo and soap, to working in the kitchen.
As I like keeping busy and interacting with people, I always opt to work kitchen shifts.
The shelter’s tucked away on a quiet street in Moabit. Ironically not too far, but thankfully far enough, from the nightmare that is LaGeSo.
Finding the exact location of the shelter can be difficult for first-timers. Once you find the “house” number, there’s no building within immediate sight. You’ll see a Berliner Stadtmission sign. Walk past the sign and continue along a tree flanked path.
Directly beside the shelter, is a venue which plays host to different types of events. During the summer, I once walked past when they were holding a wedding. There was a small orchestra playing music, wait staff handing out hors-d’oeuvres, and elegantly dressed people sipping glasses of champagne.
On the other side of the shelter are some tennis courts and a soccer field. During the warmer months, it’s not uncommon to see the facilities put to use.
You also can’t help but notice the sheer number of BMWs, Jaguars, and Porsches parked nearby.
The juxtaposition of seeing two such distinct lifestyles physically side-by-side is jarring. The difference is not lost on the refugees, nor volunteers at the shelter.
It just feels weird and somehow wrong, even if no one is actually doing anything wrong.
Once you reach the end of the pathway, turn left. You can’t miss the shelter, which some of the refugees have come to refer to as “the balloon.”
The emergency shelter is a large domed structure, which can house up to 300 people. It contains dorm rooms that sleep six, a large dining area, a children’s play space, a working kitchen, and even, ping pong and kicker tables.
It’s the first inflatable structure for refugees in Germany. Although it was met with criticism when it was first built in the fall of 2014, due to a perceived lack of privacy and dignity for the refugees, the government is now looking to replicate this model elsewhere in the country. Much has changed since then and this shelter is one of now one of the better places a refugee can stay when in Berlin.
Entering the shelter is a challenge in itself. You open the first door and must wait for it to close behind you, before opening the second door. When you attempt to open the second door, there’s a sudden gush of wind, forcing you to push it really hard to actually get the door to open all the way.
Once you enter, you immediately notice how warm it is. It’s like being inside a hot yoga studio. At this point, my glasses usually steam up. I laugh, greet the security staff a friendly hello, and inform them that I’m working in the kitchen. They check for my name and then wave me in.
Walking towards the kitchen, I see familiar faces. While the shelter was first built to house refugees temporarily, for a few days maximum, due to the backlog in the processing of asylum applications, they often find themselves there for days or months at a time.
I smile at an Afghan man, who knows I’m from Canada. We’ve talked about his desire to relocate there and it hurts to know his chances of being able to do so are slim.
My most special friend, is a little Syrian girl named Alisa. She speaks fluent Arabic, some German, and even a bit of English. She once told me that she thinks she’s 20 years old, then later confessed that she’s only 10. She always offers up smiles, big hugs, and begs you not to leave when you’re shift is over. For fun, she likes to try on my sunglasses and pose like a model.
There’s also plenty of “hallos” and “wie gehts” from the other children as you walk to the kitchen.
Finally, I reach the kitchen and from there, the routine is second nature. I hang up my jacket, don an apron, write my name on a nametag, wash my hands, put on gloves, and set out to work. I find out who the kitchen leader is that day and ask them what they’d like me to do.
Often it’s drying dishes used from the previous meal and putting them away. Other times, it’s preparing the food, like chopping pickles into small pieces, putting bread into containers, and more.
The kitchen “boss” will approach the group at some point and ask them what they would like to do during the meal. Some prefer to spend the entire shift working with the dishwasher at the back. Others, like me, prefer to serve food. Some days, I’m the “banana lady” handing out fruity desserts because the kids treat you like you’re a superhero. I usually prefer to take the first position in our little assembly line, saying hello to the refugees, and asking them what they would like to start with.
Then it’s time to serve the meal. Note — when you volunteer, you can opt to work breakfast, lunch, or supper shifts.
At times, the crowds are small, with around 100 people. Other times, the shelter is filled to capacity and you’re serving crowds of up to 300 people.
A typical meal includes fish or chicken, bread, vegetables, and fruit. For obvious reasons, pork is never on the menu. Bananas seem to be the most popular and the kids will line-up multiple times to procure themselves another piece of fruit.
Shifts are usually fun, but sometimes they’re also really tough. There’s rules that need to be followed and sometimes the refugees are not happy with them.
When they lineup for food, all members of the family must be physically present. Sometimes, the kids are sleeping or are off playing outside. You have no choice but to refuse the mother and ask her to lineup again, with the kids in tow. As you can imagine, this does not always meet with a positive response.
Sometimes, they’ll ask for extra portions. You have to request that they eat what they have and get in line again for seconds. It’s only fair, as everyone needs to be fed before you go about doling out more food. It’s extremely hard saying no though, as you only want to be generous.
Language barriers are another problem. Refugees come from all over and speak a number of different languages, but German and English are not usually one of them. This makes communication very hard, especially when there’s not always translators around to explain things. All you can do is smile, try your best, and compromise as needed. Hand gestures and pointing help. Sneaking them extra bananas also helps to keep them happy, maintain the peace, and ensure the line’s moving.
Often the refugees don’t like the food being served, and if I was them, I’d feel the same. While the food is mostly good, there’s sometimes items on offer that I wouldn’t want to eat either.
I’ve noticed a growing trend lately and see that many leave, buying their food elsewhere. They return to the shelter later on and throw together a small meal that doesn’t require any cooking preparation (they are not permitted access to the shelter’s kitchen facilities). Sometimes, it’s something as simple as cheese and bread.
After the first wave of people have taken their meal, they begin queuing up for seconds, thirds, and so on. We pass out food until everything’s gone, before closing the blinds to signal the kitchen is closed.
The real work starts at this point. There’s dishes to wash, dry, and put away. Counters to be scrubbed clean. Floors to be vacuumed, etc.
At some point, the volunteers take a break and eat a small meal together. This is my favourite time, as it’s nice to get to know the other volunteers and what motivates them to be there.
As time passes, you start to see the same people, so instead of exchanging the typical hellos, we hug and give each other high fives. Other times, there’s people on a short holiday, who actually take time from their vacation to volunteer with refugees. If I knew them better and they wouldn’t think I was weird for doing so, I’d hug them too for being so awesome.
The conversation during our break is always interesting. More often than not, it centers around politics and current events. Hearing the perspective of the paid full-time staff is always eye opening, as they are dealing with the refugee crisis on a day-to-day basis. They worry about the ineffectiveness of LaGeSo, how long refugees are stuck in limbo, and how hard it will be to integrate them into German society so they can go to school, secure work, and so on.
This particular shelter is supported by 1,300 volunteers and I’m proud to be one of them. The fact that people show up regularly and give up their free time is simply inspiring.
Groups like Serve the City come in and do art sessions with the kids, musicians come in and perform opera, while others just come in for coffee and conversation with the refugees.
I met a German man, who once took a group of male refugees out for an evening of billiards. Another girl who owns some dogs, organized an event last weekend, where she took out some of the kids and parents to a nearby park to walk and play with her dogs. Volunteers also come in daily to facilitate German language classes.
While Germany, not to mention the city of Berlin itself, may be mishandling the crisis, volunteers and charities are everything right now. If it wasn’t for them, conditions for refugees would be much worse.
For more information about the “balloon” shelter in Moabit, read this NPR Berlin piece.
If you’re interested in being a volunteer at a refugee shelter in Berlin (specifically this one), you can book a shift through vostel.de.
You can also request to be added to Berliner Stadtmission’s mailing list. They send weekly emails, allowing you to book a shift on a date and time that’s convenient for you.
--
--
2
A Canadian from Toronto in Berlin. Agile coach working in tech. Travel blogger @cherylhowardcom.

Title: How I almost got scammed looking for an apartment in Berlin
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
20
Listen
Share
Looking for an apartment in Berlin in 2017 is a madhouse. I’ve been doing it for about 2 weeks now, as I’ll be starting a new job in the city, but I’ve heard stories of people, who are living in temporary accommodations for months before finding a flat. One guy summed it up perfectly in this comment on Facebook, under a job seeker post:
Jobs are plenty in Berlin, it’s harder to find a place to live.
That being said, imagine my surprise when I received the following e-mail:
Rough translation:
“Dear Rumen,
Yes the room is still free. Please, write me something about yourself. Age, occupation, nationality, etc. I’m sorry to bother you.
It would be nice if you could tell a little bit about yourself to see if it’ll work out.
Photos, rent, deposit and address of the apartment will be disposed to your knowledge.
Good morning,
Best regards,
Christoph”
Most of you might say, of course it’s a scam, look at the inadequate writing. But imagine being desperate to find a place to live. You’re racing against time and you finally receive an answer. You really want to believe that it’s true and you start thinking about excuses. Maybe he’s not German, that’s why the writing is so bad — maybe he’s using Google Translate. Maybe he was in a hurry, because he has to answer a lot of e-mails.
I answered Christoph’s e-mail with a little bit of details about myself, why I’m coming to Berlin and included some of my social media profiles, you know, to prove I’m not a fake person. Shortly after, I get the following e-mail from Chris:
Rough translation:
“Good day Rumen,
Thank you for the information. That sounds perfect. I’m happy to meet you. The apartment is centrally heated and well furnished. The 20 sq.m. room is completely equipped, has wlan internet.
The room is located on a cross road, one has to be a little noise resistant if the windows are open. The windows are well isolated, if closed, there’s no problem with noise.
The flat itself is well organised, your room is next to the living room with a big TV, table and a corner for chilling. The kitchen is equipped with a built-in kitchen (incl. washing machine and fridge). There’s a table with 8 chairs in the living room. There’s a mirror in the bathroom, as well as a sink with a cabinet. (…)
The surroundings are excellent. Lots of places to buy stuff, cafes, restaurants are directly around the corner. Additionally, you can reach bars, clubs, markets and galleries within minutes walking distans.
Address — Friedenstrasse 36 10249 Berlin Friedrichshain
Monthly rent (all incl.)—350 EUR
Deposit (refundable) — 700 EUR
Side expenses are included in the rent. If you think it can work out I can write a little bit about myself. I would be happy to get an answer from you.
Attached, you can see some photos of the apartment.”
As I mentioned, the first red flag was the weird wording, which became evident with every next e-mail. Aside from the fact that the deal seems too good to be true, it’s also odd that someone offering an apartment would spend so much time writing long e-mails with detailed descriptions. People who post apartment offers receive hundreds of e-mails per week. Having a multi-email discussion with a single potential tenant is not likely. Still, all the small suspicions I was having were plausibly deniable. So I continued, telling Christoph the offer sounds good and that he can tell me a little bit about himself. I also asked if he could share his FB profile. The e-mail I received back was in English.
As you can see, the wording is still a bit off. The guy says he’s “half German and half UK”, but evidently can’t write properly in either language. Again, it’s a much longer e-mail than I would’ve expected, but an accusation like that sounds silly by itself — “I don’t trust this guy because he writes lenghty e-mails.” Maybe the guy likes to express himself.
It’s interesting how he mentions important details mixed inbetween marginal information. He says there’s a desk for reading in the room and that I need to pay two months rent plus the deposit up front, all in the same sentence. Conveniently, he also doesn’t use Facebook, so he couldn’t send me a profile. Other than that, everything is jolly good and we’d be living together as besties. At this point, I write how wonderful of a person he seems and that I think we’ll get along excellently. I also asked if a friend of mine could come by and have a look at the apartment, since I’ll be arriving in Berlin in two weeks. The plot thickened.
Christoph actually sent me a copy of his ID card, as well as a scanned flight ticket from Warsaw to Berlin for the 23. December. The ID card looks very real, which confused me for a second. Then again, there’s no information about a person of that name anywhere on the Internet.
It’s a well thought through plot. He provides bits of information spread out in several e-mails, before delivering the final detail. He’s not actually in Berlin, but he’ll send me the keys. I assumed it’s self-explanatory that I’ll have to pay him the money upfront. Still, I asked him to describe step by step how he imagines this would go down.
I wrote back a short reply, saying this is getting absurd. I also asked if renting is normally done this way. Chris wrote:
This is where I lost interest in playing along and told Chris I won’t be going forward with his offer.
Perhaps I should’ve pushed a bit further to see how far things would go. I could’ve also messed around with him a little bit to have something to laugh about with my mates. But to be honest, I neither have time, nor am I in the mood. After all, I need to continue looking for an apartment, just like all the hundreds (thousands?) of people sending e-mails every day.
It makes me sad that there are so many individuals trying to scam people and this probably makes everyone trust each other less. My point is to be careful what you agree on (especially on the Internet) and always consider things carefully even when you’re pressed by time or other circumstances.

Title: Characters in Berlin
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Listen
Share
But what exactly is Pictoplasma? Similar to the question posed in “The Matrix,” I found myself needing to discover the answer for myself. Let me explain: In 2004, I bought the first Pictoplasma character book in a bookstore in Switzerland and was completely captivated. I also visited their very informative website at the time and gathered that it was a meeting for character designers. Since that day, I wanted to attend Pictoplasma myself. However, it took me 20 years to finally make it. So in May 2024, I attended the conference in Berlin. On the first day, I felt a bit overwhelmed, not because of what was offered, but due to the organization. Everyone had to wait patiently until they could register. I felt a bit lost, but around 3:30 PM, things finally got started. I went to the registration and then directly to the first exhibitions by the artists who would be giving talks in the coming days. I saw some of the works and took them in. Then I wandered around the venue for a while.
The next day, the conference truly kicked off. According to the program, some highly renowned artists from the scene had gathered in Berlin. I attended talks by Joe Bennett, a young designer and animator from the USA. He recently made waves with his series “Scavenger Reign” on HBOMax, a sci-fi series that looks like it could have come from the mind of the artist Moebius. He has been working on this series for over seven years, and it will be available on Netflix in the coming months. His other works for Adult Swim and Fox also stand out, characterized by a quirky but endearing sense of humor.
Additionally, the artist duo “Los Calladitos” really impressed me. Their stunning murals depicting a fantastical world centered around the preservation of light captivated me. They work on their pieces with incredible care and creativity. They also showed some animations from their own film, which brought even more life to their characters and world. Unfortunately, I missed a talk by Peter The Roman, an artist known for experimenting with AI in his 3D worlds. However, I saw some of his works in the exhibitions spread across various locations in Berlin. Overall, 20 artists participated, giving talks and workshops.
But what sets Pictoplasma apart? It’s not merely a stage for artists; it’s also one of the largest communities in the realm of character art and animation. The “Artist Talks” provided profound insights into the world of artists: their methodologies, how they develop ideas and strategies, and how they publish, sell, and make a living from their art. It’s a platform for exchange and collaboration, bringing creatives from diverse backgrounds together. Moreover, the conference reflects the zeitgeist of 2024. In a world dominated by AI, Pictoplasma artists emphasize the importance of emotion and craftsmanship. It became evident that while AI is a valuable tool for ideation, the execution of most artists’ works remains in human hands. This realization, which I suspected before Pictoplasma, was confirmed and reinforced during the event. Indeed, the use of AI elevates the significance of handmade art. Consider, for instance, the wooden figures crafted by artist Parn “Ani” Aniwat, who carves more than 30 charming characters each month. Or reflect on Los Calladitos, who seamlessly transfer their unique style from the vast walls of their murals to their animated films. Even the ceramic lamps crafted by Portuguese artist and entrepreneur Ana Seixas demonstrate how handmade artworks garner special relevance and appreciation. Ultimately, one desires to touch the art that inundates our digital world.
All the days at Pictoplasma were incredibly lively and full of inspiration. One of the most interesting talks was by Philip Hunt, a creative director at AKA Studios from the UK. He shared his experiences and insights about design and art, particularly regarding the film industry and the challenges of adapting a children’s book like “Here We Are” by Oliver Jeffers into a film. He discussed the extensive thought and effort required to translate beautifully drawn 2D characters into a 3D medium. After many ideas and experiments, he and his team successfully turned the book into a beautiful film, which can be admired on Apple TV. By chance, I met Philip on Sunday, the last day of Pictoplasma, at a small flea market in Berlin. I approached him because I didn’t get the chance to talk to him at the event. We had a pleasant conversation about the industry, covering topics like advertising, films, and other media. He asked me how I found Pictoplasma, and I told him that initially, I didn’t know what to expect or what I would take away from it. He responded that each year, he takes away inspiration and a reminder of why he continues his work. He loves attending Pictoplasma, getting inspired by other artists, and gaining a perspective beyond commercial work. He also shared that he attended the first Pictoplasma 20 years ago and didn’t know what it was about back then either. Now, he teaches workshops and helps lead the Pictoplasma Academy. It was a very enjoyable conversation. So, what makes Pictoplasma so special? It’s the chance to see designers and artists doing something different from just working on commercial projects. This is something I can definitely take away from it. I was deeply moved by the following artist talks. One of them was by the artist Parn “Ani” Aniwat. Out of necessity, he began carving small figures out of wood. Now, he makes 30 pieces a month — small, cute characters that he sells to collectors and exhibitors. It has become his business. He gave us a glimpse into his workday, which runs from 9 to 5, after which he spends time with his family, sketches ideas, and watches Netflix. The same goes for the Portuguese artist and entrepreneur Ana Seixas. During the pandemic, she started working with pottery and created clay lamp characters that sold faster in her shop than she could make them.
Of course, even at a conference focused on hand-drawn, painted, or crafted characters, the topic of artificial intelligence can’t be avoided. Some artists use AI as a tool to support their ideas. However, despite the technology and digital capabilities that AI offers, traditional craftsmanship remains one of the most important aspects. While no one insists that art must be created by hand, most artists still find themselves holding a pencil or an Apple Pencil. One of the most memorable statements about AI came from Philip Hunt. A young designer from the audience asked him whether she should focus more on AI. He responded that she should focus on drawing, as AI will inevitably come. But drawing with a pencil would always convey ideas better (or something along those lines; I’m not certain of the exact wording). Another artist, possibly Christopher Rutledge, mentioned that AI is a useful tool but compared it to mastering image databases or programs like Photoshop or After Effects. Artists have shown that they engage with AI, but in the end, it’s their ideas and visions that they bring to life. For the past few months, I’ve felt that we are returning to an era of “handmade” artistry, especially in art, film, and design. With the overproduction of AI-generated images and texts, which now look and read quite well, the personal touch is often missing. A good example is animator Joe Taylor, who makes his style unmistakable with hand-drawn loops that resemble flat designs from claymation. He showcased a commercial clip for the ProCreate app, which he both drew and animated using their software.
Aside from the talks, there were workshops, exhibitions, and parties. Unfortunately, I couldn’t attend all the talks or everything that was offered. Given that Berlin is a very large city and the event organizers thought it would be a good idea to use various locations across the city, it wasn’t easy to be everywhere. There was also an AR scavenger hunt called Character Hunt, where participants had to travel around Berlin using the Adobe Aero app to view the characters. Great ideas, but too little time to experience everything. Attending Pictoplasma was a fascinating journey into the realm of art, characters, and animation. It was far more than I could have ever imagined back then. For me, it was a significant source of inspiration for my work as a designer. Here, I could discover new perspectives and gain a wealth of inspiration.
The most captivating talk was also the last one of Pictoplasma. It was by Mila Useche from Colombia. She is an artist and filmmaker who had a tough journey. She had to fight hard in the working world, including working for a game company where she worked up to 15 hours a day. She then became a freelancer, working for studios like Disney, Warner Brothers, Nickelodeon, and Netflix. She also worked on her own concepts and film ideas. One of these is currently being realized in a German-Colombian co-production.
Recently, there has been a crisis in many animation studios in the USA, with widespread layoffs and job cuts. Adding to this were the aftermath of the pandemic and the surge of companies eager to use AI. Mila needed to find a way out, so she began sharing her hand-drawn images on Instagram, reaching many people who celebrated her art. She now lives in Japan, where she produces her art and characters. That was Pictoplasma 2024. A few days in another world, a world full of inspiration, art, characters, and animated films. Just a different kind of matrix.

After 19 months of closure, Berghain’s doors have opened once more. You don’t need to be a techno Viking to know of its existence. As a newbie to Berlin, I’ve yet to try breaching the seemingly impenetrable doors of the ‘World Capital of Techno’ but maybe you have? How was it? If not, fear not.
Recently I came across this trainer created by sansho. the studio which helps you get in the mood — replacing the aforementioned fear (No? Just me?) with a feel of the place instead. Title: Captivating Interwar Modernism in Berlin. Part 1
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Street photography about overlooked architecture. Ukraine, Germany, Netherlands, etc.

--
2
Listen
Share
A hundred years ago, Berlin was among the biggest cities in the world as its population rapidly grew from 2 to 4,5 million. Just imagine the demand for new housing at that time! Eventually, the city became a testing ground for architectors’ creativity and social experiments.
Passionate about the ideas of affordable mass housing, modernists were trying to make utopia come true — create cheap, standard, and, if possible, lovely houses. Not to mention, it was also a time of the Nazi’s rise to power. Nowadays, pretty small apartments and compact blocks are concealed by colored plaster, original door patterns, and manicured lawns. I’m sure that living in these houses may feel totally different from the careless meditation of a passerby. We are privileged to observe modernist estates from a distance of decades and draw our own conclusions.
This piece should have started with a bird’s-eye view of the horseshoe-shaped building, but let’s leave it to the birds. City explorers like you and me, not aided by drones or helicopters, see this site differently. When I came, the frost was gleaming on the grass in shadows, and the sun shone gently through a gap between “horseshoe” edges.
The Horseshoe Colony is a complex of townhouses and 3-story blocks of flats, and the central one — as you might have guessed — is curved like a horseshoe. A humble memorial stone at the pond tells this estate was designed by Bruno Taut and built between 1925 and 1933.
I was lucky enough to visit the Horseshoe Colony twice, at dawn and dusk, although it took me an hour to reach Britz, a part of the Neukölln district. As I left the metro, sunlit rosy-and-tartare houses with fiery doors popped up. At first, I was walking past them pretty fast, not realizing they were also part of the architectural ensemble — not just the shaped block.
I didn’t expect such a burst of color either because the whole modernist architecture (and Bauhaus in particular) had always seemed minimalistic and monochrome to me before.
Although this estate appeared as affordable housing for rapidly growing Berlin, it was designed with privacy in mind, thus feeling neither fully urban nor entirely rural. In this densely populated area, you’ll notice a lot of hedged yards with lovely arbors, swings, braziers, beds of flowers, and other attributes of carefree leisure.
The Horseshoe Colony doesn’t look luxurious; however, it gives space for individuality and embodies a passion for detail. I spotted a dozen door variations. My favorite ones are the black-framed ones with colorful rectangles in the middle. You can hardly find the same building color and door pattern combination twice.
But let’s turn back to the horseshoe building for a while. What amazed me the most about it was the optical effect of using sky-blue paint. Loggias look like holes in the building, and you can pretend to see the sky through them. As a result, this pretty massive building doesn’t feel overwhelming.
I noticed something about color that would also be relevant to other housing estates in this article. So, color is probably, the cheapest way to convey style, whereas columns or sculptures require a lot of work and material. It’s remarkable how modernists used the power of color, creating affordable yet original housing.
And the icing on the cake — a crimson wall, which turned out to be just the opposite side of those tartare houses I mentioned at the beginning. The setting sun cast its light on the wall, and the windows and balcony frames got lilac. After all this, I did realize why this settlement gained its status as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
I left the Horseshoe Colony after sunset. Black silhouettes emerged from the gloom but didn’t obstruct the sky view. If you stand on the stairs between the horseshoe edges, you’ll see magnificent scenery — the sun sets behind the building, people switch on the lamps, and this light reflects on the surface of the inner pond.
You can easily spot the White City from afar. Its white minimalist geometry stands out among yellowish houses nearby, and the five-story corner towers, like guardians, stand on both sides of the street, Aroser Allee. This housing estate in the district of Reinickendorf was built in 1928–1931 and turned out to be the last modernist quarter of the Weimar era.
The key role in the White City design belongs to Otto Rudolf Salvisberg. The central structure of this ensemble is like a sea resort hotel hovering above the street. I hate when parked cars spoil the picture, so I squatted in the middle of the boulevard and shot through a hole in the hedge, thus “hiding” the vehicles behind the bushes.
And how can an authentic German building be without a clock on its top?
Look! Another clock on the opposite side of the same building. I adore how classical modernist architects could create a style with the simplest geometric shapes: squares, circles, and rectangles. Although all the buildings generally look uniform, they have numerous unique parts — like these clocks.
Now, the doors. Doors are where modernist architects burst into various color combinations and rectangle compositions. Bright red and blue doors look incredibly vivid on the white facades.
Not to mention gorgeous blue windows along the staircase, an eye-catching stripe of volume on a flat facade.
A couple of paragraphs above, I mentioned so-called “towers,” higher parts of the corner buildings. So, I found five of them: two large towers on both sides of Aroser Allee and three narrow ones at the corner of Emmentaler Straße and Genfer Straße. They create a distinctive border with other buildings and hold the borders of this settlement.
I had visited the White City before chestnuts and poplars started blooming and one more time after trees went green. In spring, there is a short period when the sun is bright enough to make the walls sparkle, but the trees, still leafless, don’t obstruct the view. I was happy to enjoy this contrast between glaring facades and black trunks.
My final unexpected observation was red and blue bands underneath the roofs. On the one side of the street — blue; on the other side — red. Pre-war architects used to leave numerous unobvious details, aesthetic gifts for an attentive urban wanderer. By the way, White City also is UNESCO-protected and part of the Berlin modernism heritage.
Call me old-fashioned, but the number of floors in a residential building should be a one-digit number. For example, five. It seems compact enough and doesn’t turn a house into an ugly “anthill” similar to Soviet-time quarters in East Berlin. I decided to check the Carl Legien Settlement late in the evening, just before sunset.
This housing estate is located a 5-minute walk from the station Prenzlauer Berg in a district of the same name. Like many buildings displayed in this article, it appeared between 1928 and 1930 and was designed by Bruno Taut and Franz Hillinger.
Carl Legien estate is more uniform than, for instance, Horseshoe Colony, but belongs to UNESCO World Heritage, too. Its buildings don’t have varying characteristics like doors or facade colors. What fascinated me the most was the pinkish tint of the walls and, of course, red, yellow, and blue frames. Gazing at them, I immediately recalled paintings by Piet Mondrian.
And again, we observe the same simplicity and minimal expressive means — no columns, no sculptures, no molding. Rounded balconies and loggias are all facing the inner yard, and I guess it must create a feeling of privacy and own space for the dwellers.
Not many buildings in Berlin have bare brick facades. Brick is typical for factories and warehouses, but most residential estates are plastered and painted in pastel colors. However, the UNESCO World Heritage complex at Shiller Park stands out; the exposed concrete grid of balconies and ochre walls immediately drew my attention. It was designed by our good old friend Bruno Taut and constructed in 1924–1930.
I noticed a bright green car on the street between the historic houses and decided to look closer. Like the settlement itself, the car turned out to be also vintage. Citroën 2CV was a popular economy vehicle in the 1950s, and it fitted in here so well. The phrase on the car, “I fly bleifrei,” is a pun. In German, “bleifrei” means “lead-free” or “unleaded” (without added tetraethyl lead), which is a characteristic of petrol or paint. This motto and a cute duck mascot made me smile.
I noticed the streets where this estate stood were named after English cities — Bristolstraße, Dubliner Straße, Oxforer Straße, and Windsorer Straße. Later I understood why — in Google Maps, this area was called the English Quarter. Except for the car and street names, there were some other beautiful details, like a white doily in one of the windows.
The way how I instantly spot historically significant buildings in Berlin is by well-preserved wooden doors and windows. Look at these bold red frames. If the door is original, not a later replacement, the paint must have been scratched off and carefully repainted a dozen times. Paint sagging and overshooting on the glass look so heartwarming and naive when you can visualize the story behind it.
At the end of that walk, I was thinking about the balconies, which were half-glazed and half-opened. Large windows with white “skeletons” created the impression of porches. Maybe this is why so many local dwellers have beds of flowers, sun umbrellas, and chairs on their balconies. It’s a blessing when your home has a special place to meditate, sipping coffee to the sounds of birds’ songs.
It’s getting more challenging to impress you with Berlin modernism, but I’ll try. The ace up my sleeve is this lovely settlement on the southeastern outskirts of Berlin. It was built a bit earlier than most estates introduced here, in 1913–1916, and the design belongs to — surprise! — Bruno Taut.
While walking and taking pictures, I felt uncomfortable — like an obnoxious intruder or a guy chewing popcorn and slurping beer at the museum. Fortunately, there is little chance you disturb someone at 6 a.m. on Saturday because people (except for me though) prefer to bask in bed a bit longer. But my weird pleasure is to stay one-on-one with architecture and avoid city dwellers casting suspicious glances at me.
This settlement is probably the richest in styles and colors and feels specially designed for vacationing. Not surprisingly, it’s called “Gartenstadt” (garden city) in German and belongs to UNESCO World Heritage.
All the buildings have two or three floors, bright wooden shutters, and terraces. Even though most houses are arranged in blocks, they don’t feel like dull clones.
On some doors, I saw eye-shaped stickers with a silhouette of a thief and a phrase in German, “Neighbours are watching.” I don’t know about you, folks, but to me, this is a typical village security system when people notice more than any video surveillance from highly urbanized districts.
So far, the “garden city” was primarily painted in warm colors: orange, red, and yellow; however, it has a winter-cold section, too. If I happened to choose my favorite building here, I’d choose this stunning blue villa. The tree, in the shade of which it stands, seems to be at least a century old, planted at the times of settlement construction.
Sorry, I cannot overcome a desire to show you the lovely doors of Falkenberg once again in detail. See how carefully a trellis (this white frame for supporting climbing plants) is covered with a sheet of glass. Residents’ needs might have changed over time, but they didn’t spoil the initial design with a massive overhang. And the red door below, besides being amazingly beautiful, has a sticker I’ve already told you about.
Did you think there was just one blue house in the garden city of Falkenberg? Here is another one. You can compare how differently the same tone looks in the sun and after the sunset. In the light, it is glossy, and in the gloom, it gets matte and soft like a gouache drawing.
It was pretty late when I headed back to the station, yet I couldn’t miss an opportunity to take one more picture. What a combination of a cold-blue sky and pavement and orange-warm lights and a bush.
I’m not overwhelming you with historical facts from Wikipedia, so you should have some energy left to cope with the last chapter. This so-called “Waldsiedlung” (forest settlement) is located in one of the most picturesque districts of Berlin, Zehlendorf. You cannot take a single photo here without capturing at least one pine.
All the previous modernist settlements were located 5–10 minutes from the nearest train stations, but this one surrounds the station with an unusual name, “Uncle Tom’s Hut.” These beautiful 2–3-story blocks of flats and townhouses were finished between 1926 and 1931. Could it happen without Bruno Taut? Of course, no, folks. And Taut was accompanied by fellow architects Hugo Häring and Otto Rudolf Salvisber, whom I mentioned many times in this and previous articles.
Onkel Toms Hütte, unfortunately, hasn’t been (yet?) honored with the status of UNESCO World Heritage and remains the only settlement in this article without this status. However, it doesn’t mean city authorities neglect its preservation. All the buildings look well-maintained and don’t have noticeable stains on their bright facades.
In childhood, my granny dressed me in not-so-new grey and brown stuff because she knew I’d be dirty by the end of the day. A residential building is something people “use” very often, and why the hell do you make it so bright? I admire the courage of architects who cared about the dwellers’ moods, too. It is much more pleasant to live in a place that also pleases your eyes than just a practical and robust apartment!
My poor German skills, though, were sufficient to interpret gorgeous letters on the building below. It must have been a hairdresser’s workplace, but now it looks unoccupied by any business.
The shadows were growing higher and getting longer. Time to return home and view all the photos taken that day…
The second part →

Title: The Berlin Philharmonic Logo Is an Example of Design Excellence
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

A publication by and for marketers. We publish marketing inspiration, case studies, career advice, tutorials, industry news, and more.

--
3
Listen
Share
One of my favorite hobbies is collecting inspirations of art and design I come across while browsing the internet. Thanks to those new “save” features in apps like Pinterest or Instagram, I’m able to build little digital art museums for myself. I have thousands of “saved” pictures, from vintage photography to exotic art collage. One day I caught myself amused by the simple, elegant, extremely creative logo of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra.
Whatever your career is, imagine yourself designing an orchestra logotype. First, you’d take a look at previous creations: mostly elegant curve-shaped designs with ornamental details or typographies. In color patterns, you’d see a majority of red, black and white, sometimes blue or green.
Second, you’d might brainstorm general aspects of orchestras. I’ll help: Tradition. Old Style. Chic. Elegant. Perfection. Beauty. Cult. Deep emotions. Beethoven. The frequency of sound wave. Instruments. Symphonies. The treble clef. The air-drawn lines of a baton.
The ordinary “elegant curve-shaped designs” illustrates these round elements of an orchestra. Music is not “straight”. Emotions are not “straight”. What about the color pattern? They are clearly trying to call attention, communicate passion (red tones) in a classic and elegant way (black, white tones) with notes of respectfulness or loyalty (blue, green tones).
The access to a huge source of inspiration enables the creation of my little digital museums, but it also harms uniqueness. You can create something beautiful and well constructed, but it’s easy to fall into ordinary. You can find many “how-to-do-a-beautiful-orchestra-logo-in-10-steps”, but the real challenge is to be creative and unique and still carry the message you are trying to transmit.
Well, here is why the Berlin Philharmonic logotype owned it:
This overlapped series of pentagon forms (straight lines), instead of illustrating common aspects of an orchestra, communicates the masterful architectural work of Hans Scharoun (1832–1972) for the orchestra’s concert hall, previously all fan or shoebox shaped.
The chosen yellow, a color that’s uncommon for this market, grabs attention, transmits creativity, motivation, optimism, and warmth. That conveys the Berlin Philharmonic is a modern, vivid, joyful orchestra but also warm — musically and emotionally deep.
There is also an easter egg: The overlapped pentagons clearly but not perfectly represent the floor plan of the concert hall. These overlapped pentagons suggest, besides all, a circular movement:
Yes. Circular. Do I have to say more? The logotype merges, in an exquisite way, an architectural uniqueness that characterizes the Berlin Philharmonic, without forgetting the musicality, elegancy, and round elements that surrounds an orchestra. All of those represented, with not a single curve.
“Good design is obvious. Great design is transparent.”
— Joe Sparano

Title: A Journey to Berlin: Networking
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up

“The strength of career success lies in the power of networking.” - Omotola E.O.
I shared in my previous post about my speaking engagement in Berlin at FOSS Backstage, where I spoke on Contributors’ Engagement and Monetization Opportunities.
In this series, I’ll share some of the new connections I made on this trip, particularly at the FOSS Backstage event.
This is my first international trip outside of Africa. I got the feeling you get when you go to a different country and meet people from different cultures. The good thing is I was already looking forward to connecting, learning new cultures, and having a good time.
I did! I met some cool folks from different organizations and career paths. One thing that brought us together is our love for open source.
Among many other connections I made at this conference, meeting with Outreachy mentors was one of my highlights.
I met with Antonin Delpeuch, an Open Refine community mentor, and Jarek Potiuk, an OpenStack community mentor.
We discussed their experience as an Outreachy mentor, how the program has benefited their projects, and them as a mentor. It’s good to hear them talk about what excites them about Outreachy applicants and interns and how the program has enhanced their projects.
After the conference, I had a good dinner with Antonin Delpeuch, and we talked more about the future of open source and outreach programs. We also shared individual goals, our steps, and what we see in open source.
It was such a great privilege to not only meet with other open source advocates who are interested in what the Outreachy program does but to learn more about how open source experts and the community can get involved, the benefit of the program to mentors, and the steps and requirements to participate in the program.
I was able to preach the gospel of Outreachy to these fantastic folks and build and strengthen their knowledge about the program and relationship. Looking forward to further connecting with them and having them support diversity in tech through the Outreachy program.
Until the next and final series, I will share my experience exploring the great Berlin. Mach’s gut (Welle)!

Title: Quirky, Grungy, Cool: Berlin
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

This publication is dedicated to learning about the world around us. The topics covered here range from travel and geography to languages and cultures.

--
1
Listen
Share
One day I found myself on a flight to Berlin, Germany. Berlin didn’t even rank within the top ten places to visit on my list but I had to go for work, so why not enjoy this obligatory adventure? I had heard that Berlin was moody and grungy, like the emo child of Europe except it’s not “just a phase”. I was prepared to be met with a lot of punk rock and broody, techno vibes but (as is custom when traveling) I discovered the unexpected.
I landed in the mid evening in Berlin and my colleagues and I were starving and excited to sample Berlin cuisine. Three of us were American and were humbly disappointed that many restaurants nearby were already closed — how inconvenient! It’s usually good to be humbled like this as an American abroad, it definitely enriches one’s character. We did manage to find — what else —but a McDonalds. At this moment, I was less than dazzled by Berlin’s seemingly inaccessible evening meal options but figured it could only get better from here.
In the days that followed, I found Berlin to be a fascinating albeit (at times) icy, bustling city of natives, expats and tourists with cool modern buildings and large boulevards. While the overtone of German austerity, order and efficiency was undeniable, there were surprising pockets of whimsy mixed in here and there.
My personal favorite site was the Brandenburg Gate. A stunning piece of architecture with a lot of history and easily one of the most recognizable landmarks of Berlin.
I also visited Checkpoint Charlie, which was historically the Berlin Wall crossing point. This was a quirky museum overflowing with objects large and small, significant to a major turning point in German history. Not too far from the Brandenburg Gate was the beautiful, lush state park called the Tiergarten. Dense with trees, I would describe the Tiergarten as “Central Park with European elegance” — definitely another favorite location.
While Berlin certainly had highlights of grunge, some parts were charming and even rather quirky with fun thrift stores, local farmer’s markets and the unexpected hipster-style cafe.
Before traveling to Berlin, I was looking forward to sampling famous local fare (currywurst and sauerkraut of course) but Berlin also had much to offer in terms of international cuisine, with a lot of Turkish influences. I made it a priority to sample at least one döner kebab (something I would describe as a cross between shawarma and a sub sandwich) and it did not disappoint. To date, one of the best breakfasts of my life (avocado toast, covered in sautéed mushrooms over thick, fresh bread) was at a highly aesthetic cafe called Kaffee Karamell Berlin. And when I finally got my fork into some local sauerkraut, I knew that I was ruined for any canned, store-bought variety…forever. At the end of my trip I discovered that Berlin was certainly more complex than I had originally imagined. Quirky, grungy, cool, refined, steeped in history yet unapologetically modern, a bit edgy with it’s soft sides as well. Snag your ticket to Berlin and see for yourself!

Title: Believing the Unbelievable: Berlin at 80
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I was in Berlin, Germany, on May 8th; the 80th anniversary of the day that German forces surrendered unconditionally to the Allies, marking the end of WW2 in Europe. This day is sometimes referred to as “VE Day” (Victory in Europe Day). What a fitting place to be for this momentous occasion.
I have been in Berlin twice before. My first visit, in the summer of 1963 when I was 15 years old, was as part of a “teen tour” of Europe. Asleep in a Berlin hotel, I was awakened by gunfire. The construction of the Berlin Wall (at first, a barbed wire fence) began in August 1961 and in the years following, many people were shot as they tried to escape from East into West Berlin.
My second visit was 24 years ago, as part of a small group from the US Holocaust Memorial Museum, visiting historic sites in Eastern Europe that included memorials, museums, and several concentration camps. Sachsenhausen, one such camp near Berlin, is in the village of Oranienburg. It began as a slave labor camp for “political prisoners” with many subcamps. Still visible are barracks and the ruins of buildings in which remain the remnants of a gas chamber, medical experimentation areas, torture and killing areas, and several crematoria. Prisoners were treated inhumanely, inadequately fed, and openly killed. If you are reading this article, you probably know the list of who would be considered enemies of the state. A partial list includes those against the Reich whether they were Christian, Protestant, Jewish, Coptic, Roma, Communists, Gays, and anyone who was perceived to be mentally or physically disabled. This camp, not unlike others, was not on the outskirts of town. It was in the town. An alleyway separates the town from the gates to the camp with the words “Arbeit Macht Frei” (Works Sets You Free) welded into the gate. This place was not hidden. Quite the contrary, it was wide open to view and more importantly to odor. With several crematoria where bodies were burned, the smell and the ash wafted over the town, falling onto people’s rose gardens as well as onto the town residents themselves.
But I digress. Twenty four years ago, when I visited this camp, there was a person with us who, as a young man, had been a prisoner in Sachsenhausen. Somehow, miraculously, he survived. A Christian man, he had been a journalist, soon to be married, but that did not happen. It was a privilege to see the camp through his eyes, and listen as he recounted his experiences, some of which he had thought he buried along with his fellow inmates.
This was a sacred place whose stories were told to keep alive the memory of those who perished and those who survived. For decades after the war ended, “Never Again” was repeated to ensure that this kind of unleashed hatred and vitriol, resulting in these sorts of inhuman actions, would never happen again. And most of us in the world were confident that nothing like this could ever happen again!
This visit was different.
First, I am different. I am 24 years older. What I try to convince myself of is “unbelievable.” I need to believe.
Second, the world is different. Hatred, vitriol, and cruelty have become normalized. The vile antisemitic tropes that were used to degrade and denigrate people are not only ripe, but they are blossoming. Regrettably, in many places, they are in full bloom. This kind of hate flourishes on the dark web, and in the full light of day. Repulsive speech and actions have become acceptable. Throughout the world we see the rise of political parties with slogans reminiscent of a world which we thought could never be resurrected. And not only is it resurrected, but these parties have also gained representation in congresses and parliaments in the same countries where brave citizens sacrificed and fought against this to make the world safe for all.
Third, the camp is not the same. Shockingly, there are some people who visit the camp, stand next to the crematory ruins, on the rim of the entrance of the first experiment for a gas chamber, beside the remains of a barracks, who say: “this did not happen.” When you tell a lie often enough, people tend to believe it. That’s what happened prior to and during World War II. And in many parts of our world, it is happening now.
I am at a time in my life when more people than not ask me “When are you going to retire?” Here’s my response. Not only am I not going to retire, I am also committing to rededicate myself to engaging in education programs and social justice issues concerning basic human rights related to antisemitism and anti-LGBTQ hatred. All in, in my “golden years” I will not stand by and silently witness the normalization of hatred.
I write this article with both a heavy and a hopeful heart. When I say things are unbelievable, I reinforce in my own mind that I shouldn’t believe them. I am awake to the reality and the knowledge that I must believe what I see, hear, and witness. When I believe it, I will be able to address it in ways that, hopefully, will change where we are, and where we can go as a civil society.
We can choose hate, or we can choose to stand up to hate. We can be silent, or we can call people out when they say or do things that are rooted in prejudice and hate. Each of us can use our voice and our platform for good. We can choose to make excuses for bad behavior, or we can call it out. We can acquaint ourselves with history. We can familiarize ourselves with the consequences when hate is permitted to run amok. We can call out when we see lies presented as truth. And we can challenge people who are fearful or intimidated into saying and behaving in ways that are unacceptable.
When we sit by as people are being dehumanized, referred to as the “other,” we are at the entrance to the gates of Hell. I went through those gates as a tourist. I’ve listened to and read testimonies, seen films and photographs of what Hell looks like. If we consider ourselves members of the human race, we need to take that membership seriously and be aware of what it means to be human. To have hope in the future we need to discover compassion within and speak out against antisemitism and all forms of hate. We cannot excuse the inexcusable and we must believe the unbelievable.
In life’s most challenging moments, how we respond influences both our immediate wellbeing and long-term recovery. Crises arrive uninvited, testing our resilience when we feel most vulnerable. The following tips offer guidance through the turbulence, toward steadier ground.
Remain Calm: When crisis emerges, take a gentle body scan — notice your breathing, pulse, and physical sensations. Do not judge, just observe. Then begin to breathe and focus on your breath. The key is to avoid panic. When we panic, we cannot solve problems effectively. The goal is to think clearly while being aware of what is happening in your body. During this process, pause, take more slow, deep breaths. For some people, repeating prayers that offer solace, doing mindful practice, mindfulness, or engaging playfully with a pet can help.
Assess The Situation: From this centered state notice where you are physically, mentally, and emotionally. Then, identify the elements defining the crisis. What risks exist? What consequences might follow different actions? This assessment doesn’t require perfect information — only honest recognition of what is known and unknown in this moment.
Create Safety: Do what you need to get out of harm’s way. Look around, listen attentively, and notice your surroundings with fresh eyes. Take actions that move you toward greater security, extending this same protective attention to others if they’re with you.
Gather Your Support Circle: Reach out to those whose compassion brings calm — trusted friends, family members, professionals, or others who have walked similar paths. Seek those who offer the support you need rather than imposing what they believe you should want. Throughout the situation, maintain connection with beloved others. Consider engaging in creative activities that redirect mental energy — photography, gardening, music, reading, or writing — offering your mind the opportunity to “reset.”
Communicate with Transparency: Share information others need to hear to assist you, especially during medical emergencies when providers need accurate knowledge of your condition to offer effective care with minimal risk. Honest communication about symptoms, relevant medical history, concerns, and needs, creates the foundation for receiving proper assistance.
Create a Crisis Plan: Consider creating a simple emergency kit kept in your vehicle or near an exit. Maintain accessible records of essential medications, identification, and emergency contacts — both digitally and physically. Identify people who might assist with temporary housing, caregiving, pet-care, or other practical needs that could arise.
Honor Your Fundamental Needs: In crisis, the basics become precious: adequate rest, nourishment, hydration, and moments of quiet. Reflect on what essentials you require and consider how to ensure access to these necessities even during disruption. Tending to these fundamental needs becomes an act of self-compassion during challenging times.
Remember that getting through times of crisis times isn’t about handling everything perfectly. It’s about showing up as best we can, being kind to ourselves, and figuring things out as we go. Sometimes the hardest moments teach us what we’re made of and connect us more deeply to what matters. We might surprise ourselves with what we can handle, even when it feels impossible at first.
I’ve co-authored a book about kindness. I believe deeply in the lasting effects of love. It is in that context that I share my own daily habit. Each morning, I say thank you for another day and ask for an opportunity to make a difference in this world.
To that end, I look for signs of connection to those who came before me — a robin reminds me that my father is near, a butterfly reminds me of my mother. I feel their presence and listen for their guidance. Certain songs transport me to moments in my past, conjuring places, people, and, sometimes, lessons learned.
This daily habit provides continuity to my life. I’m grateful that my journey has been a healthy one so far. Though everything is unpredictable, I express gratitude however I can and move through the world appreciating all the companions I’ve known along the way.
Dr. Dale Atkinsdale@drdaleatkins.comwww.drdaleatkins.com

Dr. Dale Atkins is a licensed psychologist as well as a relationship expert focusing on families, wellness, stress, and living a balanced, meaningful life.

Title: The Battle of Berlin.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
2
Listen
Share
Almost three-quarters of a century ago, the German Army had been pushed back to Berlin. Six years of war culminated in fierce fighting through the streets of Berlin. Adolf Hitler claimed his Third Reich would last for a thousand years, yet by the end of the battle his army was depleted, and his right-hand men had begun to abandon him.
The battle, which was predominantly between German and Soviet Union soldiers, was the last stand of the Nazi regime. Yet the swift advancement of the Allies on both the Eastern and Western Front meant that by the time the Battle of Berlin began, the war was coming to a gradual and bloody end.
A battle which resulted in Germany’s surrender came at a significant human cost. Over three-quarters of a million people, soldiers and civilians were either killed or wounded. Society within Berlin was almost destroyed. Destruction of the city began on the 19th April 1945. The Soviet Union began shelling the city in preparation for the tank and infantry assault. Six days later, led by General Zhukov, the first Russian soldiers broke through to the Berlin suburbs. Day by day, more and more of outer-Berlin fell into Soviet hands.
The counter-attack which was desperately needed by the Germans came from the 12th army, commanded by General Wenck, on April 27th. Yet the sheer number of Soviet soldiers, the lack of resources at Wenck’s disposal and tactical bombing from the Royal Air Force to delay the German reinforcements ultimately made sure that the counter-attack had no real impact. Wenck was halted and the Soviet forces were just 15 miles from the centre of the city. By early May, the Third Reich and everything which Nazism stood for was on the brink of total collapse.
In the meantime, Hitler was deep in his bunker underneath the streets where his people were being slaughtered by an invading force. One of his final acts as German leader was to send members of the Hitler youth out onto the bombed-out streets of Berlin. Many of these would fall during the dying days of the Third Reich.
The people who had followed him, often so loyally, for many years had been left to die by Hitler at the hands of the Soviet Union. When British and American troops made their way into the city from the west, Berlin was surrounded by the Allied forces. The Reichstag lay in ruins, as did the Nazi regime.
It had taken the Allies almost five years to regain a foothold in continental Europe, with Britain and France suffering greatly in the process. Millions of lives were lost in the struggle to crush fascism and the slaughter had been taken to the streets of a city previously considered impregnable by Allied command.
Berliners were, like at the end of the First World War, left with their governments in ruin. Thousands of people lay dead in Berlin, over a million were without power and clean water, yet for many, the worst was yet to come. Although the Second World War was over, the fear an all-new type of warfare was beginning to grip the continent.
This story was posted on Viewpoint Weekly, we publish stories and send our readers a weekly digest to give you new and unique perspectives on politics, history and culture. If you enjoyed it, give us a follow.

Title: Before and After the Wall: My Life in Berlin
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Twenty five years ago this week, TV images flashed on screen of people singing and dancing atop the Berlin Wall.
It seemed almost impossible. I gulped, smiled and felt all tingly.
The fall of the Berlin Wall on Nov. 9, 1989, was emotional and personal for me. Years earlier, I had lived on the free side of the divided city at the height of the Cold War as an American military high school student. Were our neighbors trapped in the East now free after nearly three decades of Soviet control?
To stem the flow of East Berliners who wanted to escape, a jagged 27-mile wall cut the city into two halves, and 100 miles of barbed wire encircled the back half of West Berlin, making it an island city. But as American military dependents, we enjoyed a good life and freedom in a cosmopolitan half protected by American, British and French soldiers.
Those in East Berlin experienced a daily existence that was dreary and drab behind a 13-foot-tall concrete barrier. Although all roads in West Berlin ended at the wall, we couldn’t help but see the oppression on the other side. “This wall is an illusion,” read graffiti painted on the free side. “You stand like a scab, an unhealing wound,” were scrawled words I still remember today.
With my father’s U.S. Air Force status we were allowed to venture into the East. We occasionally drove through the famous Checkpoint Charlie border crossing in our gigantic1962 Pontiac Star Chief. During day trips, we would purchase camera gear, crystal glassware and wall clocks in shops intended for visiting communist dignitaries.
We avoided the regular markets with no fresh fruit, and shoe stores with only one size, style and color.
On one outing my family returned to our car to find people standing by the trunk, which was large enough to hold three people. They asked us to take them over to the West.
My father just shook his head “no” and told us to get in the car. He had heard of other GI’s who had smuggled East Berliners back to the West and were caught by the American military police. U.S. officials would immediately transfer those soldiers who risked an international incident. They would be sent from West Berlin (a plum assignment) to a desolate outpost in South Korea as punishment the next day, or so the rumor went.
On my 16th birthday, my father took me over to the East for dinner at the Moscow Haus, a high-end restaurant frequented by communist officials. Within minutes, a man in a Russian uniform joined us at the table. In decent English, he asked about the stripes on my father’s uniform and what they meant.
I remember great awkwardness and a racing heartbeat as the soldier continued to sit with us as we remained silent. Finally the Soviet officer returned to his own table. Who was he? Where did he come from? Could we have disappeared that night, deep in the heart of East Berlin?
Another time we tried to buy a motorcycle in a showroom full of choices, or so we thought. The clerk pulled a big book from behind the counter and asked us to write in our name and address. “Three years,” he told us. “What about these in the store?” we asked. No, those were just for display, he said. We would need to get on a list and wait, so we declined.
While the Soviet east sat basically untouched and neglected for 28 years, the fall of the Wall led to massive, but slow, renovations.
The former districts of East Berlin today are festive places, full of upscale townhouses, offbeat art galleries and ethnic restaurants. Playhouses host performances that rival those of New York and Las Vegas, and American celebrities like Matt Damon and Tom Cruise turn up weekly for vacations or movie premieres.
The former swath that cut through the center of city has provided prime real estate for development again, especially along the Spree River. The city’s subway systems are united and provide seamless and efficient transportation for Berlin’s 3.5 million people.
Everything happens on a grand scale, whether it’s a massive fireworks display at the Brandenburg Gate on New Year’s Eve or the opening of Europe’s largest train station days before the 2006 World Cup soccer tournament began. The main government building, Der Reichstag, is a contrast of visions — with old style below and a futurist glass dome above that allows visitors to peer into the legislative chamber below.
By guiding University of Florida student journalists the past 10 years on study-abroad trips, I have been privileged to help tell the story of a reborn Berlin. Armed with digital cameras, voice recorders and laptops, UF students have spent two weeks every May since 2005 reporting on a cross-section of Berliners. From the city where I discovered my interest in photojournalism, we document some of the people and places that exemplify Berlin’s ongoing spirit of freedom. It’s a subtle revelation as the students come to understand the significance of what they are seeing and feeling.
Many return to Florida saying they’ve been changed; they have felt the underlying spirit of survival, transformation, creativity and openness. Most are surprised and enthralled that the city lives up its reputation of “anything goes.” Some students feel more patriotic after learning and seeing first-hand how American forces kept the city alive following World War II. Some say they want to return to Berlin and open a coffee shop – or work for the Fat Tire Bike Tour company. Most have heard the expression first-hand from Berliners that “you can be who you want to be in Berlin.”
All remember Dr. Pong — a virtually unmarked club where the only entertainment is a single ping-pong table and loud music. Holding a beverage in one hand and a paddle in the other, up to 30 partiers circle the table in a counter-clockwise motion, enjoying a group game that shrinks in size as players miss and have to sit out. After the final two players battle for the championship, the winner bangs the table three times with his paddle, and everyone starts up again. It’s a happy mix – a free-for-all of ages, styles, religions and politics.
Dr. Pong is only a hole-in-the-wall pub, a relic in the former East. It’s poorly lit, has unadorned concrete walls and is full of choking smoke. Yet it speaks volumes about the edginess of Berlin, the acceptance of others and the freedom that the united city now enjoys.
Twenty-five years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, Germany’s capital continues to reinvent itself, balancing between an historic past and an optimistic future to remain one of the world’s leading cities. I’m proud to be a part of that transformation every year.
John has been teaching photojournalism at the University of Florida since 1991. Each summer, he organizes a trip to Berlin for students interested in documentary journalism.
