Title: Fans Find Community in Football at the Euro 2024 Championship in Berlin
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

International journalism students report from Berlin, the heart of Europe.

--
Listen
Share
By John Glab
Jacob Sweetman, a long-time Union Berlin football fan, walks through the empty summer stands of the Stadion An der Alten Försterei, located among trees in eastern Berlin’s Köpenick neighborhood. The stadium dates from 1920 and was famously redeveloped around 15 years ago with the help of 2300 fan volunteers devoted to the team. Sweetman, the club’s English language spokesman, loves to recount stories of the club’s historic rivalries — particularly with western Berlin’s Hertha club.
He remembers a game in 2019 when tension ran so high among both sets of supporters that Hertha fans threw fireworks onto the pitch, setting on fire part of a net behind the goal, and delaying the game. “When Hertha and Union started playing each other more, there was a friction that formed between the two,” Sweetman said.
It’s more about pride in one’s team than any lingering East-West resentments. “It’s not that I or any other Union supporters hate Hertha. We want both of our clubs to be successful,” Sweetman said. “When it comes to playing against each other though, there are no friends in football. We want to beat the fuckers.”
This summer, Union and Hertha fans, along with others across Germany, left local rivalries aside to express their fervent passion for football — soccer to North Americans — on the national and European level, as German cities hosted the Euro 2024 tournament.
The competition saw 24 national teams compete for the UEFA European Cup. At the center of the month-long event was the nation’s capital, Berlin. Along with hosting the final match, the city welcomed more visitors than any other Germany city did, estimated at more than 2 million.
In Berlin, grassroots excitement over the Euros was everywhere. On the S-Bahn from the airport into the city, Austrian supporters in football shirts and lederhosen with three streaks of red, white, and red on their faces filled the seats. Billboards on the sides of buildings displayed the competition’s logos in massive fonts. On the streets, people were constantly talking with each other about who they thought would win a certain match, or sitting down at cafes and bars to watch games on large television screens that appeared to have been set up by any establishment that wanted to keep its paying patrons during the tournament.
Felix Tamsut, a German sports journalist who focuses on football fan culture, says that when someone supports their national football team, it comes in the context of their history and connections to their country. Their expressions of nationalism occur on a continent where millions of people have died from nationalist wars.
“Supporting a national team is a way of identifying with your own national identity,” Tamsut said. “As a result, when you combine the very strong emotions in football and national feelings of pride with national symbols, those feelings are not neutral.”
On the night of a match between Belgium and Romania, Romania was trailing for most of the match, but its fans persisted in loud support. For them, having the national team perform on the global stage of the Euros was a source of national pride. “Historically because we were always oppressed by the big powers from the East and West, we’ve always stayed together, and united under the national umbrella,” said Petru Badea, a Romanian who has been living in Berlin for the past several years. He said coming out to support Romania was about being together as a community, and a victory would be just a plus. “Even if we lose 10–0, we’re still going to love our team.”
This national fervor is most apparent at the host stadiums, such as the Olympiastadion — the home stadium of Hertha Berlin — which hosted a group-stage match between Austria and the Netherlands in late June. The stadium’s Nazi-era, neoclassical facade opened into a looming, cavernous space with orange and red walls of supporters sloping down towards the green pitch in the center. Sunlight poured through the gap in the stadium’s west curve onto the 70,000 fans in the stands, as if lighting a cauldron on fire.
Austria took an early lead, but the Netherlands tied the game shortly after halftime. The mass of Netherlands orange in the stands grew louder and louder before it was out-chanted by Austrian supporters when their team again took over the lead. The Dutch tied the game again, but Austria won in the end.
The energy coming from Austrian supporters in the last 10 minutes of the match was unrelenting. “Immer Wieder Österreich” (Forever Austria) they continuously repeated, echoing off the stadium walls, drowning out any noise from the Dutch. At the whistle, the Austrian fans lingered in the stadium singing together as one.
Austrian supporter Petr Schladming described it as the best result in the modern history of Austrian football. “For us it’s such a big moment to see we have all this potential. The emotions are just so big and great. Everyone from the country is singing these songs together and it gives you chills with this communal feeling,” he said, hoarse after 90 minutes of shouting. The S-Bahn trains back to the center of Berlin were loud with song as the celebrations continued through the night.
Outside the major stadiums, the largest display of national Euro fan support came at Berlin’s Brandenburg Gate fan zone, especially when the host country Germany played. In the Round of 16 game against Denmark, around 100,000 people came to the outdoor area to watch — though the actual game took place in Dortmund. A mass of people dressed in white with German flags draped across their shoulders stretched for a kilometer in front of the main screen.
Chants rang out, and each action hundreds of kilometers away in Dortmund provoked a reaction. During the 90-plus minutes of Germany’s 2–0 victory, the park erupted in jubilation after both goals. In close quarters, people moshed against each other, pressing forward toward the main screen as if trying to get closer to their heroes. Individual Germans, with their own varying club allegiances, were all united in support for the national team.
Overt expressions of nationalism are all but taboo among Germans given the country’s imperialist, Nazi, and East German communist pasts. “You always have to draw a line between the national team and Germany in general,” said Jano Rotanburg, a German at the fan zone for the Round of 16 match. “I think that the Euros, and Germany winning, is a great way for Germans to be proud of themselves. But it could bring a great danger if the wrong people were to phrase it a certain way.”
The wrong people Rotanburg referred to are adherents of the far-right and their main political party Alternative for Germany (AfD). The AfD uses nationalist, anti-LGBTQ and racist, anti-immigrant sentiments in its messaging. The party has become more popular in recent years — particularly among youth.
“The whole country is in a critical state right now, especially with the rise of the AfD,” said Niko Mohr, a Berliner who was watching the Germany match at one of the fan zones. “Germany is very much divided between the urban and rural areas, where cities have more progressive ideals while rural areas have the old ways of thinking.” He explained that many have felt left behind by the government, and have embraced the populist messages of the AfD.
A main AfD focus is reclaiming Germany’s national pride, and rejecting the cultural shame that they say is imbedded in post-World War II German society. Many Germans worried this summer that the far-right could use the Euros as a rallying point. But sports journalist Felix Tamsut noted that it hasn’t been the case.
The German Football Association (DFB) has made a point of stressing inclusivity for LGBTQ people and migrants and so the AfD hasn’t seen the German national team as “their team,” which would represent a less inclusive image of Germany. With more players from migrant backgrounds now on the team, football reflects the country as it currently is — not as it used to be.
Still, right-wing populism has been sprouting up across many countries in Europe, and for them football is a perfect vehicle to spread their credos. “International tournaments, whether you like it or not, have always had a political element,” Tamsut said. “A national team doing well or failing has repercussions on a country’s national identity.” Benito Mussolini used the 1934 and 1938 FIFA World Cups to try to show how strong fascist Italy was. In 2024, many world leaders are trying to do the same.
In Hungary, Prime Minister Viktor Orbán leads an authoritarian, far-right autocratic government. He has revived a nationalist narrative tied to “The Humiliation of the Treaty of Trianon” which redrew Hungary’s borders after World War I. A large part of Orbán’s platform is to regain these lands he sees as stolen, and the sentiment has emboldened many Hungarians — including football fans.
Orbán has invested millions into Hungary’s footballing infrastructure, and success at the Euros would have helped promote the nationalistic Hungarian agenda to the rest of Europe and the world. Hungary didn’t prevail at the Euros, eliminated at an early stage. But the team’s ultra-nationalistic supporters made their presence felt in those German cities where Hungary was playing. In the stands and on the streets, they wore black, displayed images of a Greater Hungary, and frequently sang racist chants, intimidating those around them.
Within the Berlin fan zone, organizers tried to maintain a space free from politics. “We think of the fan zone more as ‘united by football,’ working with the famous UEFA slogan. We want to unite cultures and for everyone to enjoy themselves, have fun, and make new friends,” said Petra Neye, spokesperson for Kulturprojekte Berlin, the company that ran the fan zone on behalf of the Berlin state government.
“We don’t want people to use it as a political platform. It’s a bit of an escape from all the bad stuff happening in the world. People need a break from it.” A key house ‘rule’ the event management agency enacted was to allow only flags of nations participating in this year’s Euros to be flown inside the fan zones.
Keeping politics out was easier said than done. For Turkey versus Austria, hundreds of Turkish supporters showed up in red, wearing the flag like a cape to support the national team. From the earliest goal onwards, supporters were unrelenting, with several people in front of the crowd leading coordinated, clapping chants, and each turn in the game prompting a frenzied reaction of hope. In the match, Turkish player Merih Demiral celebrated one of his goals with the Grey Wolf hand gesture, an important symbol for Turkish right-wing extremists who make up part of the support for Recep Tayyip Erdoğan, the president of Turkey.
Demiral was given a two-match suspension for the gesture. In the following game against the Netherlands in the quarter finals, many Turkish fans showed the Grey Wolf gesture in support of Demiral after his suspension. At the Brandenburg Gate fan zone, organizers asked them to stop, preventing an escalation.
Berlin resident Merve Guendogdua came to the fan zone for the atmosphere and connection with the other Turkish fans in Germany. “It feels good because we have the same nation and all support the same team. We connect together, we watch the game together, and we feel everything together. It’s great,” she said. She added that the large Turkish population in Germany meant many Germans supported Turkey, as well, at the Euros. And being German, she also supported the German national team.
At the Brandenburg Gate during the Germany and Spain quarter final match, another showing of 100,000 lined up through the Tiergarten to cheer Germany on. Chants of “Deutschland” bellowed out from supporters until Dani Olmo’s goal for Spain early in the second half. Now, the German fans watched anxiously as the clock ticked up towards 90 minutes, pleading with the higher powers of football to let Germany score, in order to stay in the tournament. The situation looked dire until Florian Wirtz bounced the ball off the post and into the goal at the last minute to even the score.
Immediately, German supporters leapt off the ground, erupting in euphoria. Strangers embraced each other as they bounced up and down in pure delight. Their dream of being European champions on home soil was still alive for at least 30 more minutes. Throughout extra time, Germany appeared to control the match over Spain. But in the final moments of the match, silence spread across the fan zone as Spain’s Mikel Merino headed the ball into Germany’s goal zone. Devastation numbed the faces of Germany fans, who desperately urged their players on for the last few seconds before the whistle was ultimately blown. Germany was out.
Afterwards, everyone in the fan zone fell silent, partaking in a solemn mass exodus out of the Tiergarten to go their own separate ways. One fan, Philip Buchholz, said that even though there was an immense collective sadness, Germans would forget about it in a couple days, and everything would go back to normal in the country.
The semifinals saw England beat the Netherlands and then the final game went to Spain, which beat England 2 to 1. With the air already out of the balloon for Berliners after Germany lost in the quarter finals, the energy on Berlin’s streets never rose to out-of-control levels and organizers were pleased to report no major incidents during the tournament.
A collaborative spirit persisted, with football — as marketers liked to insist — bringing people together. Like everything, though, this zealous unity is ephemeral. International tournaments end after only a month. The divisions that separate Europe and the world are still there and nationalism is on the rise. But for one month, everyone appeared to be united by football and met each other on common ground.
At the Union Berlin club in Köpenick, and for Jacob Sweetman specifically, the sport has offered a sense of belonging. From those who rebuilt the stadium, to those who are there for every match day of the year, the team offers community. “This club is how I met so many of the people Iknow,” Sweetman said. “Coming here each week, I’ve developed a bond with all these people, and I’m so lucky to have this club be my life.” That, he says, is what it means to be a football fan.
John Glab is a student at the University of Iowa who is reporting from Berlin this summer and covered the 2024 UEFA Euro championships, interviewing approximately 20 fans from across Europe.
--
--

Title: From Berlin to Zanzibar: The Journey Behind Zanzibar’s Why Not Nightclub
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Life often has a way of steering us toward unexpected paths, and mine led me from the bustling event scene in Berlin to the serene shores of Zanzibar. My name is Emin Mahrt, and I’m the founder of Why Not Limited, a nightclub I’ve envisioned as a space where music, culture, and connection come alive in this tropical paradise.
For years, Berlin was my playground—a city renowned for its underground scene, experimental music, and cultural diversity. It was here that I honed my understanding of what makes an event unforgettable. From intimate gatherings to large-scale productions, Berlin taught me how sound, space, and atmosphere intertwine to create something truly magical.
But as vibrant as Berlin is, I began to crave something different. The fast pace of city life, while exhilarating, left me searching for a deeper connection—both with myself and with the world around me. That’s when Zanzibar came into view.
Zanzibar is a place of contrasts, where tradition and modernity coexist in harmony. From the moment I arrived, I was captivated by the island’s rich cultural tapestry, warm community, and, of course, its natural beauty. Yet, as I explored, I saw an opportunity: Zanzibar had a vibrant tourism scene, but there was room to introduce a unique nightlife experience—a place where locals and visitors alike could come together to celebrate music and creativity.
The idea for Why Not Limited began to take shape. I wanted to create a venue that wasn’t just another club but a destination—a space where the energy of Berlin’s underground scene could meet the soul of Zanzibar.
Starting a project like this wasn’t without its challenges. Zanzibar’s pace of life is different from Berlin’s efficiency, and adapting to this new rhythm required patience and flexibility. From sourcing materials to navigating local regulations, each step was a lesson in perseverance.
But the community made it worthwhile. I found incredible talent among local artists, DJs, and craftspeople, all eager to contribute their skills and perspectives to the project. Collaborating with them brought the vision for Why Not to life in a way that felt authentic to Zanzibar while honoring the influences I brought from Berlin.
The name Why Not embodies the spirit of curiosity and openness that has driven this journey. It’s a question that invites exploration and challenges the status quo—a reminder that sometimes, the best experiences come from saying “yes” to the unexpected.
Our club is designed to reflect this ethos. The music lineup is eclectic, blending local sounds like taarab and bongo flava with global genres, from techno to Afrohouse. The venue itself combines modern design with traditional Zanzibari elements, creating an atmosphere that feels both familiar and fresh.
Why Not isn’t just a club; it’s a meeting point—a place where people from all walks of life can share stories, dance, and create memories.
Looking back, the journey from Berlin to Zanzibar has been transformative. It’s taught me to embrace uncertainty, adapt to new environments, and trust in the power of collaboration. Why Not Limited is more than a nightclub; it’s a testament to what can happen when you follow your instincts and dare to dream big.
I’m thrilled to see how Why Not grows and evolves, becoming a part of Zanzibar’s cultural landscape. For those who find themselves on this beautiful island, I hope you’ll stop by, share a moment, and perhaps ask yourself the same question that brought us here: Why not?
